PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I present the committee's report entitled Managing Australia's World Heritage , together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I table today follows the inquiry by the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts into the management of Australia's world heritage areas. The terms of reference for this inquiry focused the committee's attention on the management of existing world heritage areas. It did not require the committee to consider the relative merits of sites or the processes leading up to the nomination of new areas or cultural sites to the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has 11 world heritage properties. They are scattered across Australia—only the ACT and Victoria have none. All of the properties were nominated for their outstanding natural values and some, such as Uluru and the Tasmanian Wilderness, were also nominated for their cultural values. In addition to being physically separated and diverse, the world heritage properties differ with respect to their management. Some of the properties, like the Northern Territory parks—Kakadu and Uluru—are managed by the Commonwealth. Others are the responsibility of the states, and yet others, like the Great Barrier Reef, have combined state and Commonwealth management systems.

While in many cases it is the states which manage the world heritage properties, it is the Commonwealth government that has the responsibility to protect them under the terms of the world heritage convention. The inquiry on which my committee is reporting today dealt with the extent of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for world heritage protection and also considered the adequacy of funding for the world heritage areas.

Considerable controversy has been associated with the world heritage listing of many of Australia's world heritage areas. The Queensland and Tasmanian governments challenged the Commonwealth on listings in the High Court, and deep divisions have been created in many communities. It was therefore important for the committee to examine the effectiveness of the consultative arrangements that have been established for world heritage areas.

All the witnesses to the inquiry were agreed that the World Heritage Convention confers on the Commonwealth responsibility for Australia's world heritage areas. There were, however, differences of opinion about the extent of the Commonwealth's responsibilities, as distinct from those of the states. The committee considered that it is the Commonwealth's prime responsibility to ensure that high standards of management are established and maintained in all world heritage areas. The committee identified a number of ways in which the Commonwealth should meet these responsibilities:

PARA.TAB: it should ensure that all world heritage areas have management plans which are based on the areas' world heritage values;
it should ensure that, where appropriate, world heritage values are respected in regional and strategic plans;

it should ensure that the values of world heritage areas are redefined as new knowledge about the areas accumulates and the concept of world heritage evolves, and that these values are incorporated into any updates of management plans;
it should ensure that consultative bodies are established for each world heritage area;

BREAK.TAB: it should sponsor research into world heritage management, and collect and disseminate information about best prac tice, for example, in relation to consultation, monitoring, managing the impact of visitors, and the use of user charges to recover some part of the cost of managing world heritage;

PARA.TAB: it should assist with educating the public and displaying world heritage;

it should provide funding for world heritage areas on the basis of financial agreements with the states for all state managed world heritage areas to provide long‐term certainty to world heritage managers; and
it should retain legislation that can be used to protect world heritage if other measures fail.

SPEECH.PARA: In many of these areas, a good start has been made. However, it is important that the momentum so far achieved be maintained and new initiatives—like establishing systematic monitoring of all world heritage areas—be pursued.

The committee has also recommended that, in the future, issues such as the development of management plans and funding arrangements be determined before an area is nominated for the World Heritage List.

Funding is one of the critical issues for world heritage areas. Some sites, especially those administered by the Commonwealth, are reasonably well treated and some state managed areas receive sizeable additional funds from the Commonwealth. However, other state managed areas have received very little from the Commonwealth—for example, Fraser Island and Lord Howe Island. This is an inequitable situation which can only be resolved from the Commonwealth's viewpoint by distributing Commonwealth funds through a consistent approach based on the needs of the individual world heritage areas. It is important to stress, though, that the Commonwealth should not be regarded as a bottomless source of funds. The committee considered that the Commonwealth should only provide funds as a supplement to state funding, and state funding should continue at least at the level that existed before world heritage status was conferred.

BREAK.PARA: In addition to Commonwealth funds being distributed inequitably, funding is insufficient to establish and maintain high standards of world heritage management. On the basis of the information available to the committee, it is estimated that an additional $20.6 million are needed immediately and then an additional $16 million per annum if world heritage areas are to be managed adequately. The Natural Heritage Trust is expected to make $12 million available to world heritage areas over four years; this is welcome but inadequate.

The committee noted that user charges, such as entry fees, have been introduced in many world heritage areas. It supported user charges as an appropriate way in which to supplement the funds available for world heritage management, provided that the revenue from such charges is returned as extra funding to the area from which it is collected and does not simply return to be added to consolidated revenue.

The committee considered that user charges should be more than a token amount and approved, in principle, the recent decision by the Commonwealth government to increase the environmental management charge on visitors to the Great Barrier Reef. The committee was very concerned, however, about the manner in which the recent increase in fees was introduced on an inequitable base, without consultation and without adequate lead time.

The committee also noted the plethora of different charges applied by different levels of government in the Great Barrier Reef region, and recommended that the Commonwealth, with state cooperation, review these charges with a view to devising a more appropriate way of levying fees. With increasing pressures on world heritage areas and reduced funds with which to manage these pressures, there is a role for the private sector in providing works, services and infrastructure, though any private sector activity in world heritage areas will need to be very carefully controlled by government managing agencies.

It is obviously preferable that the Commonwealth and state governments cooperate in protecting, conserving and presenting world heritage areas to the public, as the world heritage convention requires. However, if world heritage values are threatened and state governments fail to act to protect these values, the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act empowers the Commonwealth to intervene. While the use of this legislation has proved contentious, the committee considers that its retention is essential for the protection of world heritage values. The committee recommended that the legislation be strengthened, but did not agree with the suggestion that additional legislation should establish a general framework for world heritage management by the Commonwealth.

There is other legislation that needs examination if we are to be sure that Australia is meeting its world heritage commitments—for example, the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. In addition, an overall review of the range of state and territory legislation would be useful to identify whether there are deficiencies. The committee also considered the legal aspects of administering the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, and in particular possible solutions to the problems that arise from the fact that the boundaries of the marine park and the world heritage area do not coincide.

Most of the recommendations in the report are of a general nature, referring to all world heritage areas. But there are a few recommendations which refer to specific areas—for example, the Great Barrier Reef, Fraser Island, the Riversleigh Fossil Mammal Site, Kakadu and Uluru. The committee was concerned about the ineffective community consultation on Fraser Island. It was also concerned by reports of poor relations between the then Australian Nature Conservation Agency and the Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory, and recommended moves to improve the cooperation between the two agencies. I was pleased to note the very recent decision to have the Commonwealth's Director of National Parks and Wildlife and the Director of the Northern Territory's Parks and Wildlife Commission sit on one another's boards of management.

Overall, it appeared to the committee that much has been achieved through the listing of Australia's world heritage areas. But it is also obvious that much remains to be done, some of it urgently. It is the committee's hope that the report I am tabling today will assist in the process of improving world heritage management.

The report is the result of nearly two years of work by the present Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts and its predecessor in the last parliament. Most of the work of the inquiry was carried out by the previous committee under the chairmanship of Mr John Langmore, and it has fallen to the current committee to finish what was an almost completed task. I would like to acknowledge the work of Mr Langmore and all of the members of the committee, both past and present, who have contributed to this inquiry. I particularly would also thank the committee staff: Ian Dundas, Dr Sarah Hnatiuk, Susan Cardell, Marlene Lyons, and the many others who have assisted with this considerable work. This is a significant report and it certainly gives me very great pleasure, on behalf of the committee, to commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is privileged to have 11 of the world's 469 heritage sites. All of these sites are of such outstanding universal cultural or natural significance that, after a rigorous process of nomination and evaluation, they have been declared a world heritage area or monument. The inquiry, the report of which we are just tabling, found that Australia's management of world heritage sites has been uneven and often inadequate. Only three—Kakadu, Uluru-Kata Tjuta and the Tasmanian wilderness—could be described as well managed and just barely adequately funded; even in those, the rangers and attentive visitors would have no difficulty with suggesting improvements.

PARA.BREAK: In all the others there are some serious inadequacies in the structure or implementation of management and of funding. In all of them dedicated staff, with a sense of the significance of the task in which they are involved, are struggling to cope with insufficient political recognition, unresolved intergovernmental conflict, incomplete man agement structures, incomplete or poorly maintained infrastructure, inadequate funding and insufficient staff.

SPEECH.PARA: These difficulties were readily apparent to the members of the environment committee. The seriousness of these inadequacies contributed to enabling the committee members to reach agreement about our report. I would like to express warm appreciation to the Chair, the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), and to other members for seeking and finding compromises which all members could support. Given the diversity of the membership of the committee, this is a significant achievement and must be recognised as adding weight to our recommendations and urgency to the importance of their implementation.

Amongst the main recommendations are recognition of the urgency of complete management plans for those sites which do not yet have them and the crucial importance of building tourist infrastructure adequate to cope with all visitors and to give them a significant educative experience. This is both the best way of minimising damage and of ensuring that tourists' appreciation of the natural environment is enhanced by their visit.

Every world heritage area should have an excellent tourist information centre, informative signs, viewing points, pathways and, where appropriate, boardwalks, lighting or floating barges. The world heritage emblem should be used throughout the areas. Training programs for a range of staff, particularly for private tour operators, often need to be upgraded, as well as there being the need for an increase in the number of ranger staff.

Funding agreements between the Commonwealth and Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australian governments must be quickly completed, in particular with the Queensland government about Fraser Island and Riversleigh fossil site and the Western Australian government about Shark Bay.

Finally, and most important of all, the Commonwealth should provide an additional $20.6 million next year and a further additional $16 million a year thereafter. These figures are the total of reasonable estimates of the needs of each area prepared in consultation with people who know each area well.

There were great pleasures for those involved in this inquiry for we had the opportunity to visit and be guided around most of Australia's beautiful world heritage areas. This was a privilege. With the help of outstanding staff, a comprehensive report has been prepared which makes concrete and practical recommendations.

I would particularly like to thank the staff—Ian Dundas, Sarah Hnatiuk, Susan Cardell and Marlene Lyons, as the chair has just mentioned. They did a particularly fine, effective and rigorous job. The thoroughness and openness of the inquiry and rigour and logic of the report give authority to the recommendations. I hope that the government will consider them quickly, endorse them and act on them promptly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry into the management arrangements of world heritage areas is certainly very timely given the controversy of listing and general management problems associated with a number of world heritage listed areas. Because of the significant areas of world heritage listing in my electorate and their impact on the general community of Leichhardt, I was pleased to be able to play a small role in the formulation of this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that I have limited time to discuss the report, I will restrict my comments to what I see as some of the key recommendations. First of all, it was very evident that funding, with the exception of Uluru and Kakadu, was extremely inadequate. I was pleased to see we were able to recommend that significant funding be made available if we are going to maintain the integrity of these parks. We believe that the amount of $20.6 million should be provided and $16 million per annum thereafter. If we are going to set these areas aside as world heritage areas, then it is absolutely critical that funding be provided for them.

PARA.BREAK: Another area in which I was pleased to see recommendations was community involvement. There were very strong recommendations to look at ensuring that local people are involved in the process right from the begin ning and all the way through. I think this is absolutely critical. We have seen incidences in my own electorate where the local community has been excluded from the process. As a consequence, there has been a tremendous amount of hostility and concern with regard to listings of world heritage areas and a lot of conflict within the community. With a little effort and significant involvement of the community you are going to suddenly have community ownership. I think that is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also recognised the need for compensation for the loss of use of an area. I think this is another important recommendation given that once these areas are listed in some cases there are restrictions for the land-holders in what they can do. I think it is very important that we acknowledge the right for compensation for these people.

One of the previous speakers mentioned looking into a user pays system. I think it is absolutely critical given the controversy that we created through the increase in the environmental management charges with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park operators. I think we need to look at that sensibly to make sure that we are totally aware of the impact of that. Knowing that we have to move into a user pays system, it is absolutely critical we put this on the agenda and have a look at it over all the world heritage areas.

We also need to look very closely at defining the boundaries of world heritage areas. I think it is a mistake to have some form of agenda that we are going to take a quota of land. The land has to be determined on its world heritage values. When we are doing these assessments it may well be that there are additional amounts of land that can be taken. There may also be land that does not meet world heritage value and it should be excluded or removed from world heritage areas. These areas do cost a lot of money to maintain and it is important that money is spent in the right areas.

There are a couple of recommendations though in which, while I support their general thrust, I believe we could have been much stronger. One of those is in regard to the Northern Territory government's involvement in the world heritage areas of Kakadu and Uluru. I feel it is important they have a stronger involvement. I also believe that private enterprise, while it is great to see that we are looking to them to provide vital infrastructure, should also have a role in management. They have a lot of knowledge. We do have ANCA, which is the broader umbrella organisation—the watchdog so to speak—but I believe private enterprise could play a much greater role.

The adoption of the 54 recommendations contained in this report will go a long way to addressing the current problems in improving and preserving the quality of our world heritage areas. Therefore, I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to congratulate the people who have been involved in the development of this report. As a recent member of the committee, I have to say that most of the work was done by my predecessors and other members who have made a contribution who are no longer here. But it is important too that there is a level of general agreement about what needs to be done in the management of our world heritage areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw to the attention of the House today a couple of the recommendations which I think are critical if a report like this is to have any weight in the long term. I think there is always a suspicion on the part of committee members, and indeed the public as a whole, that these reports are not necessarily used later by government as a basis for action. I would certainly urge the current Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and ministers who have a role in development to look very closely at the report's recommendations.

One of the things I would like to draw to the attention of the House is the recommendation by the committee—and it went to some trouble to get these figures fairly precisely—of the need for increased funding for the protection, conservation and presentation of world heritage areas. In fact, the committee recommends that the Commonwealth government—and this is not to exclude additional contributions from user pays and from state governments—should provide an additional $20.6 million immediately and $16 million a year thereafter.

In that context, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, in this budget we have been debating in recent weeks, the world heritage budget in particular has been cut by 39 per cent. Some $16.3 million was previously allocated and that is down to $9.3 million. That is a very significant reduction in funding available for environmental protection of world heritage areas.

When asked in the estimates committee how they thought the funding should be allocated for the various world heritage areas that are described in this report, the minister said that they needed to negotiate it with the states rather than look at some basis in need, as is indicated in recommendation 46, which says:

That the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, in consultation with world heritage area management authorities, identify and quantify specific additional funding needs in each of the world heritage areas as a basis for allocating the additional funds.
While it is important to negotiate with the state governments, it is really also a question of identifying what needs to be done and how much funding needs to be spent in each area.

One of the difficulties when the Commonwealth government cuts funding, as it has in this budget, is that the states move very quickly to match those cuts. That has certainly happened in the case of the Queensland government. So you have a compounding effect of reductions in funding. For example, there were significant cuts to the Wet Tropics Management Authority budget, from $4.7 million to $2.8 million—a reduction which we understand will again be matched, unfortunately, by the Queensland government. So the funds available there, in a recently declared area, will make it extremely difficult to bring up to speed not only the conservation and protection of that area but also presentation to the public of that world heritage area. I think all members of the committee were very keen to ensure that it was not left to the privileged few to have access to these areas but that it be managed carefully and appropriately funded.

I also draw attention to the fact that the government did make an explicit promise in their pre‐election policy to provide, quite apart from the heritage trust, an additional $4 million to heritage management. Not only has that not been provided but, as I say, cuts have also been made. The Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, acknowledged in the estimates committee that managing world heritage areas is a major challenge—something that is clearly underlined by the committee report—and yet we have seen these reductions.

We have also seen some significant problems in relation to the approval of activities which may well diminish the world heritage values of very important areas. I draw attention in that respect to the committee's deliberations in recommendations 7 and 8 on the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The committee recommends that the EP(IP) Act be amended to provide:
a) an environmental assessment be required where there is the possibility that a proposed action will damage the world heritage values of a listed world heritage area.

I do not need to remind members of the controversy that has erupted over the approval for the Port Hinchinbrook resort. It has been against the advice of the government's world heritage unit and a raft of serious scientific concerns, yet there has been no provision for an assessment of the impact under the EP(IP) Act of this very significant development. Similarly, in relation to Kakadu we have very significant proposals yet to be properly fleshed out, both in relation to the environmental impact and the impact on the community.

PARA.BREAK: Finally, something that I think the committee did not draw attention to was the fact that the government has changed its policy in relation to the listing of world heritage areas to require that in future they will proceed only with the agreement of the relevant state and territory governments. Given their reluctance to do that in the past, I think this means that the list we are dealing with at the mo ment may, in the foreseeable future, be the list and that we are not likely to see any further additions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the recommendations in this report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, brought down by the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss). Indeed, I would like to acknowledge the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who was the previous chairman of this committee. It is a shame that the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) is departing this chamber because there was bipartisan support to this inquiry. There was a lot of negotiation. Certainly the member for Fraser gave some very useful input, as did many of his colleagues. Regrettably, though, the member for Fremantle was not available for many of those dissertations. That obviously partly explains some of the statements she just made.

SPEECH.PARA: There are 11 world heritage parks, as was clearly mentioned by the previous speakers. We are very lucky in this country to have such a diversity both in cultural and physical attributes. Where I live, in northern New South Wales, the central eastern rainforest reserve has over five subregions of world heritage status. So I do have some affinity with those particular parks.

The terms of reference of this inquiry were to look at the Commonwealth responsibility and its international and national obligations to look at the effectiveness of the consultative arrangements with relevant stakeholders and at the funding adequacy for management of those national parks. Indeed, the key recommendations that came down were looking at the management structure.

There certainly has been a lot of controversy over the management of a number of these parks, but I am pleased to note that some of the recommendations in this report, I believe, will go to alleviating those concerns, particularly in relation to stakeholders, and encouraging the local community, particularly the indigenous people and the private sector, to have a role in the management plans. This was clearly demonstrated as a further need with some of the parks being managed in the Northern Territory. Certainly, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is a very good yardstick for future parks and some of those existing parks which are totally funded by the Commonwealth.

The other recommendations I would like to quickly brief the House on relate to the management plan and looking at a regular review—every five years—so that if there are changes in circumstances with land management and with the stakeholders they will be reviewed on a five‐yearly basis, along with a redefinition of the plan. Other recommendations relate to looking at managing the impact, particularly from the tourism angle, looking at areas of sustainable usage and at encouraging further education, through persuasion and adequate addressing of permits, to allow a more flexible usage within those parks, for both the park proprietors and, of course, the public. That was also demonstrated as a need in Kakadu.

The role of the private sector was also looked at in the report. It is critical to have a greater interface between private enterprise, between those locals earning the income from or participating in those parks, and the role that the Commonwealth and states have with relevant agencies.

I noted that the member for Fremantle mentioned that funding was not an issue raised in our committee meetings. Indeed, there was much discussion, and that is why there was universal agreement that there needed to be an extra $16 million per annum going to the parks and also a one‐off payment of $20 million. Obviously, a large section of this will come from our Natural Heritage Trust, which it is absolutely critical to get through this House, and part of it of course is going to maintaining, preserving and enhancing our world heritage parks.

In conclusion, this report should be seen as a landmark report for the management of our world heritage parks—for better management and better structures and, obviously, to protect the very assets; and that is why they were listed by UNESCO. Obviously it is looking at areas in which to recover costs through user charges in a sensible way and to give ownership back to the local communities, particularly to the indigenous people.

BREAK.PARA: There are 54 recommendations in this report. I hope that the Australian media, and no doubt the government agencies, will take time in reviewing this report. I would also like to commend the staff who were involved with this committee and the two previous chairmen, as mentioned, for the work that they have done.

Finally, what this is all about is preserving our natural world heritage assets and getting a better management structure. It is pleasing that, with the exception of one speaker today, we had universal support amongst our committee for a bipartisan approach to managing our assets so that we can pass them on to future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The genesis of this report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts was born out of the controversy that has, from time to time, surrounded matters to do with world heritage areas. Hopefully, the recommendations that the committee has produced might go some of the way to improving the situation in the management and continuing development of world heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth government of course has the obligation under the various agreements that it has entered into, but, like much of our federal system, the success of our abilities to fulfil those obligations requires a great deal of cooperation between the federal government and the states and territories. Importantly, as other speakers on this report have said, doing the right thing by ensuring the preservation of world heritage listed areas not only requires the action of government but also requires the action of the community.

The diversity of the 11 sites is of great interest because it brings up different challenges for each of the sites. If you compare areas such as Kakadu and the Tasmanian wilderness to areas such as the more recently listed Australian fossil mammal sites at Riversleigh and Naracoorte and to Lord Howe Island, you will understand that what we are talking about in this report is something that is very complex.

In formulating our recommendations, we have made some important observations about the requirements of management plans. Much of the controversy that we have seen in some of the areas would have been solved if, in fact, as we have recommended, management plans had been in place well before properties were nominated. The observation has been made that there must be not only a great deal of consultation with the communities concerned in the formulation of the management plans but that consultation must continue after the listing. If you look at the success of some of the arrangements to do with some of the properties, you will see that that success has been as a result of the continuing consultation with the various stakeholders that are involved. That is one of the most important aspects that we would like to put across about the report.

Other important recommendations go to funding. My colleagues have made mention of the recommendation indicating we believe that $20.6 million should be provided immediately and a continuing $16 million a year after that. That funding goes towards the requirement of important infrastructure—infrastructure required for visitors' amenities and infrastructure required for proper information through such things as signage and information centres—measures which will all protect the world heritage values themselves.

The other aspect I should touch upon is that the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee of this House has had a tradition of producing documents on the basis of consensus. This is such a document. There were many areas in which listeners to this debate would have got the impression that there was a tinge of controversy. But, in the end, we have produced in a bipartisan way a report to which not only this government but also a new government—when there is a change of government, hopefully sooner rather than later—would be committed to on both sides of the chamber. That is a very important aspect of the way in which the environment committee has always operated.

One of those areas of controversy was whether the two properties in the Northern Territory should be handed across to the Northern Territory government. I think there will probably be continuing debate about that, but the view of the committee is in the report. There was also controversy about the contribution of private enterprise to management, and our position is clearly stated in the report. We believe that, at the end of the day, whilst we would encourage private involvement, the decisions are properly in the hands of government and have to be done in a cooperative way.

I thank not only the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), as the present chair, but also the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who was the chair for the bulk of the inquiry in the previous parliament, for the way in which they have led consideration of this report; and the secretariat, who have once again done a fine job, as we now always expect.

The important aspect of this report is not that it will lie on a bookshelf somewhere; it is that the government will see its way clear to respond within three months, and I hope those responses will be very positive. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have had the opportunity to be involved in the formation of this report, Managing Australia's World Heritage . I am delighted to be on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts and to be able to work with so many members who share my concern for the environment and have her protection and enhancement as one of their driving passions.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is one of the most wide‐ranging and significant reports for the long-term care of our precious world heritage areas. Of the 469 properties on the world heritage list, there are 350 cultural sites, 102 natural sites and 17 mixed cultural and natural sites in 104 states or countries.

Australia's 11 sites—all natural—are easily amongst the most pristine and beautiful of the world. They have met the detailed criteria of UNESCO and it is easy to see that these areas meet the pinnacle criteria: namely, to be of outstanding universal value. Of course, there are in Australia other areas which are deserving of world heritage status which will no doubt be nominated in the future. We have, however, focused our attention over the last two to three years on our existing sites.

Having scuba dived on the Great Barrier Reef and seen the other world which lives and thrives beneath the sea—the vibrant colours of the many strange and beautiful fish and plant life which we living on the surface tend to ignore—having experienced the changing colours and terrain and the raw natural beauty of Kakadu, having walked in the wet tropics of Queensland and having spent time in the central eastern rainforests, I count myself as having been most fortunate to have witnessed the outstanding natural value of our most beautiful, biologically significant and fragile natural jewels.

This report's 54 recommendations offer a framework for the better management of these valuable sites. These recommendations centre on issues such as funding obligations between the Commonwealth and the states, some of the current problems in the management of existing areas, nomination and listing practices and the need for thorough and early consultation with relevant stakeholders as nomination is considered. This report has also unearthed some very significant ongoing obligations.

I know that other committee members share the view that all governments really have significant financial responsibilities as well as the moral and conservation obligations of maintaining our world heritage areas. But, in current circumstances, the committee has identified an immediate shortfall of $20.6 million next year and $16 million recurrent after that. We are also offering a solution through the increased use of private sector support and the increased use of user charges, where appropriate, for that funding shortfall.

In successfully nominating areas for world heritage status, it is crucial that the Commonwealth and state governments work together, that the Commonwealth meet its financial obligations, that governments ensure that areas are managed and maintained in accordance with the needs of those areas and that management plans are both considered and thoughtful. Unfortunately, not all of these obligations have been met in the past. Amongst some of the findings, we have found that there are incomplete management plans for existing sites, at times there is poor monitoring of environmental risks, at times there are poor management structures and there is an underutilisation which seems to be consistent across the public sector of private sector support.

It is all very well nominating areas for heritage listing, but it has not been good enough to then fail to provide sufficient resources and to implement clearer operational guidelines to ensure their management and protection. The report's recommendations, as stated in the summary, are `to build on the strengths and contribute to the establishment of better ways of managing world heritage'. As Australians, we must not take lightly our duties to shelter our natural environment. As custodians for the present and architects for the future, our environment is one of our most critical responsibilities.

We must shield our natural environment from the ravishes of modern living and the encroachments it seems forced to endure. We must strike a favourable balance between the trade, tourism and commercial demands on our land and the protection of pristine environmental assets for the generations beyond. Finally, I would like to thank the members of the previous committee and the committee secretariat for all their efforts in putting together this report. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for statements on this report has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 102B, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting, and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Albanese.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —How appropriate it is that I am introducing the Sydney Airport (Regulation of Movements) Bill 1996 on 4 November, for it is two years to the day since the third runway was opened at Sydney. That opening led to a disaster for residents all around the airport, and I was elected to do something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am bringing this bill forward on behalf of my constituents, and the tens of thousands of other Sydney residents, who are tired of the uncertainty that clouds KSA. This bill would place a legislative limit on the number of aircraft movements during any one‐hour period at Kingsford Smith airport. This bill fulfils a promise I made during the election campaign—that is, to introduce it regardless of who formed a government.

This bill sends a clear message to the people of Sydney: this parliament believes there is a limit to the capacity of Kingsford Smith airport. It also sends a clear message to those who oppose a second Sydney airport that this is not an option but a necessity. This clearly rebuffs those groups whose real agenda is to entrench Kingsford Smith airport as our only airport—an airport whose operations would destroy the lives of thousands of Sydney residents.

Kingsford Smith airport is growing at a rate of over nine per cent per annum. For residents under the flight path this is alarming. At the moment, there are over 280,000 aircraft movements through KSA. Already the noise levels are intolerable for many. The decision to allow take‐offs to the north from runway 34R without an EIS has significantly increased the capacity of the airport.

There are serious proposals to increase the number of flights to over 350,000 per annum as well as a proposal for a fourth runway. In addition, a bizarre coalition of the Greens, the No Aircraft Noise Party, the aviation industry and members of the Howard government, including the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale), have formed the No Second Airport in Sydney Alliance.
The need for legislation is highlighted by the hostile response of the Tourism Council of Australia to my bill. Bruce Baird said:
Restricting the ability to lift the cap on movements at Sydney airport at peak times will be bad news for the tourism industry.

He went on to say that the capacity would not be enough for the Olympics. Well, let the Olympic planners be put on notice. This bill would send a clear message to those who would excessively increase the capacity at KSA to the detriment of thousands of Sydney residents.

In addition to the increased aircraft noise, there is increased traffic from the airport through streets that were not designed to take it. There is also air pollution. Following sightings by a number of Marrickville residents, Airservices Australia have confirmed that, at 12.59 p.m. on 15 October this year, a US registered Evergreen Airlines aircraft dumped fuel over Marrickville. This occurs when tanks are overfilled or aircraft suddenly change altitude—and residents suffer. Mr Deputy Speaker, my point is quite simple: more aircraft movements equal more noise and more air pollution and a greater chance of a minor or major disaster over the most densely populated area of Australia.

However, it has to be said that there are many in the community who would have expected this measure to have been brought into legislation by now. The government took only 10 days to direct Airservices Australia to re‐open the east‐west runway. It seems bizarre that we are here eight months later waiting for them to legislate on one of their other key election promises—a cap on aircraft movements.
Their election commitment was clear. Page 8 of Putting people first—the coalition's policy on Sydney airport, of 29 January 1996, says:
The coalition will cap aircraft movements at 80 movements per hour by implementing a slot system.

It was with some disappointment that I read the response of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) to this bill. I had hoped for a more positive response. Since then, I have had a productive discussion with the minister, and it has been agreed that I and the seconder of this bill, the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), will meet with the minister within a week to discuss the government's response. It should be positive, just as the response of the shadow minister and the Labor caucus has been.
I conclude by responding to those who say that it is not necessary to have this legislation. I want to quote someone who said last year during a similar debate on his private member's bill:
It would make it the law of Australia, a law that could not be altered, except by another act of the parliament.
That was the then opposition leader, now Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard).

Mr Deputy Speaker, the people of Sydney need the strength of legislation, not the whims of ministerial discretion, to provide certainty and some direction over the future of airport operations at KSA. I am pleased that my bill will be seconded by the member for Watson, who has an outstanding record, first as the member for Grayndler and then for Watson, in standing up for residents against the vagaries of noise. I strongly urge all members to support this bill. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill. (Time expired)
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Pledge of Commitment as a Citizen of the Commonwealth of Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ms HANSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House calls on the government to strengthen the pledge of commitment as a citizen of the Commonwealth of Australia into a pledge of loyalty to acknowledge the primacy of the interests of Australia and its people above all others.

I rise in this House today to call on the government to strengthen the pledge of commitment as a citizen of the Commonwealth of Australia into a pledge of loyalty to acknowledge the primacy of the interest of Australia and its people above all others. I am convinced that the present pledge of commitment given by all new citizens of Australia is now due for an overhaul. I think that Australia's existing citizens expect a firm promise by those who come here to join them as citizens of this great nation to be willing to give a clear and unambiguous commitment of loyalty where there can be no room for higher loyalties to other nations or people.

Some people may ask, and there will no doubt be speakers today who will question, whether we need to change the pledge of commitment. Many people in this country do not even know what it says or who says it. It is a statement of commitment to be made at citizenship ceremonies and reads:
From this time forward, under God,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.
A person may choose whether or not to use the words `under God'.

This is a pretty piece of prose, but we should not forget its importance or what it symbolises. This is how people who are to become Australian citizens promise to uphold our laws and traditions. I think that we all should expect an unequivocal promise of loyalty and allegiance. The pledge as it now stands is not such a promise.

Let me tell you now that anything written as loosely as this pledge, more for its aesthetic appeal than anything else, can and will be interpreted differently by different people. Some individuals will take it to mean whatever they want. The pledge as it stands is a symbolic statement of motherhood principles and seems designed more to make us feel good than to make a real commitment. This is not a bad thing, but I believe that it is only a starting point.

At any ceremony for granting of citizenship, you can see a number of migrants from a widely diverse background. They have decided to make Australia their home, and we have accepted them here. They will bring with them many fine things that will make Australia a better place, and I think that most will look back on this ceremony as one of the defining moments in their lives. To be asked to acknowledge the primacy of the interests of their new nation over all others should be no difficult task. I believe that most would expect it to be so. A strong pledge of loyalty and allegiance is also an important symbol to those who are already Australian citizens. At no stage should, or do I expect could, anyone fail to see the importance of the fact of changing one's nationality.

I have been accused of wanting to prevent certain people from coming to this country as migrants. This accusation oversimplifies the situation and has allowed some to throw a neat label of `racist' at me. The simple fact is that the people of this nation have the right to choose who we want to join us—in fact, we have and will continue to do so as matters of government policy. Part of this choice involves making new citizens aware of what they are becoming.

It does, however, emphasise that what we have in our pledge must be clear and not open to interpretation in ways we do not intend. I believe that our pledge of commitment needs to become one of loyalty to Australia and its people above all others.

There are at least two good reasons for this. Firstly, anyone coming into the country, being accepted as an Australian citizen, must take upon themselves a clear and unequivocal promise. There can be no misunderstanding, no room for error. They must accept their obligations without reservation or qualification. There can be no `core' or `non-core' promises here. Secondly, the people of Australia must see that new citizens are prepared to make that ultimate pledge. Exchanging allegiance from one's country of origin, with its history, values, laws and customs, to another is an important step. These people have chosen to do so and share our future. I have been accused of lacking detail or substance in what I have said on other occasions, so I will spell out my proposal here. I believe that the current pledge of commitment should be strengthened into a pledge of loyalty which says:
From this time forward, under God, I pledge my loyalty—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP
SPEECH.PARA: Pride in one's country and a true sense of nationhood can be enhanced by a better understanding of citizenship.

Citizenship is the ultimate expression of a person's commitment to a nation. It involves a two-way reciprocal commitment between the citizen and the nation. It is a unifying symbol, especially in a multicultural nation like Australia. It is a genuine bond to a way of life.

These are not my words, they are the printed words of the coalition policy document. The document refers to the privilege of citizenship and the corresponding responsibilities. It also notes that a citizenship ceremony should be a memorable event and should be dignified and meaningful.

True to its election promise, the government allocated $700,000 over three years to the Australian Council on Citizenship to undertake a comprehensive review of citizenship in Australia. The government is committed to enhancing the national significance of Australian citizenship. The review will also look at issues such as residency, fluency in English, the pledge of commitment and dual citizenship.

The oath has been amended on a number of occasions since the act first came into effect in 1949 and has been the subject of examination by various committees and conventions, et cetera. Renunciation in various forms has been in and out. It has been accepted that many migrants found difficulty in renouncing `nationality', as to them it was synonymous with family and race, and renunciation therefore implied permanent dissociation from relatives, personal friends and cultures. Commitment to Australia is important. One's birthplace and the spoken word cannot be the only measuring sticks for such commitment.

A very good Australian, and a constituent of mine, who was born in Greece, told me recently that on a return visit to Greece he had recited loudly Clancy of the Overflow at the Acropolis just so that everyone there would know he was an Aussie. What is significant is that there are some matters to do with citizenship that Australia has no power over. Loss or retention of former citizenship depends entirely on the laws of the person's former homeland. A Greek citizen remains a Greek citizen under Greek law and an American ceases to be an American citizen under American law when they become an Australian citizen, irrespective of what they say at our citizenship ceremonies. Countries like Canada, Cyprus, Egypt, France, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Israel, Italy, New Zealand, Portugal, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK, to name but a few, allow dual citizenship. Others such as China, Malaysia and Vietnam do not. This must be of some relief to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). But she should know that the Joint Standing Committee on Migration stated:

The Committee rejects the arguments that one cannot owe allegiance or commitment to more than one country. It is estimated that three million Australians currently possess dual citizenship. There is no evidence to suggest that these persons are disloyal or lack commitment to Australia simply because they chose not to relinquish their former ties and heritage.

Tolerance of diversity is a cornerstone of multicultural Australian society. The ultimate expression of such tolerance would be the recognition that while Australian citizens owe their primary allegiance to Australia, they can also show a commitment to their country of origin or the country of which they are resident.

The member for Oxley in recent months has shown herself entirely ignorant of the many issues of which she has spoken. She has spoken fiction, not fact; she has preached division, not cohesion, and bigotry, not tolerance. I would recommend to the member for Oxley that she get to know the seven per cent of her electorate who were born in a non-English speaking country.

BREAK.PARA: I am proud to say that I represent every person in my electorate of Adelaide, including the 16.4 per cent from a non-English speaking background who add to our cultural diversity. I am privileged to live multiculturalism through the Australian Greeks, Italians, Cypriots and Vietnamese who have shown themselves to be such hardworking Australians. I have learnt that loyal Australians can still feel keenly for their country of birth—especially if that country was Cyprus, as it is still divided.
The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was absolutely right when he said in the chamber last week:

. . . people should always be judged on their individual worth and merit, on their character and behaviour, and on what they do for their fellow man and not on the basis of their ethnic origin, the colour of their skin, their religious beliefs or their lack of religious beliefs, or where they may happen to have been born.
The member for Oxley would do well to remember this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member who has just spoken, the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), has quite clearly completely misunderstood the intent of this motion. This motion is to strengthen Australia's pledge of allegiance. I believe it is time that such a move is undertaken and this is made more important. I understand the government is to review the concept of citizenship. The irony of all this is that the majority of coalition members would support this motion if they were being consistent with their own policy document and discussions that have been held ad nauseam within the coalition's own backbench committees about the value of Australian citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: To be an Australian citizen is something to be valued. As a citizen who was not born here I can attest to that. It is no mistake that many hundreds of thousands of people want to come here every year. Those that are able to become Australian citizens guard their associated rights and privileges closely. The current pledge is one of commitment. The mover of the motion, the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), started to read it out. If we ask ourselves what the origins of such pledges or oaths are, we find that allegiance comes from the old French `liege' meaning pure and absolute, with `liege homage' meaning unconditional.

This was developed in our culture from the English feudal system where unconditional allegiance was sworn to a sovereign. The four kinds of allegiance generally accepted are: natural allegiance, due from all people born in a domain; acquired allegiance, obtained by naturalisation; local allegiance, from aliens, so long as they remain in a domain; and legal allegiance, created by the oath of allegiance. I contend that these do not represent old and outdated concepts but, as a matter of security for the traditions, laws and institutions of a nation, the concept of allegiance remains just as valid in our society today.

Our society is in the midst of change and, generally, change for the good. We have a tolerant, liberal society that has grown in strength, value and diversity due to the contributions made not only by its own citizens but also by those new citizens who have come from all around the world to become Australians.

Anyone who comes to Australia with an expectation of becoming a citizen should be prepared to accept this country and its people, to the exclusion of all others if necessary. I believe that the Australian people would expect nothing less. As their representatives, we have an obligation to support their view. A step in this direction was taken in 1993 with the introduction of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, which introduced the previous oath with the current pledge and removed reference to a monarch. We know that at the time there was a great deal of debate over whether this was a precursor towards a republic. However, there is a view that this has generally been seen as a modern Australian approach.

The principal act—the Australian Citizenship Act 1948—requires anyone wanting to become a citizen to make an oath or affirmation of allegiance. This is a long‐accepted and, I think, important condition that we have placed on all people wanting to become citizens. If we are to continue to go to these lengths to pledge commitment to what Australia stands for and is, I think we are also bound by duty to ensure that the pledge actually means something real. The debate on citizenship cannot be undertaken separately from the debate on immigration and multiculturalism. In the previous government's own prescription of the bounds of multiculturalism, it noted:
. . . multicultural policies are based on the premise that all Australians should have an overriding and unifying commitment to Australia, to its interests and future, first and foremost,—
this is from the coalition's document; the member for Adelaide would do well to reread it—

multicultural policies require all Australians to accept the basic structures and principles of Australian society—the Constitution and the rule of law, tolerance and equality, parliamentary democracy, freedom of speech and religion, English as the national language and equality of the sexes; and multicultural policies impose obligations as well as conferring rights: the right to express one's own culture and beliefs involves a reciprocal responsibility to accept the right of others to express their views and values.
In conclusion, it is my view that the new pledge of loyalty should read as follows:
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people above all others,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect and promise to uphold, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey before any others.
It is simple and straightforward and, in my view, the vast overwhelming majority of Australians would accept it, as would most of the coalition members, amongst whom are a number opposing it today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I must thank the member for Moore (Mr Filing) for reconfirming the coalition's policy on multiculturalism and also our commitment through the Australian Council on Citizenship. I was wondering which side he was actually debating for on this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not particularly easy for those of us who have actually pledged our loyalty to Australia or witnessed our parents pledge their loyalty on our behalf to face those who say we lack commitment to this country. Let there be no mistaking what the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) is suggesting: ethnic Australians are agents of foreign countries out to destabilise Australia.

On 29 January 1965, in the Fremantle Town Hall, at the age of 9½, with my sister I stood by my father's side as he recited in his far from perfect English his commitment to this country. No-one forced my father to become an Australian citizen; he chose to become one. Unlike the member for Oxley, I stood by my father and we pledged allegiance to this country. I have before me evidence of my pledge to this country.

Like other members of this House, such as the member for Kooyong (Mr Georgiou), the member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash) and the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), we came here as children. I for one am extremely proud of my immigrant heritage. Since then the oath has changed on more than one occasion. It has undergone reviews and amendments. Despite these changes, members may be interested to know that entire sections of our immigrant community have not turned into racial, radical, anti-Australian revolutionaries simply because they used one formula of the oath rather than another. They have maintained their rock solid commitment to this country and the values we hold dear, while simultaneously maintaining a precious bond with a culture, a language and a religion of their past. This has been possible in Australia and we should all be proud of it.

I am convinced that the motion put forward by the member for Oxley today is, above all, unnecessary. It pre‐empts the work of the Australian Council on Citizenship, as announced by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) on 20 August. Our minister announced the process of reviewing comprehensively the issues of citizenship in Australia with a view to advising how best to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Australian citizenship on 26 January 1999. The council would deal with issues such as the meaning and value of citizenship; residency, language, age and other requirements; reviewing the current pledge; dual and multi‐ citizenship issues; and several other issues. The aim of the review will be to make citizenship more meaningful for all Australians, something which I fully support. The council deserves a chance to make inquiries and reach its conclusions without being pressured or pre‐empted by politicians on demagogic campaigns.

With the centenary of Federation approaching fast, it is important that we openly examine the symbols and values which we as Australians see as important. There is always room for change and progress in this area, but it is just as important that these changes be undertaken in a mature and responsible way. The Australian Council on Citizenship will ensure that the concerns of all Australians, not some, are heard. This motion is just another example of opportunistic policy on the run.

There is no political imperative to strengthen the oath of allegiance. To think otherwise is to imply that people simply swan into Australia, become citizens without even thinking about what they are doing and are somehow less committed than their Australian born counterparts. I point out that there are many countries in the Asian region—those countries which the member for Oxley believes are swamping us—which force its citizens to renounce their original citizenship once they become Australians. The member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) pointed out some of these countries, and I wish to repeat some of those. China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Singapore, Brunei, Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia and Nepal are some of the countries in this category. This would imply that people would not simply come to Australia and decide to become citizens lightly. They would do it because they believe it is the best thing for themselves, their family and their future, fully aware that there is no going back.

I also reaffirm my belief that it is not the oath itself that makes us good Australians or this piece of paper which I am holding now, even though I am extremely proud of it, as most immigrants to this country would be. What makes us Australian is our basic commitment to values of equality and justice, our commitment to tolerances of all types—tolerance of diversity, tolerance of those who have endured hardship and tolerance of those who seek a helping hand by a compassionate society. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot do more than express my general agreement with the remarks of the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) and the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi). I think it is unfortunate that the member for Moore (Mr Filing) has associated himself with what I think was called in the newspaper this morning, and an accurate reflect of its motivation, `dog whistling'. That is saying something which has an ostensibly overt purpose but is intended to send subliminal tones to others that convey an entirely different message. That message is, as the member for Deakin has said, that some of our fellow citizens have not given a commitment to this country in a manner which we would expect when they become citizens of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I say that the Labor Party has no diffidence about defending the terms of the pledge of commitment as a citizen. In the term of our government we made an expressly Australian act of affirmation to become a citizen. We removed reference to a pledge of loyalty to Her Majesty. We made it clear that when somebody does become a citizen of this country they are pledging their commitment to this nation. I can do no better than refer to the words that former Senator Tate used when he was referring to its genesis through the words of Les Murray, with whom he consulted in developing this. He referred to it this way:

Then it says, `I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people'. This is the affirmative, positive act indicating a solemn commitment, an allegiance to Australia and its people. `Australia' is used there in a very simple expression but it has various levels of meaning. Obviously, there is the political entity, the Commonwealth of Australia. Loyalty is being expressed to that political entity, the name by which we are known amongst all the nations. But there is also a geographical and physical sense, which should not be totally discounted—the place. There is a commitment to Australia as the place where we are fortunate to be, the sunburnt country, the land abounding in nature's gifts of beauty rich and rare.
He concluded by saying:

BREAK.PARA: So the loyal commitment is meant to evoke obligations to Australian society, the political entity and the land itself, the place where we are.

And it does that. No pledge can detail every particular of a citizen's ongoing obligations. But this demands of a person a commitment of loyalty to Australia and its people and a respect for Australia's democratic traditions. It says that those democratic traditions are to be shared, rights and liberties respected and laws obeyed and upheld.

What could be more clear‐cut? What could be more expressive of the obligations we expect of somebody joining the Australian community? What could be less properly characterised—as it has been this morning—as something which is merely a pretty piece of prose? This is something that is strongly Australian, but it is not jingoistic and it is not resentful of the fact that, when some amongst us come to Australia and take citizenship, they do not leave behind other of the sentiments that we would expect them to hold.

It is true that to become a member of this place one must renounce all other citizenships. Perhaps that is appropriate for a member of the parliament but, notwithstanding that, there are members of this House, including the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), for example, who felt great unease in being placed in a position where he had to formally renounce his United Kingdom citizenship. There are many who have previously held dual citizenship and who feel that when they come to this place the constitutional obligation is one which places them in a situation which they ought not to be placed in.

That is a matter which this House and the parliament will have to deal with in due course. But respecting the rights and entitlements of all of us who have made a commitment to this nation is a foundation stone for where we would wish to be. I do not believe that this House is in any way ready to accept the unspoken message of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson)—who was, I believe, unfortunately joined this morning by the member for Moore—that we do, in some sense, not demand of people coming to this nation a loyalty and commitment to Australia, a primacy of that loyalty and commitment, and that we are in any way short of asking of them the mutual respect that citizenship requires of us a nation and as citizens pledging themselves to it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with interest to the remarks of the members for Oxley (Ms Hanson), Moore (Mr Filing), Deakin (Mr Barresi), Adelaide (Ms Worth) and Denison (Mr Kerr) and I have to say that I think this is one of those debates in which there is scope for differences of nuance and certainly of experience. I have to confess that I have not gone looking in the words of the motion for some sinister or dark objectives or motives or meanings. But perhaps it is my naivety and the simple lawyer's training which simply says you take the words at face value and go from there.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard this issue as important. The question of citizenship is an appropriate and important subject for our consideration in this place. I do not find anything in the motion especially offensive or objectionable. I note that our government has moved to highlight and underscore the importance of citizenship and has established the Australian Council on Citizenship to look at the issue in its widest possible context. So my only hesitation about the motion is that it ought to be considered as part of the wider question of how we elevate the sense of appreciation and value that we place on citizenship, not just for new migrants but for the nation as whole.

On that subject, I take from the motion concerns about citizenship, about nationality, about allegiance and about identity. I regard all those issues as being appropriate and important subjects of debate in this place. In that regard I know that there is a view that the whole concept of nationality is becoming passe, that it is no longer of great relevance. The great exponent of that view in our region would be Kenichi Ohmae, the famous business strategist. He argues that, in view of the emergence of the global economy, the global village and the borderless world, the whole concept of national identity is no longer of any great relevance; that the combined influences of capital, corporations, consumers and communications suggest that we ought to dispense with the notion of nationality altogether.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The member will have leave to continue his remarks when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of government would short‐change pensioners in residential aged care? The Howard government would. What sort of government would be lousy enough to take $350 per annum from some of Australia's most needy and deserving citizens? The Howard government. When rental assistance was paid directly to age pensioners in residential care, they were able to retain 15 per cent of the assistance for cost‐of‐living expenses. Now the Howard government has ripped away this amount—approximately $7 each week—and bundled it into recurrent subsidies to cover the cost of administration in nursing homes and hostels.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an appalling double standard and injustice. Why should other Australians, including age pensioners renting accommodation, receive rental assistance directly, while people in aged residential care are discriminated against? Four hundred residents in the Frank Whiddon Masonic Homes in my electorate are adversely affected by this change. I say to the government on their behalf, `Give them back their $7 a week for cost‐of‐living expenses, a very important amount for aged pensioners.'

Equally, around Australia in 3,000 nursing homes, tens of thousands of age pensioners are being hurt by this mean-spirited, tight fisted, callous policy. I call upon the Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan, and the government to reduce the injustice and abandon this policy change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Through the initiative of the South‐West Chamber of Commerce and its president, Peter Janssen, a local jobs summit is being organised to tackle the problem of youth unemployment in my electorate. The summit will involve local businesses, schools, training providers, community organisations and the trade union movement. They are all getting together to pool their resources in an ongoing process of collaboration in order to identify and create employment opportunities for young people. This is exactly the sort of grassroots initiative and cooperation we need to encourage employment growth in a real way and to give especially our young people the practical help they need to find real jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: The No. 1 priority of the Howard government has been to put the right building blocks and linkages into place to facilitate this process. We have introduced schemes like the new modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system, the jobs placement, employment and training program and the green corps program—all specifically for young people. We have increased funding to schools to improve the literacy and numeracy skills of young Australians. We are fixing up Labor's disastrous IR laws and cutting red tape costs for small business.

The South‐West Chamber of Commerce jobs summit is very much a local effort and a team effort because the people in my electorate, after 13 long years of experience of Labor's failed employment policies, know this government has better policies and is on the right track. The Howard government policies will enable people on the ground to network with government and each other to produce the outcomes they want and we all need in our local areas. I commend Peter Janssen and the chamber. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw attention to the unfair burden being placed by the federal and ACT governments on people who work for the disabled. I refer to the ACT government's shameful decision to single out disability program staff for the removal of penalty rates. The Commonwealth government is also doing its best to make life harder for people who take on the vital challenge of working with the disabled. The budget imposes an across‐the‐board efficiency cut on Department of Health and Family Services programs. The application of the efficiency cut will be inequitable. It will particularly hit the organisations funded through the department which help people with intellectual disabilities into open employment. It is bad enough that sheltered workshops are going to suffer an efficiency cut in the order of six per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: If this government has any decency, it will immediately review the effect of its budget cuts on people who work with the disabled. Not to act is unfair to the staff who are affected, to the disabled people themselves and, importantly, to their families. I call on the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) to act now to ensure that these constructive projects, which help some of the most vulnerable members of our society to work, are properly valued and protected.

In the last government huge tripartite steps were made, with government, unions and employers working together to put into open employment people with disabilities who long term had been denied support for open employment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to highlight the plight of Wang Dan, a 26‐year‐old freelance writer. Wang Dan was on the list of most wanted student leaders after the crackdown in June 1989. He was released on parole in February 1993 after a four‐year sentence. At that time he was a history major at Beijing University. He was formally expelled for his continuing political activities and after his release he continued to speak out for democracy and human rights, initiating petitions and writing to and speaking with journalists.

SPEECH.PARA: Since his release on parole he has been in and out of detention and has been sent on forced vacations. On 21 May 1995 he disappeared after he signed a petition demanding the reassessment of the 1989 protest calling for tolerance towards dissent and release of political prisoners. His home was searched, eight bags of his belongings were removed and he was taken away by uniformed officers saying they wanted to question him. And so it goes on.

Little was known of him during that 17‐month period. He finally turned up in October 1996 when he was indicted for conspiring to subvert the government. Seven or eight days after a trial that lasted half a day, he was sentenced to 11 years imprisonment. This is the behaviour of the Chinese government in relation to people who are trying to speak the truth and stand up to the shocking repression of human rights in that country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to report to this parliament on the first British Australian festival held at the Blacktown showground last Sunday, 3 November 1996. Britfest celebrates the links between British and Australian culture. Traditional pipe bands, Highland and Irish country dancing and kilt making were part of the first Britfest. Arrangements are already under way for the 1997 festival when it is planned to present a two‐day festival incorporating a full military tattoo.

SPEECH.PARA: It will provide additional income for charities and other needy bodies via donations from the proceeds of this function, as well as promoting a forum for commercial activities by Australian and British businessmen by incorporating a trade fair into Britfest. Further development of the Britfest concept will have great potential for business and employment growth in western Sydney as well as building on a successful Carnivale organised in August, so adding to the reputation of Blacktown as the multicultural capital of western Sydney.

The 1996 Blacktown Britfest was officially opened by the newly elected mayor of Blacktown, Charles Lowles. I congratulate Mayor Lowles on his election as the mayor of the fastest growing local government area in New South Wales. I congratulate the coordinator of Britfest, Tony Smith, and his hardworking committee on a great event. We wish them well for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP
