TALK.START.PARA: —For many years now the Shoalhaven has been sold short. All we seem to receive are promises in regard to the electrification of the railway lines through to Nowra. If it is really the intention of the state government that all share in the benefits of the Olympics, then the best way for the Shoalhaven to benefit in the short and long term is for this long‐time commitment of rail electrification to be honoured. The benefits to the area both socially and economically could not be measured. With the expansion of HMAS Albatross over the next decade, the investment would have a secondary beneficial effect on the naval base.

SPEECH.PARA: Having a modern rail service in the Shoalhaven can only prove to be an environmentally wise initiative by offsetting the road use on which this area depends. The transportation of goods and raw materials by road is often the only option for many Shoalhaven businesses and manufacturers. The opportunity to transport goods and raw materials by rail would be a very attractive alternative to negotiating some well‐known road black spots.

As the second fastest growing area in New South Wales, an improved rail link would rapidly accelerate the tourism potential of what is already one of the major tourist destinations in Australia. Tourist attractions such as Jervis Bay, the Shoalhaven River, Kangaroo Valley and towns like Kiama, Gerringong, Nowra and, even further south, Ulladulla would have a much brighter economic and social future if an improved rail link to Nowra was realised.

For the residents of Shoalhaven, the electrification of the rail link to Nowra would mean that they would no longer be treated as second-class citizens. Direct access to the Olympics would be made simple and it would certainly be made easier for the elderly, the infirm and others to access specialist services. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I salute one of Geelong's great sporting heroes—72-year-old veteran cycling legend Jack Griffin. Jack has just completed a 14,000 kilometre, 97-day bike ride around Australia with 76-year-old Eric Doughty from Wollongong. What makes Jack so special is that this is his third time around Australia as a veteran cyclist.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last parliament, Jack came to me seeking support from the previous Labor government for his latest ride. Jack felt that he could demonstrate to other war veterans and older people that life really does begin at 70. I was pleased that the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Con Sciacca, saw fit to allocate $15,000 in sponsorship through his department for the event. Jack has asked me to publicly thank Con Sciacca for that support.

The Geelong Advertiser reporter Tracey Ellis wrote that Jack is a quick riding, fast talking promotion for good health and fitness. She is not wrong in that description. He is an enthusiastic older Australian with a keen sense of humour and a vision to encourage older Australians to live life to its fullest. He has succeeded in doing that.
To Jack, his riding buddy, Eric Doughty, his support crew, his Geelong sponsors and the Department of Veterans' Affairs, our congratulations on a magnificent effort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday I spent 1½ hours in a Kenworth K100G travelling a route that should take less than a third of that time by car. This was no fault of my driver, more of the road system, its inadequacies and the road transport industry's quest for safety. Of course it could also have had something to do with the fact that I was sitting in a B-double, which, as some of you may know, is the largest vehicle currently allowed to travel around our cities.

SPEECH.PARA: This journey gave me a greater understanding of the frustration endured by truck drivers on a day-to-day basis. The reason for my making this trip was to help launch the National Road Safety Awareness Week.

BREAK.PARA: All members in this House would be well aware of the vital part trucks play in keeping this country moving. Unfortunately, when you have such large vehicles ploughing down the highways at breakneck pace, it is inevitable that there will be accidents—and not all of them occur on the highways. My electorate of Bowman includes the Port of Brisbane, an area that would see possibly more heavy vehicles than any other in Brisbane. So, naturally, I have a keen interest in road safety.

Having the opportunity to travel in one of these beasts has given me a rare insight into the difficulties these drivers face. It has also shown me how talented and skilled they are. These drivers have a greater respect for safety than anyone I know—they have to, it is their livelihood. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I note with interest today in the West Australian newspaper, a report about the comments made by Professor Paddy O'Brien in relation to the Court government's slowness in implementing the reforms recommended by the Commission on Government. Western Australians would know that this was set up in response to the Royal Commission into WA Inc. after years of corrupt Labor governments. Of the 263 recommendations, very few so far have been implemented by the Court government.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that there is a very strong tyranny of executive government, both within the state and in the federal context. It is absolutely critical in the Western Australian context that strong willed, strong thinking Independent members are elected in the state election, in particular Peter Kyle in the seat of Carine and Penny Hearne in the seat of Alfred Cove, to join Elizabeth Constable and Phil Pendal. The member for Swan (Mr Randall), former Senator Crichton-Browne's candidate, well knows that, unless you have Independents in there, you will not get the reforms that will bring open and accountable government to Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At a ceremony to be held in the Cessnock Town Hall on Tuesday, 26 November, Andrew James Frame—or Mick Frame, as he is known—will have bestowed upon him the honour of the freedom of the City of Cessnock. There could be no more worthier a recipient for such an honour than Mick Frame. Mick will be only the fourth person to receive the award and will join his brother Coogan and Cessnock residents Mr Cec Anstey and Mr Fred Yeatman. He is certainly in good company.

SPEECH.PARA: Mick Frame was born in Weston in 1911 and has lived and worked on the northern coalfields all of his life. This is not the first award to be bestowed upon Mick. In 1979 he was awarded an OAM for distinguished services to the community. He is a recipient of a Premier's award for his services to the aged. He is a life member of the Australian Labor Party and in 1987 was named Kurri Kurri Apex Club's citizen of the year.

Mick Frame served on Cessnock's City Council continuously for 18 years and was Deputy Mayor of the city for seven of them. He has 42 years of continuous service with the St John Ambulance Service and 43 years continuous involvement with the Northern New South Wales First Aid Competition, organised by the New South Wales Coal Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2.00 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) will be absent from question time this week. He is visiting India on government business. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) will answer questions on his behalf.

—Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to advise the House that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, is also visiting India and Indonesia this week. In his absence, I am Acting Leader of the Opposition.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. I remind the minister of the government's commitment, recently restated by the Prime Minister, to reduce small business paperwork by 50 per cent over the term of this parliament. Following the findings of the Charlie Bell small business report, will he now give an unequivocal undertaking that the average time devoted to government paperwork by small business will be down to two hours per week by 1998‐99?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to respond to that question. The report showed 13 years of lost opportunity built up by the Labor Party in government. As I recall, Senator Cook is on record as saying that, in hindsight, they could have done more for small business; that, when they were looking at the big picture, they had overlooked the importance of small business.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure the parliament that this government does not intend to ignore small business. We recognise the importance of small business to the economy and to job growth. We recognise that they have been burdened by 13 years of red tape and compliance built up under your party in government. We will not abandon them like you did.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of the severe financial strain still being felt by many farmers as a consequence of the drought? Will the government take steps to alleviate this strain on regional Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as implied in the honourable gentleman's question, that, although many areas of Australia have experienced bumper seasons as a result of very heavy rainfalls and in some areas of Australia some of the best seasons in living memory, it is also paradoxically the case that other parts of Australia are still in the grip of a severe drought or are still experiencing the after effects of having been released from the drought but still not, so far as the farmers are concerned, receiving any income of any substance.

ANSWER.PARA: I had the opportunity a couple of months ago, accompanied by the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries and also by Mr Don McGauchie, the President of the National Farmers Federation, to visit one such area in outback Queensland near Winton. Nobody could have visited that area without being quite moved by the extent of family hardship, the aridity of the terrain and the very severe strain that five years of drought had placed upon the people of that district.

The problem is that, although many of these farms have now been out of drought declared areas since June of this year, the primary producers are not receiving any income. Their cash flow is absolutely negligible and under present arrangements it is quite unrealistic to contemplate that those people will lose the assistance they are now receiving come the early part of December. That is now only a little more than a month away. To take the assistance from those people, given what they experienced and what they continue to experience and the hardship they suffer, would be absolutely unreasonable.

A couple of weeks ago I received a delegation led by the Queensland Premier, Mr Borbidge, which included representatives of industry. They put a case to me, which I found very compelling, for some change in the existing arrangements following the lifting of a drought declaration. As a result of those representations, the government has decided to extend, to a period of 12 months from the existing six months, the time within which the drought relief payments, currently restricted to only six months, can be paid. This is essentially a family support payment to help meet day‐to‐day living expenses.

Other special assistance from Austudy through a relaxed assets test will also continue for the extended period as will special access to health care cards, family payments and the parenting allowance. As part of this package of measures, an extra $10 million for farm recovery, particularly to help with herd rebuilding and pasture re‐establishment, will also be made available.

BREAK.PARA: This is an entirely appropriate response to an ongoing area of very great need. The farmers of Australia over the last five years have suffered many things. They have been ravaged in many parts of our country by one of the worst droughts experienced for decades and this range of additional assistance measures is entirely appropriate. It is relevant. It is defensible. And I hope it is something that will draw the support of all members of the parliament.

The truth is that there are still many Australian farmers, although they have been out of drought now approaching a period of six months, who have no real prospect of a viable cash flow for some months into the future, and that is why the government has decided to double the period from six months to 12 months. It will not only apply to those people who have just come out of a drought declaration in June; it will apply in future to all people who have been in drought declared areas. Instead of having the assistance continue for a period of six months, that assistance will continue for a period of 12 months. It is estimated that these measures will cost over a full year an extra $81 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much!

—They are to cost $81 million. The honourable member for Werriwa is questioning the commitment, is he? Is the honourable member for Werriwa complaining about this? He is. The honourable member for Werriwa does not like a bit of extra relief being given to the drought strapped farmers of Australia. The honourable member for Werriwa cannot help himself. He is a beauty, this bloke—he cannot help himself.

BREAK.PARA: This decision is an example of the ongoing commitment of the coalition government to rural and regional areas of Australia. We are not only interested in justice and fairness for Australian farmers; we are also interested in jobs for Australians in the regional areas of this country. That is why we took the decision that we did in relation to woodchips—and I noticed that a few days ago in the Senate the Labor Party tried to knock off those regional jobs; I noticed that the Labor Party wanted to knock them off. That is a great message to send to regional Australia. You want to knock off their jobs; you want to cripple the timber industry. You do not want to give those regional towns any hope of future viability.

I am proud to make this announcement, on behalf of the coalition government. It is an earnest of the ongoing commitment of the Liberal and National parties together to the viability of the Australian farm sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it his position that ordinary wage earners should once again be subsidising executives in big companies taking large chunks of their salaries in the form of tax‐free school fee payments, home mortgage payments, health benefits and overseas holidays? Given that only six per cent of small businesses pay fringe benefits tax, what else could the Prime Minister have meant when he said last Friday that he wished he could announce its immediate abolition?
—No. That was your policy and practice for 13 years.

—Mr Speaker, I have a supplementary question. If the Prime Minister did not mean that last Friday, what did he mean in using the words that he did—that he wanted to see the immediate abolition of fringe benefits tax?

—No, I meant that I wanted to do something to reduce the red tape burden that has been strangling small business. I meant that I wanted to do something to get rid of the unfair dismissal law that you still want to maintain. I said that I wanted to do something about the provisional tax uplift factor, which we have done. I also want to do this: I also want to remind you that one of the reasons that you were thrown out of office unceremoniously on 2 March was that you had drifted a long way away from the people who were your original constituents.
—I seek to table the transcript of the Prime Minister's press conference in which he says, `I wish I could announce its abolition this morning.'

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister advise the House on what action the government will take in response to the recommendations made by the Small Business Deregulation Task Force to reduce the red tape burden on small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the honourable gentleman, can I say that one of the hallmarks of the coalition government will be an unswerving commitment to the role of small business in the Australian economy. It remains the case that, as we move towards the next century, more and more Australians will be employed by small business, fewer and fewer proportionately by large corporations and fewer and fewer by government instrumentalities. That is a trend that all Australians must understand and accept. It follows from that that all governments have an obligation—an absolute obligation—to create as welcoming a set of circumstances for small business as is consistent with the responsibility of governments to the employees of small business and to the consumers of the products and services of small business.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the reason why I committed the coalition in the election campaign to the goal of reducing red tape by up to 50 per cent in our first term of office. To help achieve that goal, I appointed the Small Business Deregulation Task Force that was chaired by Mr Charlie Bell, managing director of McDonald's foods. On behalf of the government, I want to thank Mr Bell and the other members of his committee for delivering a first‐class report, delivering it in a very readable, digestible form and delivering it well and truly on time. I can say in reply to the members of the task force that the government will give a comprehensive response to the recommendations of the task force by mid‐February 1997.

We have already implemented a large number of the commitments we made in the election campaign. We have reduced the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. That is worth $160 million a year—let me say again: $160 million a year of extra cash flow injected into the activities of small business, partnerships and firms.

In the Treasurer's budget we foreshadowed legislation that will come into effect on 1 July next year that will provide capital gains tax rollover relief to the tune of $200 million. This will fulfil an election undertaking made by the coalition. It will be of direct and very considerable benefit to the small business sector of Australia. We have legislated, and we await the passage of the legislation in the Senate.

Now that an arrangement has been reached with the Australian Democrats, the Labor Party almost alone will remain opposed to freeing the small business sector of Australia from the unfair dismissal laws. I want to say that again: every time a small business man or woman complains about the unfair dismissal laws that actually discourage thousands of small businesses around Australia from taking on more staff, there is only one group of people they have to blame—and that is the men and women of the Australian Labor Party. It is the men and women of the Australian Labor Party who were responsible, without a mandate, without warning, without any electoral authority, for introducing the unfair dismissal law, a law described even by the sole remaining Labor Premier in Australia, Bob Carr, as a law that is destroying the job opportunities of young Australians. Nowhere is that happening more intentionally than in the small business sector of the Australian economy.

The report of the Bell committee made a number of sweeping recommendations about the operation of the fringe benefits tax. The terms of reference of the committee were that consideration should take place on the basis of revenue neutrality so far as recommendations were concerned, but there is little doubt that the complexity of the fringe benefits tax is one of the main complaints of small business wherever you go in Australia.

The fringe benefits tax cannot be abolished. I do not pretend for a moment that we hold out the prospect of abolishing it or getting rid of it in any substantial way. We are not arguing that. But we are arguing, and we welcome the proposals that have been put forward by Mr Bell's committee, that there are ways and means of making that tax operate in a less burdensome fashion.

There is a recommendation that government agencies should develop a single registration form for small businesses, that the Australian Taxation Office develop a single registration form for all taxes, to allow employers to issue all group certificates at the end of the year unless required by an employee, to extend the voluntary payment system for provisional tax to ease the cash flow burden on small businesses. I have already taken action to place small business deregulation on the agenda for the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments to take place in November.

In conclusion, this is a first‐class report. All of the recommendations will be treated seriously by the coalition government. I will announce a comprehensive response by not later than the middle of February next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that today's ANZ job survey shows that job advertisements have now fallen for four consecutive months for the first time in nearly five years and that jobs growth is at only half the rate needed to meet the modest budget forecasts of employment growth? Has the Prime Minister's cabinet unemployment committee met as yet? If so, what immediate decisions has it taken to reverse this recent catastrophic decline in Australia's jobs outlook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give the honourable member for Batman something; that is, he has an enormous amount of gall, nerve and hide as someone who was the industrial mainstay for years of the failed policies that caused the present high level of unemployment. Let everybody understand that we have been in office for eight months, yet it is all our fault. They were there for 13 years and none of it is their fault. It is an extraordinary proposition.

ANSWER.PARA: All of the available evidence is that you are the only people who believe that absurd proposition. If you wanted to make a serious contribution to relieving the problem of unemployment, if you were interested in anything other than shedding crocodile tears about unemployment in Australia, you would have passed the workplace relations bill months ago and you would have signalled your intention to pass the budget a long time ago. By those two actions alone you would have contributed to a far more benign and stable economic climate in Australia.
You had 13 years. You drove unemployment to post‐Depression levels and you still have no credibility at all to lecture us on the subject of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of the latest movement in the Commonwealth Bank‐HIA index of housing affordability? What are the implications for home buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kooyong for his question. No doubt he read, as I did, in one of the newspapers circulating in Victoria this morning that buying a home in Victoria is at its most affordable level since 1984, driven by lower mortgage rates, higher household incomes and an easing in house prices in the September quarter. Affordability—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would interject very loudly at this stage, if I were you, to try to drown this out. Affordability is at its highest since the Commonwealth Bank‐Housing Industry Association index began in late 1984. That is the delivery to the Australian family of housing affordability at the best rate since they started taking this index in late 1984. There is no better benefit that can be delivered to the home buyers of Australia than lower interest rates, particularly to those families which struggled under the punitive interest rates of the failed Keating regime when the failed Keating regime took housing interest rates to 17 per cent and business rates to 21 and 22 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: It gives this side of the House great encouragement to see that we are delivering housing affordability to average Australians. The HIA‐CBA housing report recorded a 10 per cent increase in housing affordability in the September quarter. Housing affordability has been increasing over the last year and this is the biggest quarterly rise since March 1992 when interest rates fell by one percentage point to 12 per cent. All of the variables that affect affordability are working in the same direction.

The loan repayment needed on a typical first home mortgage fell from 20.7 per cent of household income in the June quarter 1996 to 18.9 per cent in the September quarter. The level of housing affordability is one factor, together with the unwinding of stocks, which points to a recovery in the house building industry starting next year. These are direct benefits to the Australia home buyer.

I would also take this opportunity to point out that margins—that is, the margin for banks between the interest paid to depositors and the interest rate charged to borrowers—have been traditionally high in Australia and there are opportunities for those margins to still fall further.

We saw earlier this year that the major banks were, as a result of aggressive competition in the home mortgage market and as a result of competitive pressures, able to reduce the variable home loan rate by 0.75 per cent in advance of a cut in official interest rates. That proves the benefits of competition, and the benefits of aggressive competition for mortgage originators, who have now taken their rates below eight per cent, also puts the pressure on banks to see if they can compress those margins further in relation to the variable mortgage rate.

As far as the government is concerned, it is competition which will drive the compression of those margins. It is competition which will deliver those kinds of benefits to borrowers. It is sound economic policy which has made housing affordability so great for the average Australian family. This is the delivery of the program that the coalition holds dear—to families and to children in relation to mortgage rates. This is the way in which average Australian families will see the benefits of good economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will be aware of the political and media criticism of him for not condemning me for remarks I have not made and for views I do not hold.
—The honourable member for Oxley will move very quickly to the question or resume her place.

—He will be aware that the criticism targets an incident in Rockhampton involving five Singaporean defence personnel. He will be aware that reports of the incident have been spread widely in Asian newspapers and that they have been subject to editorials in Asian newspapers.
—Order! The honourable member for Oxley has a question for the Prime Minister?
—Yes.
—Address the question or resume your seat.

—Is it a fact that the attack on the Singaporean defence personnel was carried out not by white Australians inflamed by me and condoned by him, but by a group of Aboriginals where alcohol was involved on both sides?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say in reply to the member for Oxley that the investigation of alleged criminal offences is the responsibility of the state police authorities. I do not think it is ever appropriate for federal members of parliament to give running commentaries, be they members or ministers or Prime Ministers, on particular police investigations. I know that the Minister for Defence offered a private briefing to the shadow minister for defence. I think there were good reasons for him doing that. I think the same private briefing could, I am sure with profit, be offered by the Minister for Defence to the member for Oxley.

ANSWER.PARA: Could I lastly say as a general observation that I do not believe the racial background of an alleged offender against the laws of Australia should be the subject of identification or comment unless—this is a very important caveat—it is necessary to the identification and apprehension of that person, where I think it is an entirely legitimate thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. What has the government done to ensure that the states, territories and local governments join with the Howard government in reducing the burden on small business? Minister, what will you be doing to ensure that the recommendations of the small business task force are not lost in time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Herbert for his question. Last Friday was indeed a defining moment for small business. Firstly, the Prime Minister and I received a very comprehensive report by the Small Business Deregulation Task Force, a report that contains 62 recommendations with regard to the red tape burden imposed on small business.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the report sets out the litany of bureaucratic madness built up over the last 13 years by Labor. If Labor was ever wondering why small business cast them aside on 2 March, they should read the report. Even Labor's shadow minister for small business is reported as saying on 28 October:
In hindsight the Labor federal government could have done more to raise the profile and importance of small business in the community.
How right he was in that particular case. It is a pity that small business had to wait for the election of a coalition government to address these issues.

I am pleased to inform the House that the state and territory governments, as well as the local governments, are committed to the government's endeavours to free small business from the red tape and compliance burden. They pledged their commitment at the small business deregulation summit held on 12 June and I am meeting with state and territory small business ministers, as well as local government representatives, on 16 December to discuss the report's recommendations and agree on strategies to address the task force recommendations.

This government is committed to removing the red tape burden. This report confirms our commitment. I can assure the House that the recommendations will not be lost in time. We undertook to tackle the red tape burden.

As the Prime Minister mentioned a moment ago, the government is committed to responding to the report by mid-February. We will be remembered as the government that lifted the red tape burden on small business, a commitment that will enable small business to grow and expand and employ young Australians, unlike that mob that in fact ignored small business for the last 13 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In view of your previous answer to the parliament today, why have you not pressed the banks to bring their credit card interest rates down? Why have credit card rates remained unchanged since last June? Will you, as a matter of urgency, direct the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to commence formal monitoring of credit cards to ensure that consumers get a fair deal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I have raised it with the banks. Did you hear that? Of course I have. And why wouldn't I? Credit card interest rates are a matter of concern. They are 16.7 per cent in 1996. They are a matter of concern because under Labor in 1990 they were 24.8 per cent. I know that the shadow Treasurer has put you up to asking this question, but did he tell you that when Labor was in control they were at 24.8 per cent? Did he tell you why the Labor Party was unable to do anything about them? Did he tell you why you were the bunny put up to ask the question?

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to credit card rates, it is important that competitive factors be unleashed in relation to them as well. Just as competitive factors have reduced bank margins, competitive factors will reduce credit card margins. Interest rates for credit cards of banks with no interest free period range from 12.75 per cent to 17.95 per cent. So there is obviously room for competition in there. Credit cards with an interest free period range from 15.5 per cent to 18.95 per cent, the majority having an annual fee ranging from $15 to $35. You will recall that one of the things the Labor Party did was introduce fees on credit cards. Do you recall that? He has gone silent again, hasn't he?

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit of amnesia.

—A bit of amnesia—selective amnesia. One of the reasons why that was done was so that transactional costs could be charged and in relation to interest rates you would get that competition. That was one of the reasons why it was done. So we have seen an improvement on the extraordinarily high interest rate regime of the Labor Party, and it is something that I constantly mention to banks—that we would like to see the same competitive forces as are working under this government in relation to the variable mortgage rate also work in relation to credit cards.
—What are you going to do about it?

—I hear the shadow Treasurer intervening at this point. I just want to say to the Prime Minister that I had a lovely Sunday morning because I opened up my paper and I saw this headline: `Evans vows to stay for long haul'. The article says:

ANSWER.PARA: Speculation about Mr Evans' possible early retirement has been running since Labor's poor showing at the Lindsay by-election . . .
Well, he wasn't responsible single‐handedly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Relevant as that may be to Mr Costello's future, it is not relevant to the answering of this question. What is he going to do about directing the ACCC to bring those rates down? That is the question he was asked. Why doesn't he answer it?
—The Treasurer will quickly finalise his answer.
—The article went on to quote the shadow Treasurer as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: .. there is no doubt after a break at Christmas I will bounce back with renewed vigour and enthusiasm.
But my hopes were dashed because the headline was `Evans vows to stay for long haul'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, relating to relevance. I did not ask the Treasurer about a newspaper article; I asked him about what he was going to do to bring credit card interest rates down in the interests of Australian consumers and Australian businesses. Would he answer the question, please?
—I thank the honourable member for Corio and I would draw the Treasurer's attention to the question.

—Yes, Mr Speaker. One of the things we are going to do to bring credit card rates down is stay in government for a long time. That is why `Evans vows to stay for long haul' is a part of the answer to this question. But my hopes were dashed because the article had this statement:

ANSWER.PARA: I have told everyone I will be here for the long haul or at least until the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. These are repeated breaches by the Treasurer of standing order 145.
—I thank the honourable member. I think the Treasurer has concluded his wide-ranging answer to the question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister advise the House how many applications for premium increases from private health funds are currently under consideration? Is the minister aware of how the previous government dealt with such applications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. A number of funds have applied for increases since 29 August, and currently there are three applications for premium increases under consideration. I will not confirm or deny any reports about a particular fund because this information is commercial‐in‐confidence, but I think it is worth telling the honourable member about the process that these funds go through. Firstly, they are referred to the Private Health Insurance Advisory Council for its advice as to whether or not the premiums are required for statutory solvency levels. In some cases, my department has approached funds and asked for additional information, asked for figures to be reworked or, particularly, asked to clarify assumptions under which some of the calculations have been made. Once this has been done, the department forwards notification details and the council's advice to me, together with any other information that it might think relevant. I make recommendations then to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, keeping in mind the basis on which premium increases can be disallowed.

ANSWER.PARA: To date, no applications have been disallowed because all the premium increases have been justified on the basis of the funds' requirement to maintain solvency levels under the law. However, I am making it very clear to the funds that there is no more rubber stamping of premium increases. The public is not expecting that premium increases will never go up, but it does expect the health funds to act responsibly with full reference to the environment in which they operate. I am taking these expectations into account before considering premium increase proposals. I would also remind the honourable member that the previous government over a period of 13 years allowed 174 premium increases and knocked back none whatsoever, and that was about one premium increase per fund per year. So that rubber stamping has certainly stopped.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Treasurer. Will he accept that last Friday's alarming retail sales figures and now today's equally alarming ANZ job advertisement figures confirm all the other indicators now showing that the Australian economy is dead flat; that a big interest rate cut is necessary to revive it; and that if the Reserve Bank does decide on a cut at its meeting tomorrow it will be for that reason and for that reason only?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it will not. When it is considering monetary policy, the Reserve Bank will look at the inflation performance and at the indicators I have enumerated over quite some time: namely, the inflation target of two per cent to three per cent underlying inflation over the course of the cycle. In relation to wages figures, we saw figures that were quite consistent. They will be the matters on the mind of the Reserve Bank. Nobody could think otherwise.

ANSWER.PARA: Every time there is a good inflation figure, Senator Sherry runs out and says, `It's all Labor's doing.' Every time there is a retail figure, you run out and say, `It's all the coalition's doing.' One of the things you will have to try to do is get some consistency. You have to actually understand. The trouble is where there is no understanding there is no conscience. That is what illustrates Labor's economic policy.

You run out and say we should be balancing the budget over three years and then you oppose every measure to do it. When asked the day after the budget what you would have done differently, you said, `We'd have balanced over three years.' That is what we did in the budget. That is what we actually did. You came out the day after with absolute ignorance as to what had been announced the night before and then when it went to the shadow cabinet we found this proposal to balance the budget over three years but to knock back $19 billion worth of savings to get there. Where there is no understanding, there is no conscience, and that is the situation the Labor Party has got itself into.

In relation to jobs and employment growth, the employment growth in the September quarter was 0.5 per cent. It was right on budget target, which is two per cent over the year—0.5 per cent in a quarter, two per cent over the year. It was right on target, bang on target. That was the outcome. You can go and delude yourselves that you will actually make a political point by trying to talk down the Australian economy, but talking down the economy is the last act of a desperate opposition.

There are wonderful opportunities in the Australian economy at the moment. We have home variable mortgage rates the lowest in 20 years. We have housing affordability the best since 1984. We have enormous investment in sectors such as the mining industry and communications and entertainment. We have wonderful opportunities in relation to long-term bond rates. We have halved the margin differential on the US long-term bond and the Australian bond. We have a new monetary policy target which gives us the opportunity to lock in low inflation. We have competition in the financial system, which is delivering the benefits of competition. There are wonderful opportunities at the moment.

In relation to the reform program of this government, there are even better opportunities with a new industrial relations system, with the opportunity to develop savings in this country to give us the prospect of sustainable growth over the long and medium term. No amount of doomsaying from an `un‐understanding' opposition will take away those wonderful prospects that we have in this country at the moment, the prospects to relieve the economic torpor of 13 years of Keating‐Labor failure and to get on with the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister advise the House on the progress of the government's industrial relations scheme? When the scheme is implemented, what benefits will flow to Australian workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and for his interest in the subject. It is very important for Australia that we have a modern industrial relations system. The reason we want to do it is that it will be good for the average Australian. For people at work, whether they are an employer or an employee, in the last 13 years they have been deprived of the opportunity and the encouragement to sit down at work and say, `What's good for this business which, therefore, will be good for both the future investment in this business and the wages of the people who work in it?'

ANSWER.PARA: One of the positive developments we have seen in the last few days has been the passage of the objects of the workplace relations legislation in the Senate. That is of symbolic importance as well as practical importance because the objects of the act really underpin the direction in which we want to encourage the system to move in the future.

The principal object of the bill reflects the government's intention to establish a framework for much more cooperative workplace relations which will lead to improved productivity, high employment, low inflation and international competitiveness through higher productivity and a flexible and fair labour market. It also emphasises agreement making as the principal means of the determination of wages and conditions above the award safety net standards and really enables employers and employees to choose the most appropriate form of agreement for their particular circumstances. So you can end up with tailor‐made arrangements to really facilitate the better management of our businesses.

The object gives primary responsibility for industrial relations and agreement making to employers and employees at the workplace level with the award system acting as a safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions. It is employers and employees at the workplace level who really are best able to determine what is in the best interests of that particular business and of the personal needs of the employees themselves.

That is also consistent with another underlying value in our system. That is, the government is saying to the people running our businesses, `Subject to that reasonable set of minimum conditions, it is really your responsibility at work to take advantage of that system which best suits you.' So the legislation is properly enabling as opposed to being proscriptive.

It is worth noting that, contrary to the claims of some of the critics of the bill, the needs of women and young people and the role of the unions are also addressed. The principal object, amongst other things, includes ensuring freedom of association and democratic, accountable and effective trade unions and employer organisations.

PARA.BREAK: The one which I dubbed the Howard object is the object which encourages the parties at work to allow employees to better balance their work and family responsibilities. There has been such a big social change in our country in the last 20 or 30 years. It is a great shame that in the last 13 years those who have wanted to better balance those responsibilities have been denied that opportunity. The last and interesting point to make is that, whilst we put up what I think are very sen sible and practical objects to the proposed legislation, the Labor Party has been opposing them at absolutely every turn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I endeavoured to place on the Notice Paper a question which was in exactly the same terms as the question that has been asked of the minister, seeking that the minister provide to me details of all amendments to the workplace relations bill which have now been agreed upon by the government and the Democrats and details of any public reaction to the bill and the government's response to these reactions. This question was ruled out of order as it was said to be in breach of standing order 72. I am wondering why that was out of order in terms of standing order 72 yet the question given to, and now being answered by, the minister is not similarly in breach of standing order 72.
—I thank the honourable member for Wills for his point of order. The question is in order, and I invite the minister to continue his response.

—Let me now conclude by saying that what is interesting is that the Labor Party has been opposing these sensible changes. So I must say that I was rather choking on my weeties on Sunday morning as well, Treasurer.
—A very happy Sunday, wasn't it?

—It was a happy Sunday. The bit that I was choking on was, `There's no doubt I've been rather flat in the past six months'. The explanation of that is obvious: you guys are day in, day out being flattened by the ACTU, who are telling you what to do and what to say when it comes to the workplace relations bill in the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: It sets the pattern that we will see increasingly in the months ahead where, rather than hanging on to the position that you had on 2 March on industrial relations, you will continue to regress through the early 1990s, through the 1980s, into the 1970s and further beyond, all at the behest of the trade union movement, who ultimately dictate your policy on these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that last week 140 full-time and casual workers at the Adelaide company Griffin Press lost their jobs and that this has been directly linked to the government's axing of the book bounty? In light of this, would the Prime Minister convene or request that the employment cabinet committee urgently review this decision? Can the Prime Minister look any of those workers in the eye and tell them that this decision meets his jobs test—`to increase economic growth and therefore increase jobs for Australians'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I say in answer to the honourable member for Port Adelaide that the employment committee of cabinet will address and examine all of the policies of the government which bear on issues relating to employment and unemployment. The question asked by the honourable member makes the rather erroneous assumption—if I may say so with respect, because I know he is concerned about his own constituents, and it is a legitimate and proper question to ask on behalf of some of your constituents—that there is absolutely no contribution made to medium and longer term economic growth when a government undertakes fiscal consolidation.

ANSWER.PARA: Even that proposition was assented to by your current leader when he was minister for employment and the former Prime Minister when he was both Prime Minister and Treasurer and it has been assented to by leading political figures on both sides of politics over a long period of time. If you really want to destroy jobs in this country, you first destroy the country's creditworthiness, and that is what the former government was doing by running up such a large volume of debt. It was not until the new government came into office and we tackled the problem of both the national debt and, through it, the overseas debt that we put down a strategy which, in the medium to longer term, will be a strategy for dealing with that.

If you are really interested in unemployment, if you are interested in getting unemployment down, if you are interested in building a medium and longer term basis of sustained economic growth, you cannot continue to run the sort of budget deficits that we inherited from the former government. We inherited a deficit of $10 billion in underlying terms despite the promises to the contrary. If we had sat by and done nothing, if we had adopted the advice that was given to us by some members of the Labor Party—although, interestingly, the current acting leader of the Labor Party actually, in one of his calmer moments, agreed with the fiscal consolidation strategy—

TALK.START.PARA: —The day after the budget.
—A reasonable one.

—That is quite right. Would you like to have a further little chat about it? That is absolutely right. No wonder my colleagues have very pleasant Sunday mornings reading the Melbourne newspapers. The fact is that you agreed with our strategy, and if we had adopted the strategy that is implicit in the question, if we had adopted the advice that is now so freely given to us, the outlook for unemployment in this country would be very, very bad indeed, because you cannot build employment on fiscal profligacy. You cannot build employment by allowing a budget to career out of control. That is why over a period of 13 years your signal economic achievement was to drive unemployment in this country to a post-Depression high of 11.2 per cent.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Has the minister seen comments by the Leader of the Opposition supporting the positive aspects for Australia of business migration? What is the minister's view of the impact that opposition moves to oppose the government's migration program would have on business and skilled migration?

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the question asked the minister what his view was; in other words, asked the minister for his opinion. Hence, it is out of order as it is contrary to standing order 144.
—The question is out of order.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Can the minister confirm that he remains a director and a principal shareholder of Prosser Automotive Engineers Pty Ltd? Can he confirm that Prosser Automotive Engineers has an interest in the petroleum industry in Western Australia? Can he also confirm that he represented the Commonwealth at a meeting of the Ministerial Council on Consumer Affairs in Darwin on 27 September? Can he confirm that at that meeting he successfully persuaded ministers to oppose a move to introduce petrol temperature correction at service stations—a position which he advocated publicly before the meeting? Isn't it the case that introduction of temperature correction would have made petrol consumers better off at the expense of suppliers? Isn't this a clear breach of the Prime Minister's guidelines?

—I think some of the members on the other side have actually been petrol sniffing, with that sort of question. It is a great irony that the last true worker on that side of the parliament in fact does not sit on the frontbench any more. It was actually Mick Young. The last person who represented the worker over there was Mick Young. We have on this side of the parliament many people who have not only worked for employers but also employed workers. But these sorts of stupid questions take away from what we are trying to do on this side of the parliament—to provide a better economic climate so that we can grow jobs here and build a better climate for business and small business.

—Mr Speaker, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that Prosser Automotive Engineers has an interest in the petroleum industry? Can he indicate the role that he took in a decision at the Ministerial Council on Consumer Affairs which advantages people supplying petrol at the expense of those buying it?
—That is a repeat of the question earlier asked. The question is out of order.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Has the minister seen comments by the Leader of the Opposition supporting the positive aspects for Australia of business migration? What impact will opposition moves to oppose the government's migration program have on business and skilled migration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder why it is that the opposition is so sensitive about these matters. It is particularly important, when discussing issues in relation to immigration, to address factual questions. One of the issues which I think needs to be addressed in a factual way relates to unemployment in particular. It is an area of frequent misunderstanding. The longitudinal study that my department has undertaken demonstrates that family migrants have a significantly less satisfactory employment experience in Australia than skilled migrants.

ANSWER.PARA: In July, after the government announced its program for this year, the Leader of the Opposition made some comments about employment. He said:
. . . bad news for Australian jobs. . . Mr Howard has increased the category that directly competes with Australians trying to get jobs.
On Friday, on a program on Sydney radio, he said about employment:
The fact of the matter is that the current immigration levels do not impact on that at all.
He went on to say:

The impact of immigration probably on all of that is slightly to the good in terms of opportunities that are provided in building industries and the opportunities that are provided for business migrants coming in to create employment chances here in Australia.

He was recognising that the skilled categories, particularly in the business migration program, were going to play a very positive role in building the Australian economy and in providing job opportunities for Australians. I have no quarrel with that.

The fact is that the economic benefits that can be derived from immigration are going to be there only if the program is balanced. What the opposition want to do is to attach themselves to our overall target of 74,000. Then they want to expand family migration, which is essentially unskilled in its character, and to take away opportunities for independent migrants, for business migrants and for skilled migrants—the very people that they acknowledge themselves, and that the Leader of the Opposition acknowledges, provide the impetus and justification for an immigration program.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are misrepresenting our position.

—I would hope that the noisy members of the opposition start to reassess their view on these particular matters and reassess the approach that they are going to take in the Senate later on and address the significant balance problems that do exist while we have a program where two out of every eight migrants to Australia today are in the skilled categories and over six are in the family reunion categories.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I refer the minister to the harm being done to the tourism industry by the statements of the member for Oxley and the actions of some of her supporters. Will the minister ensure that the difficulties being experienced by the tourism industry are kept under close review? If it is the case that further difficulties arise, will the minister guarantee that action, including restoring budget tourism promotion funding, will be taken by the government to restore confidence overseas in Australia as a tourist destination and to protect the jobs of 600,000 Australians employed in that industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the matter raised by the honourable member, and remind him that the TCA annual meeting was held in Perth on the weekend. These matters were raised at that meeting. Since then the matter has been raised by another tourist organisation. This morning I received a letter from the managing director of Tourism Council Australia in which he outlined their meeting's resolution. The resolution of the meeting was, firstly, to issue a media statement stressing the potential harm of the debate and, secondly, in partnership with other government ministers, to seek to reassure visitors from major nations in this region that their tourism business remains welcome in Australia. He went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: We were pleased to note that on the same day as our Council meeting the Government moved on each of these proposals.

On top of that, I have also asked the Australian Tourist Commission to keep me informed of any developments that may be showing up in tourist numbers coming to Australia. The ATC is Australia's major marketing organisation and, as such, is in touch with all the facts relevant to that area. At this moment I have had no response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. The minister was quoting from a letter. I would ask that he table that letter, pursuant to standing order 321.
—I invite the minister to table the letter.
—It is confidential.
—The material is confidential.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of claims that government budget decisions might have an adverse impact on Aboriginal health? Is there any basis for such claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. There has been a lot of interest in Aboriginal health in recent weeks, as there always is, with comments by the Fred Hollows Foundation, by Mandawuy Yunupingu and also by the member for Dobell on Sunday.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make a few comments about Aboriginal health. The first is that the budget, overall, is very positive for Aboriginal health. The Aboriginal health specific budget was not subject to any savings; in fact, the efficiency dividend is being ploughed back into new Aboriginal health services. There are 200 Aboriginal communities in Australia without any access to health whatsoever, even the most basic nursing post. We will be able to address 35 of these communities' needs because of decisions in the budget.

We have also allowed Aboriginal medical services to have access to Medicare billing. Not all did. This provides an income stream that many of them did not have. We announced funding for the third national HIV-AIDS strategy. This will run from 1997 to the year 2000. Within that, Aboriginal sexual health will be taking a greater priority. I have had discussions with organisations interested in HIV-AIDS matters. They accept that it is time that Aboriginal people got a greater access to this funding.

There are a number of other initiatives that will specifically benefit Aboriginal people. The diabetes action plan that we promised before the election will be implemented. It will affect Aboriginal people because they have a particularly high rate of diabetes. We are trying to get GP and specialist services into rural and remote areas. We committed $215 million to that in the budget. That will help Aboriginal people. We have a joint initiative with the AMA, which is very well progressed, to try to get specialist services into rural and remote areas.

I would not want to see Aboriginal health just in terms of money, because we would be making the mistakes of the past if we thought that was all it was. One thing I have been working very hard on is framework agreements with state and territory governments. I was able to announce to the House a couple of months ago that we had signed the first one with South Australia. I have now signed five such agreements, with South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales, the ACT and Queensland, the last being on Friday with Victoria. I am confident that we will soon have every state and territory in the country signing these agreements. Of themselves they are not going to make a dramatic difference, but they are an important building block to make sure that two things happen. The first is that all tiers of government are trying to work in a coordinated manner. The second thing is that we bring Aboriginal medical services and ATSIC in around the table as part of the joint planning process so that never again do we get the overlap and duplication that have bedevilled this area.

I would say to the honourable member that the task is still immense, that honourable members should reflect that in 1996 there are still 380 Aboriginal communities with no access to running water and there are still 200 Aboriginal communities with no access to a health service, no matter how rudimentary. The task is not an easy one. It has had many overblown hopes before. It is certainly not something I want to do. I would say to the honourable member for Dobell and to any other member of this House that if they have serious ideas as to how we can do more and how we can make a greater impact, I make the offer that I am very keen to hear from them. I would be happy to make my department available. In the end, this is something in which, if we can all work together in a slow, hard slog, we might make some improvement over time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. It follows the answer from the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs to the question of the member for Hotham. Does the Prime Minister accept the apparent view of the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs that it is a `stupid question' to ask of a minister a question going directly to a possible breach of the Prime Minister's guideline that ministers may retain directorships in private companies only if retention of the directorships are not likely to conflict with the ministers' public duty? Does the Prime Minister further take the view that it is a `stupid question' to ask of one of his ministers a question going to that particular minister's shares in a company or business involved in an area of his portfolio responsibilities? If these are not `stupid questions' for any halfway accountable executive and a halfway legitimate parliament, will the Prime Minister direct his minister to answer them?
—The answer to the acting—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. The question really asks the Prime Minister for an opinion about something that the minister has said. In my submission, it is out of order because it is calling for opinion on all counts.
—The question is out of order.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: before you rule on it, I asked the Prime Minister whether he accepted the position as stated by his minister. That was the way it was put.
—That is another question.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. Mr Speaker, you heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's question. You then called the Prime Minister, who had risen to answer the question. By that time the caravan has moved on and it is not competent for someone to call into question your ruling, by which you had asked the Prime Minister to answer the question. Can we now take it that it is in order to call into question whether a question is in order some way through the answer?
—I thank the honourable member for Watson for his point of order. The caravans in both instances have moved on. I have ruled on the question.
—Mr Speaker, on a further point of order: there were three questions which I asked.
—They all sought an opinion. I listened to them carefully.
—The third one was: will you direct your minister to answer the questions?
—No, I have ruled on the questions.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice. Can the Attorney-General advise what progress is being made in relation to Australian participation in schemes to provide for the international transfer of prisoners? Is it true that Australia is seeking to conclude a prison er transfer agreement with Thailand and, if so, how is it progressing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the question from the honourable member for Cook, I am pleased to advise the House that the recent meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General held in Canberra took an important step towards Australia's participation in international arrangements for the transfer of prisoners. With the exception of the Northern Territory, and subject to final confirmation from one jurisdiction, all state and territory Attorneys-General endorsed a legislative scheme for the transfer of prisoners. This endorsement paves the way for participation in transfer of prisoner schemes with other countries. Such schemes have significant humanitarian, economic and social advantages.

ANSWER.PARA: Once enacted, the proposed legislation will allow Australians serving prison sentences overseas and foreign nationals serving prison sentences in Australian prisons to return to their home countries to complete their sentences. Before any prisoner transfers can take place, this legislation will have to pass through the federal parliament and through the relevant state and territory parliaments. A number of administrative steps will also need to be taken, and transfer agreements will have to be made with other countries. We will be working to have the scheme operating as quickly as possible, and to that end I intend to introduce the Commonwealth legislation in the near future. I expect the participating states and the ACT will enact complementary legislation promptly.

The honourable member for Cook also asked about Thailand. The conclusion of a prisoner transfer agreement with Thailand has been a high priority because of the comparatively high number of Australian prisoners in Thai prisons. Thai and Australian officials conducted preliminary discussions on this matter in April this year. The endorsement of the legislative scheme at the recent SCAG meeting will enable the commencement of more substantive negotiations. Any agreement reached with Thailand will not be able to enter into force until Australia's legislation—that is, the Commonwealth, states and ACT legislation—is in place. As I said, I expect relevant jurisdictions will act on this promptly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to advise the House of a temporary change in sitting arrangements for tomorrow afternoon. There is an event occurring at 3.20 tomorrow afternoon, namely, the Melbourne Cup, for which the whole nation stops. It is only fitting, therefore, that the parliament joins in the celebrations of that great event. It has been agreed between the two sides of the House that, after question time tomorrow, at approximately 3.00 p.m., the House will adjourn for approximately 30 minutes. It will require the cooperation and assistance of ministers in limiting answers to an even greater extent than they do at present to wind up by 3 o'clock. And, of course, questions from the opposition need to be briefer than they have been until now.

—Mr Speaker, I draw your attention to question No. 484 to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and also question No. 584 to the Minister for Administrative Services. Under standing order 150, could I ask that you write to the relevant ministers seeking answers.
—I will pursue inquiries with the relevant ministers on your behalf forthwith.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October, the member for Moore (Mr Filing) asked me a question on the hours of operation of the airconditioning system in Parliament House. I have been informed that the system operates for the following hours per day: on sitting days, between 7.00 a.m. and 12 midnight, and if the sitting of either House extends beyond this time the airconditioning remains on until one hour after the last house rises; and, on non-sitting days, between 7.00 a.m. and 7.00 p.m., which does include weekends.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have also been advised that, if the windows were allowed to be opened, because of the design of the centralised airconditioning system in the building, this would lead to the discomfort of others in rooms adjacent to the room with the window open and substantially increase the energy costs for Parliament House. To provide more information on this matter, I have asked the Joint House Department to issue a circular to building occupants on the building's airconditioning system. If individuals still have concerns, the circular contains contact points where inquiries can be made and, if necessary, investigations ordered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Anthony, Larry, MP; Anthony, Larry, MP; Anthony, Larry, MP; Crosio, Janice, MP; Crosio, Janice, MP; McClelland, Robert, MP; Melham, Daryl, MP; Mutch, Stephen, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the families and friends of Cooloon Children's Centre Inc, Tweed Heads, and Gumnuts Community Preschool Inc., NSW, and Rainbow Children's Centre Inc., NSW, and Merrydays Kindergarten Society Inc., NSW, and Smithfield Child Care Centre, NSW, and Turrella Children's Centre, NSW, and Revesby Uniting Church Child Care Centre, NSW, and Koala Child Care Centre, NSW, respectfully bring to your attention the adverse effects to the quality, availability and equity of child care should changes proposed in the recently tabled budget go ahead.
Namely that:

PARA.TAB: removal of operational subsidies to community based (not for profit) long day care centres will increase fees, adding a greater financial burden to working parents.

removal of operational subsidy to community based (not for profit) long day care centres in order to place them in competition with privately owned centres (operating for profit) is unfair, iniquitous and may result in a lesser quality of care for our children.

PETITION.PARA: We request the House support the retention of operational subsidies to community based (not for profit) long day care centres and that community based (not for profit) child care continue to be valued and supported as a lower cost, high quality child care alternative for working parents.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anthony (from 65 citizens), Mr Anthony (from 41 citizens), Mr Anthony (from 31 citizens), Mrs Crosio (from 141 citizens), Mrs Crosio (from 44 citizens), Mr McClelland (from 72 citizens), Mr Melham (from 49 citizens), and Mr Mutch (from 30 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Crosio, Janice, MP; Mutch, Stephen, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Provider Numbers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of NSW draws to the attention of the House that we the undersigned are totally opposed to the restriction of issuing of provider numbers to registered doctors unless they have entered a recognised training program, are vocationally registered or are a qualified specialist. We consider that such an action would cause serious suffering, including a severe disadvantage to women and rural communities and medical research. We believe that it is the essential right of all Australian registered doctors to have access to provider numbers that allow them to provide services which can attract Medicare rebates. We believe that such restrictions are an attack on the most defenceless and vulnerable strata of the medical profession and will not achieve the projected savings which it purports to do. We consider it to be a denial of natural justice, an attack on Medicare and un‐Australian.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

Call upon the Federal Minister for Health the Hon. Michael Wooldridge MP, to enter into meaningful discussions with representatives of those groups most affected by the harsh and unconscionable decisions of his government.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Crosio (from 20 citizens)and Mr Mutch (from 40 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Tanner, Lindsay, MP; Worth, Trish, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Provider Numbers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the Government's intention to legislate to restrict the issuing of Medicare provider numbers to doctors.

We consider that such an action would cause serious suffering, including a severe disadvantage to women and rural communities and medical research. We believe that it is the essential right of all Australian registered doctors to have access to provider numbers that allow them to provide services to the community which can attract Medicare rebates for patients. We believe that the proposed restrictions are an attack on the most defenceless and vulnerable strata of the medical profession. We consider it to be a denial of natural justice, and an attack on Medicare.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives to:

Call upon the Federal Minister for Health the Hon. Michael Wooldridge MP, to not proceed with the proposed restrictions on the provision of Medicare provider numbers to doctors and to enter into discussions with representatives of the medical profession to identify alternative measures to resolve the problems facing Medicare and the Australian medical workforce.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Tanner (from 19 citizens)and Ms Worth (from 1,963 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office: Marrickville
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the opposition of residents of the electorate of Grayndler to the closure of the Marrickville Medicare office.
We are concerned that many residents will not be able to access the services currently provided. We are also concerned about the privacy of residents if these services are contracted out.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to ensure the Marrickville office of Medicare remains open.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This is the petition of certain electors of the Division of Richmond, in particular the families of children who attend Pippies Early Childhood Centre, a Community Based Rural Multipurpose Centre.
We draw attention to the matters of:
1. The rumoured cessation of Operational Subsidy to Community based Long Day Care Centres
2. The rumoured changes in Administration of Childcare Assistance
3. The rumoured changes in funding which will affect the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System
We the petitioners therefore request the House to:
1. Continue the Operational Subsidy
2. Maintain payment of Childcare Assistance direct to the centres at the current levels.
3. Expand the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System to all sectors of the childcare industry.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House proposed changes to Child Care in the 20th August Federal Budget.

PARA.TAB: Operational Subsidy to be removed completely or drastically reduced.
Childcare Assistance to be abolished and amalgamated into one family payment.
Childcare Assistance eligibility level and fee ceiling to be lowered.
Childcare Cash Rebate to be abolished.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request the House to not consider these changes as it will create real hardship for low income families.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain parents and staff of a Long Day Care Community Children's Centre draws to the attention of the House Federal Government 20th August Budget Cuts to Child Care.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to

PARA.TAB: Keep operational subsidy for community centres
Maintain child care assistance

TAB.TAB: maintenance of existing levels of Child Care Assistance
continuation of the current method of payment through services

PARA.TAB: Maintain national government responsibility for the provision of high quality, affordable and accessible childcare places for all families.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the Australian Capital Territory, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and Victoria draws to the attention of the House their concerns regarding cuts and changes to child care spending by the Federal Coalition Government in its August 1996 Budget.

In particular these include: the withdrawal of the operational subsidy for community based child care centres; the imposition of a 50 hour limit on child care assistance; the abolition of 5,500 new child care places and the introduction of an option for families to have child care assistance paid directly to them rather than to the service.

These cuts will adversely affect families and children by eroding equitable access to quality child care and protection. Reducing this access will also mean that many good quality, community‐based services will become unviable.
Your petitioners request that the House:

PARA.TAB: Reinstate the operation subsidy for all community‐based services
Remove the 50 hour limit on child care assistance
Reinstate the 5,500 community‐based child care places
Ensure that child care assistance payments are made directly to services
Reinstate the $30.00 Disregard for Family Income Assessment for Child Care Assistance.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia.
This petition of certain residents in the State of Queensland expresses concern at the Federal Government's recent decision to cut funding to the ABC by $65 million over two years.
