This decision will severely compromise the role of the ABC as an independent, non‐commercial source of news, sport, information and entertainment. The ABC is a widely respected Australian institution, recognised as a service committed to quality and excellence in broadcasting.
The funding cuts which have been announced are the largest ever to the ABC since it was formed in 1932.

This decision contrasts completely with a commitment given by Prime Minister, John Howard, and Communications and the Arts Minister, Senator Richard Alston, prior to the election in March 1996. It was then promised that "The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC."
We request the House to call on the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to stand by their pre‐election commitment, and rescind its recent decision to slash funding to the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House:

PARA.TAB: that a discontinuation of capital funding to public and community housing providers will not lead to an expansion of housing in Queensland for those in housing need.
that a move to rent subsidies will cause an increase in rents to:

TAB.TAB: existing tenants of community housing, particularly those in high rent areas.
people on low incomes who are not in receipt of Social Security benefits—`Aussie Battlers'.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners request that the House:

1. delay the implementation of the reforms endorsed by COAG to Commonwealth/State responsibilities with regard to housing assistance in order to allow sufficient time for discussion of implications to community housing and of the most effective transitional arrangements.
2. hold members of the Coalition to their pre‐election commitment that the reform to housing assistance would not disadvantage existing public and community housing tenants.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Employment Service and Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors of the Division of McPherson draws to the attention of the House that the facilities of the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security situated in the suburb of Palm Beach, City of Gold Coast, Queensland, are quite unsuitable for that suburb. The existence of the facilities and congestion caused by patrons are causing problems, inconvenience, nuisance and distress to residents and are materially detracting from the amenity of the area.
Your petitioners respectfully urge the House to persuade the relevant Commonwealth Departments to relocate the said facilities to a more suitable location elsewhere than in the suburb of Palm Beach.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the decision by the Federal Government to abolish operational subsidies for community long‐day child care centres will result in huge fee increases for parents making it difficult for many Australian families to continue to use long‐day care.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to overturn this decision and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Migrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Sydney calls to the attention of the House that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has removed the ability of permanent residents of Australia to sponsor family members wishing to migrate to Australia. This decision unfairly discriminates against permanent residents of this country particularly in circumstances where they may have experienced some delay or difficulty in obtaining Australian citizenship and could result in the separation of close family members for periods exceeding two years.

Your petitioners therefore request the house to direct the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to forthwith revoke his decision to remove the ability for permanent residents to sponsor family members wishing to migrate to Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Migration Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Sydney calls to the attention of the House that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has increased fees for all offshore and onshore family visa classes for the 1996/97 financial year including: spouse, prospective marriage, parent, preferential family, interdependency, skilled and family. This decision will cause significant hardship to a number of people including less well off families who will have difficulty in meeting the costs of applications particularly in circumstances where the application fee may well be sacrificed if the application is unsuccessful.
Your petitioners therefore request the house to direct the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to forthwith revoke his decision to impose such additional migration fees.

PETITION.TITLE: Migrant Visas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Sydney calls to the attention of the House that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has stated that a cap will be imposed upon certain family visa classes for the 1996/97 financial year including: prospective marriage, parent, preferential family and interdependency. This decision will cause significant hardship to a number of families as it will arbitrarily prevent any more visas being issued irrespective of the merits of the application once the capped figure has been reached.

Your petitioners therefore request the house to direct the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to forthwith revoke his decision to impose such caps and to consider all applications for family visas on their merits.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of the certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House that:

1. The Coalition's decision to means test the Childcare Cash Rebate discriminates against working parents and is a breach of a pre‐election promise, where the Coalition's policy clearly stated `We are committed to maintaining a non means tested Childcare Cash Rebate';

2. The Coalition's decision to abolish operational subsidies for community based long day care centres will result in these centres having to charge higher fees, which will again discriminate against working parents; and

3. The Coalition's changes to the income test for Childcare Assistance will mean that the majority of parents pay far more in increased child care costs than provided through the Family Tax Initiative.
Your Petitioners request that the House:
1. exert pressure on Members of the Coalition to reverse the outcomes of the 1996 Federal Budget in relation to child care;
2. hold Members of the Coalition to their pre‐election commitments to retain the former system of child care; and
3. vote against legislation given effect to these changes which are to the detriment of Australian families.

PETITION.TITLE: Migrants: English Classes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain residents of New South Wales draws the attention of the House to the following:
(1) There has been an approximately 80% cut in the AMES English classes funded by the Department of Education and Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA) this year.

Over 133 classes have closed in NSW and about 2000 students have lost access to English classes. AMES Wollongong is no longer running any classes and the number of AMES Rockdale classes in the St George area has fallen from 18 classes to 3 classes.

We believe that these classes are essential for migrants to access formal mainstream education and training or find work. The cuts to English classes under Labour Market Programs have already affected thousands of migrants.

(2) Migrants are entitled to 510 hours of English funded by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) but this is often insufficient to achieve a functional level of English. Without the option of accessing DEETYA funded English classes after their 510 hours, these migrants are condemned to long‐term unemployment.
We request the House to restore funding to DEETYA English classes to 1995 levels and abolish the 510 hour limit for DIMA funded English classes.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take heed of our request.

PETITION.TITLE: Migrants: English Classes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain residents of Sydney draws the attention of the House that:
(1) There has been an approximately 80% cut in the AMES English classes funded by the Department of Education and Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA) this year.

Over 133 classes have closed in NSW and about 2000 students have lost access to English classes. AMES Wollongong is no longer running any classes and the number of AMES Rockdale classes in the St George area has fallen from 18 classes to 3 classes.

These classes are essential for migrants to access formal mainstream education and training or find work. The cuts to English classes under Labour Market Programs have already affected thousands of migrants, and.

(2) Migrants are entitled to 510 hours of English funded by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) but this is often insufficient to achieve a functional level of English. Without the option of accessing DEETYA funded English classes after their 510 hours, these migrants are condemned to long‐term unemployment.
Your petitioners request that the House:
Restores the funding to DEETYA English classes to 1995 levels and abolishes the 510 hour limit for DIMA funded English classes.

PETITION.TITLE: Holsworthy Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the proposal to use the Holsworthy military range as a possible site for the building of Sydney's second international airport.
We believe that the site is unsuitable due to:
its proximity to large and rapidly growing residential areas;
the presence of unexploded ammunition on site;
the expense involved due to necessary landfill to make the site suitable for development;
the existent noise pollution in the area already suffered by residents which would only be increased under the new proposal;
the area's importance in maintaining high quality air and water for South Western Sydney;
the presence of rare and endangered species of flora and fauna and significant examples of Aboriginal and early European cultural heritage.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House oppose the newly proposed site of Holsworthy for Sydney's second international airport.

PETITION.TITLE: Holsworthy Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the proposal to use the Holsworthy military range as a possible site for the building of Sydney's second international airport.
We believe that the site is unsuitable due to:
its proximity to large and rapidly growing residential areas;
the presence of unexploded ammunition on site;
the expense involved due to necessary landfill to make the site suitable for development;
the existent noise pollution in the area already suffered by residents which would only be increased under the new proposal.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House oppose the newly proposed site of Holsworthy for Sydney's second international airport.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House that the Honourable the Minister for Communications has foreshadowed presenting to the House Appropriation Bills which will substantially reduce the funding appropriated by the Parliament to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. This reduction will greatly damage the nature of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House resolves to maintain the funding appropriated to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation at the current real level.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain students, teachers, and parents of students of the state of Tasmania, draws to the attention of the House that the additional rises in the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) will mean a decline in students seeking tertiary education, and senior secondary education. Your petitioners therefore pray that the House should dismiss this new legislation in regards to HECS and revert to the previous legislation.
Is Australia still the land of opportunity? We are the future!

PETITION.TITLE: Euthanasia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the house that euthanasia is the actual intervention by another to end a human life. It is neither curing nor a therapy. It destroys a human life.
Your petitioners therefore request the house to:
(a) recognise that euthanasia is not an issue which can be dealt with adequately by the State or Territories;
(b) listen to the public, doctors, health carers and religious organisations who are against euthanasia;
(c) legislate to prevent euthanasia being carried out in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Munjuwa Queanbeyan Aboriginal Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Federal Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory bring to the attention of the House that due to funding cuts through the Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander Commission, the Munjuwa Queanbeyan Aboriginal Corporation will be forced to close unless alternative funding can be obtained.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to support and assist the Corporation to obtain alternative funding to enable the Corporation to continue to provide the multi‐services needed for the Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander communities of Queanbeyan and surrounding areas.

PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows that:

We believe that the traditional Christian view of the family unit excludes anything other than a male and female, living in a lawful marriage relationship, along with their children, and that it is necessary for this to be restated by our political leaders.
We reaffirm our belief in the traditional Christian view of marriage as God's holy institution in which male and female become one flesh. (Genesis 2.24; Matthew 19.5,6)

We reaffirm that God is the author of marriage, and has restricted it to the union of male with female and that such marriage between male and female is commended in Scripture as honourable among all. (Ephesians 5.15‐23)
We reaffirm that such marriage between male and female is ordained for life‐long companionship, help and comfort which husband and wife ought to have of each other. (Romans 7.2,3)

We reaffirm that children are a heritage of the Lord and should be nurtured in a godly home, and that human society can be strong and happy only where the marriage bond is held in honour. (Psalm 127.3)

We reaffirm that incestuous marriages can never be made lawful by the law of any man or government, or the consent of parties, so as to allow those people to live together as married couples. (Mark 6.18; Leviticus 18.6‐28)

We reaffirm that, according to Biblical law, it is forbidden for a male to practise sexual intercourse with another male, or for a female with a female, and that since this is an abomination before the Lord, such as a prohibited relationship for marriage. (Leviticus 18.22; 20.13)
We believe the entire stability and well being of our society depends on maintaining this traditional Christian view of marriage and family (Leviticus 20.15‐16; 18.23‐24)
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should call on the Government to:
(a) Preserve completely intact the exclusiveness of marriage as being one male and one female.
(b) That the definition of a prohibited relationship in the Marriage Act 1961, Part III 23(2) be amended with the addition of a new clause (c) so that it reads as follows:
(2) Marriages of parties within a prohibited relationship are marriages—
(a) between a person and an ancestor or descendant of the person; or
(b) between a brother and a sister (whether of the whole blood or the half blood); or
(c) between a male and a male or between a female and a female.
Your Petitioners humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned electors of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the catastrophic implications to the lives of children and their families that will occur if changes to the current Children's Services Program, proposed in the Federal Audit Commission Report and the EPAC Interim Report, are adopted.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:
Maintain existing levels of Child Care Assistance
Continue payments of Child Care Assistance through services
Retain Operational Subsidies to all community based service types
Retain the benefits of the Cash Rebate for middle income earners
Maintain a National System of Quality Assurance
Extend Quality Assurance to all formal service types
Continue the Federal Government responsibility for Children's Services
Your petitioners therefore ask the House not to pass legislation that will in any way risk the loss of existing quality, affordable child care options for families.

BREAK.PARA: Petitions received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek indulgence to state the opposition's position on the question of the House adjourning for the Melbourne Cup tomorrow.
—Proceed.

—The Deputy Leader of the House (Mr McGauran) appeared to be under something of a misapprehension when he said this matter had been the subject of discussion and agreement with the opposition. It appears to be the case that there has certainly been no formal discussion and considerable uncertainty as to what informal discussion there may have been at an officers' level, not at members' level.

SPEECH.PARA: In the circumstances, may I state shortly that our position is that we would be deeply unhappy at anything which curtailed question time taking its full, normal and natural course and that, while there may or may not be a case for stopping the parliament briefly while the rest of the country has stopped for the running of the race, our view would be that a half‐hour adjournment was unnecessary, particularly if it were to cut into what would otherwise be the scope of question time and given the pressures allegedly upon the business of this House. We believe there is a need for some further discussion between the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) and others, and we hope this can be the subject of further report back later this day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House:
(1) notes the high level of community concern in the Greater Western Sydney region over the proposed construction of a second international airport at Badgerys Creek;
(2) acknowledges that the Sydney basin has a finite population capacity and it is clearly approaching its limits for absorbing air and water pollution;

(3) recognises that building a second international airport, either at Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy, inside the Sydney basin will subject hundreds of thousands of people to the same, if not worse, environmental and lifestyle problems which have already beset the residents surrounding Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport;

(4) calls on the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to initiate an Environmental Impact Study on Goulburn as a site for an international airport, to run in conjunction with the current studies on the Holsworthy and Badgerys Creek airport sites;

(5) calls on the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to commission a study into the economic and social benefits for the Southern Highlands region in building an international airport at Goulburn serviced by a `very fast train' of the kind currently in operation, or being considered for operation, in Europe; and

(6) conducts an inquiry through the relevant parliamentary standing committee into the viability of, and the benefits associated with, the operation of a `very fast train' linking Sydney and Canberra, and its capacity to act as the main conduit for passengers and freight between Sydney and an international airport situated at Goulburn.

I am speaking again today on Badgerys Creek because I refuse to let the issue slip quietly away into the night. I refuse to let it be put on the political backburner where certain people, for reasons known only to themselves, will keep it in the hope that it slips from the collective minds of the public in Sydney's west.

We have many concerns in western Sydney. We worry about employment—or the lack of it—business growth, family dislocation, social services and welfare. When we have time, we also worry about the spectre of an international airport operating at Badgerys Creek. The people of western Sydney are deeply concerned about Badgerys Creek, and similarly with Holsworthy. After the third runway debacle at Kingsford Smith, they view any talk of EISs with a thoroughly jaundiced eye.

Government assurances of environmental safety, whether they be from a Labor or a coalition government, are seen as admissions from the powers that be that they know something is wrong. It is cynical, but true: this is the reality as I find it in western Sydney. When the decision was made to build Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek in 1985, a few people, like me, raised their voices seeking answers to what troubled us most about the development. That number has only grown larger over the years.

We were wary of what toll such an airport would take on our lifestyles and on our family's lifestyles. However, we were informed by the authorities that nothing would go wrong at Badgerys Creek and that all the relevant steps would be taken so that the airport's environmental and social impact on our communities would be kept to a minimum. The Kingsford Smith third runway debacle did nothing to alleviate our fears, nor did it instil in us any confidence in what the authorities were telling us. In western Sydney we felt from both sides of politics a genuine lack of understanding of the way people were feeling in Sydney's west about Badgerys Creek.

Over the same time it became apparent that Sydney's capacity for absorbing air and water pollution had reached its limit. Asthma rates were up in Sydney's west. Scientific models show how the air pollution of the entire city travels west each day, settling on our heads causing the health problems we know about and heaven knows what else we do not know about.

The people of western Sydney know in their hearts that a fully‐fledged international airport of the kind now being envisaged by the coalition—360,000‐plus flight movements and 13 million passengers per year—can never operate on their doorstep without devastating social and environmental effects. They felt the same way about an airport of the magnitude suggested by the Labor government when it was in power—270,000 flight movements per year. They know this to be the case whether the airport is situated at either Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy. The question now is: what can be done to make those in control of the decision making process sit up and take notice of our fears and concerns?

The coalition came to power promising to listen to the people of Australia. They spent the entire campaign in Lindsay talking about how they were a government which listened to the people of western Sydney. Yet the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), is not listening to the people of my community and the people from the western Sydney area who are saying, `No, we don't want an international airport built next door to us. No, we don't want to have jumbo jets screaming over our homes 24 hours a day.'

If he were listening, he would be acting. If the member for Hume and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) really wanted to listen to the people and if they really wanted to act in the best interests of the voters from the west, they would swallow their pride and take a serious look at what other opportunities there are in relation to Sydney's second airport.

The idea of building an international airport at Goulburn seemed ludicrous in 1985. To put forward the notion of constructing Sydney's second airport close to two hours drive away with little or no transport infrastructure to support it would have been to invite ridicule but, over the last 11 years, the story has changed somewhat. Spiralling pollution levels in the Sydney basin combined with our burgeoning population should signal to any sane individual that the time for building an international airport within 50 kilometres of Sydney's city centre has passed. We missed the opportunity 10 years ago and there is no chance that we can reclaim it now.

The story has changed in that we now also have the prospect of the very fast train link going into operation between Sydney and Canberra some time in the near future, which could be easily routed to run through Goulburn. That would negate the strongest argument against that town being chosen as the general site for Sydney's second airport. That argument at the time was its distance from Sydney.

Whichever fast train option is decided upon—be it Speedrail's TGV model or Transrapid's Maglev train—we are looking at a transport system which would cut down the travelling time between Sydney and Goulburn to 45 minutes. Forty‐five minutes is the time it presently takes to travel from London's Heathrow Airport to that city's centre on the tube—a journey made by thousands of people every day, day in and day out, and hundreds of thousands a year without any hiccups whatsoever. Forty‐five minutes is less time than it would take an individual to travel on City Rail from Badgerys Creek to the centre of Sydney—we have not got a line there at the moment. It takes more than 45 minutes for my constituents to travel from my electorate office in Fairfield to the Sydney CBD.

Distance and travelling time from an airport at Goulburn to Sydney is therefore no longer an issue with the operation of the very fast train. In the process, the argument against Goulburn being at least considered—and that is what I am asking for, consideration—as a site fades into the ether, and that is what we should be on about.

That people can still continue to be so short-sighted and single-minded as to insist that either Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy are reasonable options for an international airport faced with what information we have is not only frustrating but downright dangerous. It is an admission they do not care about inflicting an environmental disaster on a section of the Australian population which has already borne and continues to bear more than its fair share of social and environmental inequities.

Goulburn has the capacity for site development as the airport's demand grows in the future. Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy do not. Goulburn has none of the population pressures associated with Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy. Goulburn is a safer environmental alternative than either Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy. Goulburn can be operated 24 hours a day without the devastating effects that such an operation would have on the people surrounding Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy. Lastly—and this is really the killer point—Goulburn, as a site for Sydney's second international airport, has the widespread public approval of people living in the city of Goulburn. Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy do not.

An airport at Goulburn would mean jobs, infrastructure and economic development for the people of the Southern Highlands, just as the very fast train would mean the same. If the government can consider Holsworthy, one of the least attractive options in the original 1985 EIS, when faced with the information we now have and faced with the population and pollution problems that besiege us now in Sydney, then surely it can show enough judgment to carry out another EIS into the Goulburn site—an EIS based on the premise that the very fast train service will be in operation by the time the airport is finally built.

At the same time as an EIS is being carried out on Goulburn we should look into the capacity of the very fast train to act as the main conduit for passengers and freight between the airport there and Sydney. The very fast train project has received warm approval from both sides of politics at state and federal levels. Now all we need is the political will and the political courage to take the next steps.

I may be accused of parochialism in my stance on Badgerys Creek, but once again I make it clear to this House that I am just as vehemently opposed to an international airport being built at Holsworthy. I expect to be accused of being a NIMBY by the same people who have the small-mindedness to insist that an airport at Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy can fly.

I want not only what is best for my community but what is best for Sydney and what is best for our region as a whole. Can those who follow me speaking on this motion today say the same? Not only do I not want an airport in my backyard, I do not want an airport in the backyards of the members for Werriwa (Mr Latham), Hughes (Mrs Vale) or Banks (Mr Melham). I want an international airport where it should go—outside the Sydney basin, where it will alleviate the concerns of my constituents and the concerns of the constituents of the members for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton) and Barton (Mr McClelland), just to name a few.

An airport at Goulburn built in conjunction with the very fast train is a win-win situation. It will avoid the further environmental degradation of our biggest city while injecting a much needed economic shot in the arm for the Southern Highlands. Why can we not see that? Why are we just so short-sighted in this regard?

Goulburn is the place for an international airport 25 to 50 years down the track—not just for the Olympics, not just for the short term. Forty‐five minutes is a short time now. In 25 or 50 years time it will be even less. In 25 to 50 years time Goulburn will be less of a satellite city to Sydney than it is now becoming. It will be an outlying suburb, for goodness sake. In 25 to 50 years we will be patting ourselves on the back for having the foresight and the fortitude not only to make the hard decisions, but to make the right decisions.

In this House we talk about leaving economic debts to our children. Let us not leave them the environmental and social debts of our actions by making a mistake over our choice for Sydney's second airport. We have made too many errors on airports over the years. Let us not repeat this.

I call on all members concerned with this issue to join in the spirit of bipartisanship that has entered this House over the last few days, especially with the previous debate with the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). Let us put away the political knives. Let us take off the blinkers and inject some clear thinking and reason into this debate while we still have the time.

That is why I have said in the motion I have moved that, if we are going to take any account of where a future airport in this great nation should be sited, particularly in the state of New South Wales, then let us give consideration to where growth is going to be, where environmentally it will be a sound a decision and, most importantly, where the people of the area would welcome it and we will not be forever polluting the Sydney basin, which now has reached its capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The underlying intention of the motion moved by the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) is, without doubt, to limit Sydney to the one international airport—that is, KSA—which will soon be approaching maximum capacity. I am astonished that the honourable member for Prospect was able to get this motion through her caucus. At least I am assuming that she got the motion through caucus. If she has done it without caucus approval, then I expect all her Labor colleagues whose electorates are currently noise affected to publicly dissociate themselves from this motion. If not, then I will make sure that their constituents know of their acquiescence to this motion that is intended to limit Sydney to one international airport.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is the case that the honourable member put this forward without caucus approval, I would expect the ALP members whose electorates are noise affected to rebuke their colleague the honourable member for Prospect as part of their contribution to this debate. No matter whether the former or the latter is the case, the fact is that the Labor members on the other side will definitely have to be into each other about this motion. It will be a very interesting half hour indeed.

It is important that this parliament notes, once again, the fact that half a million Sydney residents, if not more, are being subjected to intolerable levels of aircraft noise and pollution because of the prevarication for more than 10 years by the former Labor government in getting on with the task of building a new international airport.

More than 10 years ago, the Hawke government selected Badgerys Creek as the site for the new international airport. I will not go into all the details in the short space of time available to me. However, what I will say is that the bumbling delays by the former government would be almost comical were it not such a serious matter affecting the health and wellbeing of more than half a million Sydney residents who have continued to suffer and who, regrettably, will have to continue to suffer because a new Sydney international airport is still some years away.

The coalition government is getting on with the job of selecting the most suitable site and building the new airport as soon as possible, as soon as feasible. The land at Badgerys Creek has now been purchased and Badgerys Creek remains the government's preferred site subject to a satisfactory EIS. The land at Holsworthy is Commonwealth property and the government has actioned a parallel EIS for Holsworthy in the event that the EIS for Badgerys Creek proves to be unsatisfactory for whatever reason. Both EISs will be transparent and in keeping with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise.
The work on the two EISs is well advanced and the cost is very substantial—some $21 million has been allocated in this year's budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The honourable member says, `Rubbish!' If the honourable member had looked the matter up in the budget papers, she would have seen that approximately $11 million has been provided for the two EISs and $8 million has been provided for the purchase of the additional properties required to complete the land purchase at Badgerys Creek. It is therefore astounding that the honourable member for Prospect comes into this parliament and puts forward the motion we are now debating, which is intended to cause further delays in the choice of, and commencement of the building of, the new international airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Prospect plucks a place out of the air and says, `Why not a new international airport at, say, Goulburn?' Why does the honourable member stop at Goulburn? Why not throw in Wilton, Richmond, Newcastle and Wollongong? I have rarely come across such confused thinking and continual shooting from the hip as the honourable member for Prospect has exhibited and continues to exhibit.

On 29 May in this House, the honourable member said, `I am particularly concerned by the announcement that a second EIS will be done.' These are her exact words taken out of Hansard. Four months later, she gets up in this place and says, `Never mind a second EIS. I want a third EIS, as well—and you pay for it, and pick Goulburn as an example!'

The honourable member for Prospect seems to be claiming an expertise in the issue of picking a suitable airport site or, at the very least, she knew or she should have known that Goulburn was considered in 1985 with nine other sites but was quickly rejected as unsuitable for several reasons, not the least of which was its great distance from Sydney.

The honourable member mentions in a motion that a very fast train service will solve the distance problems to Sydney. What she does not say is that the cost of the VFT is in the vicinity of $2½ billion—that is $2,500 million. On top of all that, she says absolutely nothing of the cost involved for that return trip from Sydney to Goulburn—in the vicinity of $170 per person return. A family of three will have to pay more than $500 to see someone off and to come back to Sydney.

Additionally, the honourable member knew or should have known the fact, as was stated when Goulburn was looked at as a possible site, that the Goulburn area is fogbound for 50 days of the year. In other words, if there is to be an international airport—which just will not happen in Goulburn—she will be restricting the use of Goulburn airport by one-seventh of the year because it is fogbound.

The fact is that, if Goulburn were picked, it would quickly fall into disuse. The airlines just will not go there, for all the reasons that I have mentioned. That will cause a tremendous pressure to fall on Sydney airport which has a cap now of 80 movements a hour. The pressure will be such that a government, no matter what government, will have to consider lifting the cap, otherwise Sydney airport will just close down. How many movements an hour at Sydney airport does the honourable member for Prospect want—80, 100, 120, 160? Is that what she wants to subject the people of Sydney to?

The fact is that, if Goulburn were to be picked as the second international airport, the pressure of these delays on Sydney airport—if it were to be considered, after which no doubt it will be rejected—will force Sydney airport into being a 24‐hour airport, otherwise we in Sydney will not be able to cope. That is just unacceptable to the residents of Sydney. The honourable member for Prospect has not thought through the implications of her motion. I am certain that members of both sides of the House will treat this motion with the disdain it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) for bringing this motion before the House. I commend her for two reasons: first, she has highlighted the government's mismanagement of the second airport issue; and, secondly, she has posed the valid question that, if it is good enough for Holsworthy to be considered as an alternative to Badgerys Creek, why is it not good enough for Goulburn? If it is good enough for Holsworthy to be considered as the alternative airport site, why is it not good enough for the other eight sites that were considered in 1986—everything from Richmond through to Goulburn? I recoil with surprise to hear the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) talking about delays. I recoil with surprise when I consider his cant and hypocrisy in talking about delays.
—Ha, ha!
—The member for Mitchell scoffs at the idea that under this government there will be a 10-year delay in the construction of the second airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) throws his head back with surprise. But what he should do right now is march up to the office of the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, Mrs Bishop, and ask her why she issued the following letter to a constituent of mine who resides in Minto Heights. That constituent was writing to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel asking, if the government were to proceed with an airport at Holsworthy, what would happen to the $30 million construction of the new army hospital at Holsworthy—a hospital that has been relocated out of Ingleburn in my electorate to the electorate of the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale). This is what the office of the minister replied:
If Holsworthy is selected as the site for the second airport, then the hospital would be relocated.
She went on:
This would not be necessary until the airport was operational, which would not be for about 10 years.

There it is from a minister in this Howard government, saying to one of my constituents that, if the airport is to be built at Holsworthy and the hospital needs to be relocated, it will not happen `until the airport was operational, which would not be for about 10 years'.

There is a 10-year delay under this government in the construction of the second airport. So, if the member for Lowe has a concern about aircraft noise for his constituents, if he has a concern about aircraft noise around Mascot, he should go back to his constituents and tell them that there will be no relief under the policies of the Howard government for 10 years and the source of that is the office of one of the ministers who has responsibility. The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, who has all those Holsworthy considerations on her plate, has announced in this letter, which I will seek leave to table, that the second airport will not be built for 10 years.

During that decade there will be time to have another five studies into Holsworthy, another five studies into Goulburn and another five studies or more into Richmond. With a 10-year delay, there is time for study after study after study. So why the rush to put the fix on to have this airport constructed at Holsworthy in the electorate of the member for Hughes or, in the event of the government still being keen, at Badgerys Creek? Why the rush? Why the haste? Why the fix to do all this so quickly if you have a minister out of her office announcing that it will be 10 years until it is built?

I challenge the member for Lowe to take this letter back and letterbox it throughout his electorate and surrounding constituencies to let them know that government policy is not to build the second airport for a decade. I challenge the member for Hughes, who is in the chamber, to take this letter to her constituents and ask why there is a need for an EIS within the next six months if the airport will not be operational for another 10 years. Why the rush into Holsworthy if government policy is not to do anything about this for 10 years? I challenge the member for North Sydney to go back to his consultative committee—his gerrymandered, rigged consultative committee—and ask them how serious the government is to do something about aircraft noise in the inner city, when Mrs Bishop has announced in this letter to my constituent that nothing will change for a decade?

The mismanagement, the cant, the hypocrisy, the misguided fools on the government side who cannot get their thinking and their policy straight on this issue! This is, of course, a government led by someone who conned the people of Holsworthy. There was a 12-month debate about aircraft noise in Sydney, and not for a moment did the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) mention, in a word or a whisper, Holsworthy. A few weeks after the election, all of a sudden there is the need for an EIS into Holsworthy.

The member for Prospect has put the very sensible proposition: if it is good enough for Holsworthy, it is good enough for Goulburn. If it is good enough for Holsworthy, it is good enough for the other eight sites that were considered in 1986. There is no rush; there is no fast tracking. We have 10 years to get this right, under the schedule announced by Mrs Bishop. So the motion is a good one in the context of this government's delays.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Werriwa has posed certain questions across the chamber in regard to the letter purportedly sent by the minister.
—I will table it.
—I am not asking you to table it.
—Could you please get to your point of order?
—There is a very big difference between `operational' and `fully operational to maximum use'.
—There is no point of order.
—I seek leave to table the letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) for placing this motion on the Notice Paper because she has provided me with an opportunity to debunk some of the myths that have been sprouted around the Sydney basin by the ALP on this particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it somewhat ironic that the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has got up to second the motion put forward by the member for Prospect. The old right‐wing mates are coming in again saying, `We're standing right behind you when it counts,' in exactly the same way the member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), the former member for Barton and the other right‐wing mates stood right behind the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and his predecessor and the member for Sydney (Mr Peter Baldwin) when it came to the new flight paths over Sydney.

They put the flight paths, they put the planes, over the people who vote Labor in the first instance, not the people who vote Liberal. They did them over. This is a classic case of an issue where the right wing of the Australian Labor Party is doing over the left wing of the Australian Labor Party in factional battles. And the big losers are unquestionably the half a million people affected by aircraft noise in Sydney. We have had a number of instances where the ALP has sacrificed people in the Sydney basin for their greater factional battles. There has been no issue more significant—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the honourable member for Werriwa said that he wanted to table the letter. I understand he tabled the letter and then he took it away. Has the clerk got the letter?
—It has been tabled. Resume your seat.

—The ALP's factional battles take precedence over the welfare of the people of Sydney. There is no example more obvious than where the great deal of the 1980s was done. That great deal—we all know about it—was when Bob Hawke could not get the third runway through caucus. So what did he do? He went to his mates. He went to the former member for Barton and he went to the member for Kingsford‐Smith and said, `Let's do a deal. You give me the third runway and I'll close the east‐west. I won't put any planes over you.' It was at that particular caucus meeting and the cabinet meeting before it when the ALP sold out the people of Sydney. There is no doubt about that. They sold them out.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, my point of order is very precise. If the honourable member for North Sydney had read my motion, he would see there is nothing here on flight paths, nothing here on caucuses, nothing here on Bob Hawke or on factions. What I do see is another alternative being put up. If the honourable member cannot speak on that, I ask him to reread the motion. I am pleased that the honourable member for Lowe has a copy of the letter now.
—There is no point of order.

—I am glad to see that finally the truth is coming out and it is getting under the skin of the member for Prospect. If she should be turning her considerable guns anywhere, it should be towards the member for Kingsford‐Smith. The member for Kingsford‐Smith sold out the people of Sydney when it came to the second airport in the same way he sold out the people of Sydney in relation to the third runway.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the ALP that said that Badgerys Creek should only be an overflow airport. It was the ALP that said that Badgerys Creek should have no more than 275,000 movements representing 13 million people. I have news for you. Sydney airport is currently operating at 18 million passengers a year or 260,000 movements and by 2010 it will have 36 million passengers a year or around 500,000 movements.

BREAK.PARA: What that says is that the ALP never really believed in Sydney's second international airport. Only this side of the House, only the Liberal Party, has been going to the people and asking, `What do you want?' The overwhelming view coming back has been, `We want a second international airport for Sydney.'

It is as logical to build an airport at Goulburn as it is to build an airport on Deimos—a moon that circumnavigates Mars. Two hundred and ten kilometres from Sydney: that is a hell of a long avgas pipeline. That is a pipeline that goes from Kurnell to provide the avgas that is going to run the considerable number of planes that will be running out of a second international airport. Every jumbo requires 14 tankers of avgas. How are you going to do that? Put it on a very fast train? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: during the debate the honourable member for Werriwa said that he had in his possession a letter from the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. That is absolutely wrong. He has misled the House. It is not from the minister; it is from the minister's adviser.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: I am sure the honourable member knows that if he wishes to move a charge of such magnitude against another member in this place he must do so by way of a substantive motion.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: I think you will find that the Hansard record will show that the honourable member for Werriwa used the words `the office of the minister'.
—I did.
—Therefore, there is no point of order.

—I thank the honourable member for Chifley. There is no point of order. The time allotted for this debate has expired. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay, Alex, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) condemns the Government of Iraq and particularly President Saddam Hussein for his continued, constant and unwarranted aggression against the Kuwaiti people and their government;

(2) condemns the flagrant violations of human rights by the Government of Iraq in continuing to illegally hold hundreds of Kuwaiti citizens as prisoners of war since its abortive invasion of Kuwait in 1990; and
(3) urges the international community, through its representatives at the UN, to
(a) increase their efforts to achieve a lasting solution to the aggression of Iraq against its neighbours; and
(b) ensure the safe and speedy return of all prisoners of war held by the Government of Iraq.

Before I speak to the motion, I would like to mention Abdul Jannil Albaf at whose initiative the Kuwait‐Australia Parliamentary Friendship Group was formed. I congratulate Abdul on his efforts to keep us up to date on developments in Kuwait and to ensure that the plight of the Kuwaiti people, still suffering from Iraq's aggression, is not forgotten.

Long after war is over the horror continues. The horror of the Gulf War is still vivid around the globe, nowhere more than in the homes of thousands of Kuwaitis, but the aftermath of Saddam Hussein's aggression is far reaching and tragic.

The United States authorities are only now trying to track down 20,000 US soldiers who unknowingly may have been exposed to Iraq's chemical weapons during the war. The Kurdish people in northern Iraq are still literally fighting for their very existence. Many Iraqi civilians continue to mourn the loss of loved ones and suffer under Saddam Hussein's oppressive regime; but, as I said, nowhere is the pain of the aftermath of Iraq's aggression felt more than in the homes of the Kuwaiti families whose fathers, sons and brothers have simply vanished—vanished because the Iraq government refuses to comply with UN resolutions 686 and 687 and disclose their fate.

During their retreat in February 1991, the Iraqis took several thousand Kuwaiti prisoners and used them as a human shield. Many were later released, but there are about 630 Kuwaitis who have not been accounted for. The Kuwaiti people will continue to suffer for as long as the Iraqi government refuses to disclose either the fate or the location of these innocent people. They remain prisoners of war held by Iraq, and it is now 5½ years since the fighting in the gulf ended.

At this point I think it is appropriate to allude to Australia's involvement in the Gulf War. We committed Royal Australian Navy warships and supply vessels to the gulf in 1990. We openly condemned the invasion of Kuwait and the taking of hostages by the Iraqis. Following the liberation of Kuwait, Australian Defence Force personnel took part in mines disposal and Australian companies contributed to the postwar reconstruction of Kuwait. We must continue to offer support, continue to condemn Iraq for its actions and seek the release of these innocent Kuwaitis.

I have no hesitation in moving this motion condemning the government of Iraq and particularly Saddam Hussein for his continued aggression against the Kuwaiti people. I believe the hypocrisy of Saddam Hussein and his government has never been fully exposed. Only this month—again, 5½ years after the Iraqis were forced to retreat from the sovereign nation of Kuwait—Iraq has told the UN that economic sanctions threaten its society with a horrendous disaster that may lead to its collapse and has accused the United States of attempting genocide. In a memorandum to UN Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, Iraq claimed that the economic sanctions which ban the export of all and import of most goods except food, medicine and humanitarian items were part of a US plot to cripple Iraq. The memorandum states:

Iraq holds the United States fully responsible for the sufferings of the Iraqi people through its insistence on maintaining the economic embargo . . . there is no room for doubt that the United States is intentionally endeavouring to annihilate the Iraqi people.
It added:
. . . the civilised world has determined that genocide, whether committed in time of peace or war, is a crime under international law that must be prevented and punished.

Iraq is claiming that the sanctions are no longer justified since it has discharged its obligations under the relevant Security Council resolutions. Iraq is yet to satisfy a special UN commission that it has provided all details of its weapons programs. Let us not forget that it has failed to meet the requirements of the two UN resolutions I referred to earlier and disclose the fate or location of the Kuwaiti POWs. We must not forget these POWs. This House should urge the international community to pressure Iraq to ensure the safe return of these 360 innocent Kuwaitis to their homes.

Too often our focus on international incidents is limited to that which the media of the day deems newsworthy or good copy. Often we as governments and nations are prompted into action by overseas news reports of famine and war, but as each new atrocity is exposed governments and people unintentionally shift their focus. Let us not forget, therefore, the Gulf War, which was sparked by Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. Let us not forget the horrendous crimes which were committed by the Iraqi soldiers under the direction of Saddam Hussein. I quote George Bush in March 1991:

Newborn babies, thrown out of incubators and the incubators then shipped off to Baghdad. Dialysis patients, ripped from their machines and those machines then too, sent off to Baghdad. The story of two young kids passing out leaflets—Iraqi troops rounded up their parents and made them watch while these two kids were shot dead, executed, before their eyes.
George Bush went on to say:
Hitler revisited, but remember, when Hitler's war ended, there were the Nuremburg trials.
Finally, let us not forget the Kuwaitis still being held as prisoners of war by Iraqi forces. I urge the parliament to support this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Ted, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, with great pleasure. I would also like to congratulate the new chairman of the Kuwait‐Australia Parliamentary Friendship Group, my colleague Alex Somlyay. While we are on congratulations, I would also like to send congratulations to a very good friend of the association and a good friend of mine, Sheikh Salem, who, after the recent elections in Kuwait, has now taken up the high office of Deputy Prime Minister and defence minister in Kuwait. At the same time, he has retained his chairmanship of the Missing Persons Bureau, an appointment he has held since the end of the Kuwaiti war because of his interest and at the great expense, of course, of other important government positions. He has come back into the government again but retained his position as chairman. For those of you who might not know, he has devoted all of his time to travelling the world convincing people of the disaster that was Kuwait five or six years ago. He has discussed this subject in the UN and every other forum that he has been able to get access to.

SPEECH.PARA: It may not seem a big thing when you say `just over 600 people'—I have pointed this out to the parliament before—but if you equate 600 people to a very small national population of just over half a million people, you would soon deduce that nearly every home in Kuwait has been affected by the atrocious behaviour of Saddam Hussein. We are talking about missing people. I know this subject is not about me, but I remember during the war when one of my uncles went missing. I always remember my old Irish grandmother was in a terrible state, and the fact that he was missing was more of a blow to her and caused more anguish in the family than the fact that nobody was aware of what became of him. It is the same with these people.

Iraq is playing a silly war of nerves with Kuwait at the present time. On numerous occasions they have said that those people do not exist, and yet at other times they say, `Yes, they do exist, but not in the numbers that you say.' To add more confusion to the matter, in December last year, for some unknown reason, they released to Kuwait the dead body of one of the prisoners listed. On the one hand, they deny that prisoners exist; and the next thing is that they deliver the body of a prisoner who died in detention. And as recently as 15 May this year they actually released one prisoner. Confusion has been caused.

Obviously, Saddam Hussein is still smarting over the terrible hiding he got from Kuwait and her associate countries during the war. Of course, we should all be proud of the fact that Australia was involved in that terrible war.

The fact is that even as recently as 16 October 1996, at a meeting in Geneva regarding the missing people of the Kuwaiti war, the Iraqi delegation did not know anything. This is the stock answer that they keep giving. So it is confusion all round. Obviously, those people are there somewhere, and some of the information from people who have escaped from Iraq over the last four to five years has confirmed that yes, there are Kuwaiti prisoners of war there.

Getting information is not always easy, and that is where I would like to give my congratulations to Abdul Jannil Albaf. As the chairman of our committee meant to say, he formed the Kuwait‐Australia Friendship Group in Australia. Through association with that group, I became friendly with him and he encouraged me to form the parliamentary group of the same name here in Canberra, of which I was the inaugural chairman.

Without people like Abdul Jannil we would not get any information at all. He has been a great source of information to both myself and the group. A couple of years ago he initiated a program whereby Australian parliamentarians went to Kuwait to see first-hand the damage done to the country by the vandals from Iraq. That was a very good trip which was arranged by Abdul Jannil. He was also instrumental in inviting Sheikh Salem, who is now the Deputy Prime Minister and defence minister of Kuwait, to Australia 18 months to two years ago; and that was a very successful trip.

Personally, I think that Saddam Hussein should not be let off the hook under any circumstances whatsoever in his obligations to conform to the United Nations sanctions. As a matter of fact, we have gone a long way in allowing Iraq to sell some oil to alleviate some of the poverty in his country, but that is as far as we should go. As parliamentarians in Australia and as friends of Kuwait in the friendship group, we should never miss an opportunity to inform everybody we can through the world on our visits overseas of our position. When delegations visit Australia, we should never miss an opportunity to advise world politicians, and anybody who is willing to listen, of our position.

As the parliament would be aware, every year we have two parliamentarians attending the United Nations sessions in New York for a three‐month period. This year we have from the government the Hon. Bruce Reid and from the opposition the Hon. Ralph Willis, two very prominent politicians in Australia. I took the opportunity to advise them on the up-to-date situation in Kuwait and pleaded with them, while they were in New York, to lobby anybody that was in easy reach of them and to inform them of Australia's point of view. I also asked them to point out to anybody who might lobby for Saddam Hussein Iraq's responsibilities in conforming to the UN resolutions that have been passed on him over the past four years. I take great pleasure in seconding this motion and recommend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with the strongest conviction that I rise to support this motion put forward by the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) and seconded by the member for Fowler (Mr Ted Grace). I certainly commend them both for their action in this matter. Most of the world deplored the actions of the government in Baghdad for its 1990 act of aggression against Kuwait, and having visited Kuwait after its liberation I was still amazed at the wilful destruction that had taken place. It is a credit to the government of Kuwait that, in a short space of time, it has been able to restore most of the damage that was done and thus enable its citizens to continue their lives as they would wish, even allowing for the continuing threat of the regime in Iraq.

BREAK.PARA: In September this year the actions of Saddam Hussein in attacking the minority Kurd groups in the safe haven set up after the 1990 conflict brought about quick retaliation from the United States. The most recent incident was reported overnight with the revelation that a United States F16 fighter fired a missile at an Iraqi anti‐aircraft battery whose radar started tracking the plane while it patrolled an allied no‐fly zone over southern Iraq. The incident occurred south‐east of Kut‐al‐Hayy, which is between the 32nd and 33rd parallels. It has been some time now since the invasion of Kuwait by the Iraqis under Saddam Hussein took place and still little is known of the fate of the 625 Kuwaitis taken by the invaders as prisoners of war.

As I said in December 1994 following a visit to Kuwait, it is important that Australia, as a middle order democracy, continues to join other nations of the world in seeking the release of those Kuwaiti detainees. While ever since their capture the Iraqis have denied the existence of those prisoners, there is a strong rumour that in talks between Iraq and Jordan comments have been made by the Iraqis that would indicate they admit to having Kuwaiti prisoners. How much information has been conveyed in these discussions is uncertain, but at least it gives some hope that the Iraqis are now prepared to talk about the existence of the prisoners. Possibly in the near future negotiations may be instigated, even if they are through a broker like the Jordanian government, to have them released at an early date.

The very interesting thing about Kuwait is that it is the only Gulf state that presently has a form of democracy. It allows the people of Kuwait to have a say in the process of government and Kuwait, under His Highness the Emir, is a leader in this regard not only in the Middle East but in the wider world.

I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Sheik Salem Sabah Al‐Salem Al‐Sabah on his elevation to the office of Deputy Prime Minister of Kuwait and Minister for Defence following the recent Kuwaiti elections. Over the years and in various capacities, he has been a wonderful advocate for Kuwait and few people have worked harder for the release of the Kuwaiti detainees than Sheik Salem. Sheik Salem is highly regarded not only within Kuwait but within the wider forum of the Middle East and other parts of the world.

I would like also to mention Mr Abdul Jalil Albaf, who is well known to many people in this parliament on both sides of the House, particularly those in the Australia‐Kuwait Parliamentary Friendship Group. Mr Albaf has been a constant promoter of contact between Australia and Kuwait in both cultural and trade terms. For a long period, with the former government and now with the present coalition government, he has pressed for an air transport agreement between Australia and Kuwait.

Since the coalition government was elected, Mr Albaf has had meetings with the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) and, more recently, with the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) on all occasions promoting Australian‐Kuwait relationships. Mr Albaf has also played a key role in informing members of the Australian parliament of the 625 Kuwaiti prisoners of war and is always reminding us of the impact their incarceration has had on a nation whose population is approximately only 1.4 million.

The political situation in the Middle East is very complex, and I am aware those politics are not confined to that part of the world. However, I cannot understand how a nation like Iraq that has the potential for wealth, for providing a higher standard of living and quality of life for its people, can have a leadership so intent on committing aggression. This leadership has led to disaster for the people of Iraq, including its minority groups, has caused great suffering to its neighbour, Kuwait, and has also added to the instability of the Middle East.

I strongly support the motion put forward by the honourable member for Fairfax today. I urge not only members and senators of the Australian parliament to keep up their campaign to have the Kuwaiti prisoners of war released but also the international community, especially through the UN, to press for their speedy release.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on the motion on Iraq. I might just correct my good friend the member for Fowler (Mr Ted Grace). I thought it was Kuwait, not Iraq, that the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) said but, nonetheless, we will not argue over a minor detail.

SPEECH.PARA: If I may, I will make an observation: not quite five years ago we were in this chamber for two days debating Australia's involvement in the Gulf War. That was a significant debate because for the first time in many years we were sending Australian troops—Australian servicemen and servicewomen—to a foreign place to participate in a conflict.

Also, we were faced with the prospect that, for the first time in a major conflict, there could have been the use of chemical weapons. I am sure that played on the minds of a lot of members when they debated the matter at that time. Here we are five years or so later speaking on the same matter to all intents and purposes and still seeing the continued aggression against the people of Kuwait by Saddam Hussein and the government of Iraq.

Interestingly, tomorrow is the United States presidential election and, of course, we have seen George Bush participate in the election campaign. I am sure that to his dying day George Bush will say one of his greatest disappointments, probably his greatest failure, was the fact the allies failed to destroy the regime of Saddam Hussein when they forced his troops out of Kuwait and back into Iraqi territory.

I particularly wish to condemn the flagrant violations of human rights by the government of Iraq, which is continuing to illegally hold hundreds of Kuwaiti citizens as prisoners of war since its abortive invasion in 1990. It has been over four years since the conclusion of the military operations in the land and air campaign in the Gulf War, and we do well to question what we have achieved. Saddam Hussein is still in power, still threatening his neighbour and still threatening and oppressing his own citizens—and, for that matter, murdering his own citizens.

PARA.BREAK: Kuwait is now free from Iraqi occupation. That is true. Oil is now flowing to the economies of the world that have become so de pendent on it, and a message has been sent to all aggressors about the limits to which the international community will tolerate aggression and violence against, in particular, the small, apparently defenceless nation of Kuwait.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, however, some negative effects that arise and may grow so that they diminish all the positive elements achieved in the Gulf War unless they are addressed. The first thing is that Saddam Hussein continues to threaten his neighbours, including Kuwait, despite international condemnation and sanctions. This must constitute the greatest failure of the pre-war, war and post-war policies of not only the United States but also all the allies. The Iraqi nuclear, chemical and biological arsenal has not been destroyed and, by some accounts, continues to grow. It remains a significant threat, not just to the region but to all nations on this planet.

Iraq continues to hold an estimated 625 prisoners of war, taken during its abortive invasion. Iraq does this despite international condemnation and sanctions. As has been indicated by the member for Fowler on other occasions, the number of prisoners is a substantial tragedy for Kuwait. On a per capita basis, it would be equivalent to 15,000 Australian, 50,000 British or 220,000 American citizens being held by Iraq. I cannot emphasise enough the enormity of this tragedy to a small nation like Kuwait.

Australia played a very important role in the international efforts to reclaim Kuwait. It is a role of which we can be justifiably proud. We must remember, however, that the job is not finished, and it will not be completed until Saddam Hussein's ability to threaten his neighbours with impunity is destroyed, the Iraqi nuclear, chemical and biological arsenal is destroyed, and all Kuwaiti prisoners of war are returned safely to their homes.

We must recognise that, unless we are able to carry this issue with Kuwait and Iraq through to its proper conclusion, we will indirectly contribute to the ongoing tragedy. Further, we expose other nations and other people around the world to the risk posed by aggressors who may be encouraged by any failure to deal with Saddam Hussein or the government of Iraq.

In conclusion, I join the other speakers in their condemnation and call on the international community, through its representatives at the UN, to increase their efforts to achieve a lasting solution to the aggression of Iraq against its neighbours and to ensure the safe and speedy return of all prisoners of war held by the government of Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The maintenance of a viable car and components manufacturing industry is essential to Australia's manufacturing future and absolutely critical to the economic survival of the Geelong region, which I represent in this parliament. The car industry is at the core of Australia's manufacturing activity. It is a driver for other key manufacturing industries, such as glass, chemicals, plastics and steel. It makes an important contribution to skills formation and world best practice manufacturing. It is a significant vehicle for research and development and for the application of new manufacturing technologies and is a critical contributor to the survival of regional economies such as Geelong and others across the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of the automotive industry to Geelong cannot be understated. Geelong's largest private employer, Ford, employs 2,800 people at its Geelong operation, and its suppliers employ a further 1,000. According to Ford's submission to the Productivity Commission, its work force generates $136.5 million in wages and salaries to the local economy, and the automotive sector accounts for 25 per cent of manufacturing employment in Geelong.

PARA.BREAK: The city has had to bear a heavy burden in social and economic terms from past structur al adjustments to this industry. It has done that in the hope that the creation of an efficient, productive and best practice manufacturing facility in Geelong would guarantee the economic survival of the city beyond the year 2000. To put it simply, the closure of Ford would have a devastating effect on all private businesses in Geelong and would create an industrial wasteland that would stifle economic development of the region for the next two decades.

SPEECH.PARA: When the federal government announced the Button plan in 1984, it set out several objectives for the industry. One major objective was to increase efficiency across the industry to enable it to compete with imports and in the international marketplace at lower levels of government assistance. Another was to provide better quality cars to consumers at lower prices. These objectives were to be achieved by a combination of gradual tariff reductions, better economies of scale through rationalisation, and productivity and quality improvements through massive investments in new technology and human resources. Today the overall success of the Button plan in achieving these objectives is not in dispute. However, that success has not come without considerable cost.

The industry has registered significant increases in productivity. For example, by 1995 labour productivity in car manufacturing was 47 per cent higher than in 1988. The quality of Australian cars has improved dramatically, and efficiency gains have enabled Australian manufacturers to compete successfully in key car categories. Two important car manufacturers—Ford and GMH—have returned to profitability after several difficult years, with all four manufacturers committing investments of around $2 billion in new models and plant upgrades. In addition, exports from the car and components industry have increased from around $383 million in 1984 to over $1.7 billion today, with the most promising increases coming from the car components industry, reflecting price and quality improvements all the way down the supply chain.

Despite these advances, there has been a significant drop in employment in the car and components industry, from 63,000 in 1985 to around 45,000 in 1995. Total output of vehicles has fallen from 383,000 in 1985 to around 286,000 in 1995. This falling local output has been accompanied by increased import penetration of the Australian market, to the point where imported vehicles now make up 50 per cent of the passenger car market and nearly 100 per cent of the commercial vehicle market.

Today the Australian car manufacturing industry faces a unique set of challenges, having come through a period of restructuring, and having cemented its place as an efficient producer of quality products in our extremely competitive global trading environment. The entrance of Australia into the global automotive market is a reflection of the fact that Australia can now supply to the world cars and components at a competitive price and quality.

However, at this point in its manufacturing history, the industry finds that its future does not just lie in its own internal capacity to become more efficient and productive. Its future will be shaped by the further globalisation of the industry along with Australia's trade liberalisation commitments and by the car industry assistance arrangements that will be set in place for the industry beyond 2000 by the Australian government.

It is these industry assistance arrangements that I wish to address in this House today. The Howard government must make a strong commitment to the preservation of a viable car and component manufacturing industry in Australia. Fortunately, the electoral defeat of the Liberal Party in the 1993 election forced upon the current government an abandonment of its near zero tariff policy and an acceptance of a base level of tariff assistance of 15 per cent by the year 2000.

But we know that Fightback is alive and well in this government and in its disposition to accept dry economic advice from its economic rationalist advisory bodies, such as the Productivity Commission, which is now considering the future of the industry. Indeed, the Productivity Commission inquiry process is quite irrelevant to the car industry's situation today and what the government must do to ensure the car industry's survival in Australia's trading environment beyond the year 2000.

The reality is simply this. Firstly, the globalisation of Australia's car industry means that critical investment decisions on its future are made by international car companies in a global context. They must be sent a clear signal by the Australian government that it wants a car and component manufacturing presence in Australia. Secondly, it is clear that the long-term survival of the industry is linked to the expanding of its export capacity, and that is inextricably linked to gaining access to new markets, particularly in Asia.
