The international trading environment of the Australian car industry will be increasingly hostile in the future.

Many of our Asian and APEC trading partners have both tariff and extensive non-tariff mechanisms in place to protect their automotive industries and to foster further industry development. For example, Malaysia imposes tariff levels of up to 200 per cent, Indonesia 100 per cent, South Africa 61 per cent and India 50 per cent, while Taiwan imposes a ban on vehicle imports from Australia. Our traditional trading partners in western Europe and the USA have voluntary trade restraint agreements with their major trading partner, Japan.

Indeed, if every other country in the world provides some degree of assistance to support their car industry as a core manufacturing industry, why should Australia be any different? To successfully retain a viable car industry presence in Australia, the government must provide an industry assistance regime that will stimulate market demand for locally produced cars in the short term and expand exports so that the production of Australian cars can return to historically viable levels.

It would be naive of me to suggest that a Liberal government, wedded still to Fightback and Thatcher experiments in industry policy, would alter the current phase‐down of tariff levels to 15 per cent by the year 2000. But it should call a halt to any further tariff reductions at 15 per cent by 2000 and link any further tariff cuts to substantial actual reductions in tariff and non-tariff barriers by our trading partners whose markets Australian manufacturers seek to access.

To create a viable domestic market, the government needs to lower current taxes and charges, such as sales tax, to effectively stimulate demand for Australian cars and to seek ways of overcoming the old age of the Australian car park. The government must also provide appropriate support for the industry's efforts to export and restore its incentives to invest and engage in research and development.

It is clear that the industry's great success in recent years has been due to the massive skilling of its work force, the development of a new workplace culture and the application of advanced manufacturing technologies. The government must make sure that this process continues and that management is included in the skilling process. It must ensure that the current export facilitation scheme continues.

This industry's future does not lie in the zero tariff rhetoric of Fightback or in an obsessive preoccupation with micro‐economic reform and labour market deregulation to guarantee its future. The great gains of this industry have been achieved by redefining the workplace culture and in extensive cooperation between management and progressive unions. Its future lies in a practical realistic framework of industry assistance that continues enterprise improvement, builds upon the great skills of the work force and provides a secure level of tariff protection which sends the signal to car companies that they are welcome in Australia's manufacturing environment.

If this industry were to close down, it would cause a loss of direct employment in the car and components industry of around 22,000 with devastating consequences for key manufacturing regions such as Geelong, and it would cause a massive blow-out of the automotive trade deficit to $11 billion at a time when the government is making great play of the necessity to reduce the nation's current account deficit.

Clearly, the Australian government and the community cannot let this situation happen. So I challenge the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) to come out and support Geelong's car industry with a clear, unequivocal commitment to the preservation of car manufacturing in our city. The people of Geelong remember that the member for Corangamite and the Geelong branch of the Liberal Party were strong supporters of the Hewson zero tariff policy—a policy which would have seen the stagnation and demise of car and component manufacturing in Geelong. It is clear that if that policy had prevailed in 1993 Ford would not have made the $1 billion investment in its Australian operations in 1995 and Geelong would not have a car manufacturing facility. If he does not, all of Geelong will know that the spots on the Corangamite leopard have not changed since 1993. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is with the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), who has unleashed in our nation a debate which is on the one hand laudable and on the other abominable. I will make clear the differentiation between the two in my remarks today. Of the many issues she has raised, I wish to address in my brief time, firstly, multicultural and Aboriginal affairs and, secondly, immigration. Let me say at the outset that I believe deeply and passionately in the philosophical concept of freedom of speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Among those basic rights which I hold dear to the foundation of a democratic society are freedom of speech, freedom of association, freedom of assembly and freedom of religion. Foremost among those is freedom of speech, for if the state or others take from us our inherent right to express freely our views, our opinions, our thoughts and even our prejudices we become a society of oppression where the views of the many are dictated by the few. Woodrow Wilson once said:

I have always been amongst those who believe that the greatest freedom was the greatest safety, because if a man is a fool the best thing to do is to encourage him to advertise the fact by speaking. It cannot be so easily discovered if you allow him to remain silent and look wise. But if you let him speak the secret is out the world knows that he is a fool.
Charles James Fox said:
Opinions only become dangerous to a state only when persecution makes it necessary for the people to communicate their ideas under a bond of secrecy.
Lewis D. Brandeis, in a concurring opinion in Whitney v. California in 1927, said:
Fear of serious injury cannot alone justify suppression of free speech and assembly. Men feared witches and burned them. It is a function of speech to free men from the bondage of irrational fears.

While I champion the right of free men and women to assemble, join and practise whatever religion they will and speak openly and freely, it is important to recognise that those freedoms come with a price, which is responsibility. If our speaking would hurt or harm others, then we must learn to moderate our speaking in support of a cohesive and tolerant society.

I am told by a learned friend that witches can dance around raindrops. But rather than viewing that dance as a marvellous ability which they did not possess, men and women, through fear and ignorance, burned witches at the stake. While we now live in more enlightened times, it seems we still have need to guard against fear, ignorance and intolerance where such attitudes bring hurt to others.

In reflecting on the community debate in Australia today following some overly publicised comments by the member for Oxley, I think we are having two debates. The first, which is about race, creed, culture and religion—in fact, difference—seems to me to be through lack of tolerance based on fear and lack of understanding. The second is, I think, a genuine intellectual debate about, firstly, how best to help those of us who from whatever circumstances cannot or will not without community help lift themselves from positions of deprivation and, secondly, the level, but not the composition of, immigration.
Former American President, Abraham Lincoln, in his famous Gettysburg Address, said:

Fourscore and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal. Now we are engaged in a great civil war testing whether that nation or any nation so conceived and so dedicated can long endure.

Our nation of Australia was, of course, conceived at a different time and in different circumstances, but we have never been any less committed to the democratic concept that all men, and indeed all women, are created equal. Lincoln's question was answered in the affirmative.
The member for Oxley has said that a truly multicultural country can never be strong or united. She has also said:
I believe we are in danger of being swamped by Asians.

I think the member for Oxley is just plain wrong. Our nation is a nation of immigrants, even including, tens of thousands of years ago, our Aboriginal citizens. I am an immigrant, as are many of my colleagues who are representatives of the people in this House of Representatives.

I believe that Australia has become one of the greatest melting pots, if not the greatest, of the world's humanity and that we have done it better than any other nation on earth. We have managed to bring together cultures, creeds and ethnicities from all points of the globe without the racial and religious intolerance and hatred leading to violence and physical acts of desecration which are so prevalent in so many other and older societies in both the developed and the developing world. Any debate which denies that fact is just plain wrong.

I can understand that many in our community feel insecurity because of change to the largest extent forced on us by a rapidly changing world—change we can no more ignore than we could walk to the moon. Too high levels of unemployment help feed that insecurity. But immigration has built this nation and immigration has provided jobs, not taken them away. Fear of difference and fear by individuals of being unable to control events outside themselves always make it easy to blame others for our particular circumstances. But fearing people who look different, speak differently or dress differently is addressed by education and tolerance, not bigotry or racism. I have said before in this place that I grew up in one of the most racist societies on earth, but I grew up to deplore the intolerance and belief in superiority of one race over another. Adolf Hitler fanned underlying fear, greed and hatred to bring on the Second World War and the Holocaust. His views of racial superiority failed the test, and so they should.

On the second of my major issues today, I think the member for Oxley has kicked along a debate we are starting to have, which I have described as an intellectual debate, on how best to help those in our society who today we term `disadvantaged'. It is a reasoned and rational debate which has surrounded modern concepts of the welfare state for a very long time. In recent years it has become all too frequently the habit of those who believe in an ever expanding safety net to denigrate those of differing views as heartless, unthinking, racist or lacking in sympathy and understanding. It is a political correctness argument. In my view it is intellectually sustainable to argue that increasing social welfare can lead to increasing dependence and that dependence breeds upon itself, locking those encompassed by it into a life void of happiness, ambition or fulfilment because of that dependence. The member for Oxley has said:
The majority of Aboriginals do not want handouts because they realise welfare is killing them.

I suspect that is not true. I believe that we have a compelling need to help our Aboriginal brothers and sisters lift themselves through effective education, urgent attention to demonstrably poor health outcomes and dramatically improving their access to an acceptable standard of housing. It is not only appropriate but also incumbent on us to do everything possible to help those in our society who are in need and to give them a chance to help themselves. How we go about this is a legitimate debate.
But to argue that Aboriginals, particularly those in regional and outback Australia, are not the most disadvantaged of our citizens is an absolute nonsense. The member for Oxley has said:
To survive in peace and harmony, united and strong, we must have one people, one nation, one flag.

At first glance, that sounds like the ultimate national motherhood statement, but if it is code that we must all be the same to meet that objective, then the honourable member misses the boat well and truly. We will never be all the same. Trying to put us into boxes defined by race, creed, colour, hairstyle or dress is both impractical and undesirable. It is our differences that make us learn, think, expand and grow—and that, my colleagues, is for the good of us all. Mark Twain said:
It is by the goodness of God that in our country we have those three unspeakably precious things: freedom of speech, freedom of conscience, and the prudence never to practice either of them.
I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate to express my concern about events in recent months. I would like to start by quoting from an article by Peter Robinson in yesterday's Sun‐Herald :

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen reflected in the mirror of the past few weeks is a nation that is lost. Its pride and self‐esteem, the very soul of nationhood, have been transmuted into a whine of self‐doubt.
Those words, I think, are very pertinent and go very much to the nub of what has been happening in recent months. I think it is important to probe some of the issues that are involved.

We are increasingly aware of the internationalisation of economies, trade and values, and of the globalisation of companies and businesses. Almost daily the communication revolution ensures that we watch events live, whether it be elections or debates or whether it be major catastrophes like those in Zaire or in other parts of the world. In that process there has been a tendency for people to become more tribalised. This has been spoken about to some degree, but it is perhaps less understood. It has become more and more difficult for people to relate closely to each other in large numbers. We are seeing the breaking up of nations in the USSR and in Yugoslavia. We are seeing a move toward smaller units and smaller groups, to identification for self‐awareness. That is understandable and it is human, but it carries with it a great danger. Mr Robinson's words are very pertinent when people, as a country, begin to doubt who they are and whether they are a country. In that context it is quite predictable that people may seek to appeal to the simplistic and to the emotive. That is what we have been seeing in the last year or more. There has been an increasing appeal to prejudice.

Prejudice has always been around and it always will be. It is a part of human nature. It is based on fear, insecurity, paranoia, very often ignorance and, of course, the matter of self‐doubt, particularly at national levels. Prejudice in my youth was about the then incoming waves of migrants, about religion, about where people lived and about what state you came from. We see it being expressed in football games in all ways and in all forms. We must not pretend that it is something new. It has been used by politicians and leaders of all kinds since man was man. The previous speaker, the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), spoke about the demagoguery of the Nazi regime and its appeal to prejudice.

We understand that prejudice is there and we understand what it means. We also understood, or thought we did, that civilisation and social cohesion were predominantly about understanding our prejudices and recognising them for what they are, and about respecting the fact that one person's prejudice is another person's offence or insult. We understood that recognising and refraining from expressing our prejudices in the more extreme forms was a part of being civilised. It was a part of being educated. It was a part of recognising our individual acceptance of some sense of social norm, social mores and social cohesion.

What we are being told now is that that was all wrong, that it was actually political correctness that prevented people from insulting each other. Manners had nothing to do with it; politeness and respect did not matter. What really mattered was that people were not allowed to speak because of some supposed notion of political correctness. That is a very limp excuse and a very limp explanation of a much more serious matter. The idea of labelling it with some new trendy label does not solve the problem and does not answer the question. I think the efforts of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in this regard in the last six or eight months have been incredibly destructive of any sense of manners and politeness in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—I will tell you how if you also interject afterwards. For the Prime Minister to suggest that people should be free to speak and then, after they have spoken, to say, `There's an example or a demonstration of free speech,' effectively means that he is condoning the insulting of those who are insulted, the offending of those who are offended and the enraging of those who are enraged. That is what he has done, and he has done it very carefully and very precisely. That is why, in his opening remarks in that same article, Mr Robinson said:

SPEECH.PARA: John Howard, still unable to confront the racism issue head‐on, now says that the whole thing will be forgotten in a month or two anyway.

Throughout that article Mr Robinson points out that this is actually avoiding the issue. The idea that the answer is that somehow it will be forgotten is not the answer, because it needs to be challenged head‐on, not in terms of censoring people and not in terms of saying people can't talk but in terms of saying that social cohesion and social responsibility mean that we accept and recognise our prejudices and that we recognise the harm they can do others.

What we are seeing is a licence to vilify, a licence to offend and a licence to insult under the guise of freedom of speech. Freedom of speech has never had such licences attached to it. It has always been there for those who want to do it. There has never been a legal restraint on those who want to act in that way, and nor should there be. But there always has been a social recognition that that causes other problems. Effectively, what we are talking about is social anarchy.

As a country we often hear about law and order. We do not often talk about the boundaries of black letter law or law in terms of social mores and social standards, which in many ways is the more important law, the more important judgment. What we are seeing now is an expression of anarchy by not just some parliamentarians but by the Prime Minister as well, in condoning that. There are those who think you can restrict expressions of prejudice simply to matters of race, religion or culture. No, you can't. We will be seeing similar expressions of prejudice to older people, to people with disabilities, to all kinds of people who are different in any way, because prejudice is basically about difference.

The condoning of this so‐called freedom of speech and this so‐called debate is actually an encouragement to those who will seek to express their prejudices as and when they wish—and to hell with the consequences. Those consequences are widespread and profound. The fact is that we have been hearing some examples, particularly in the first speech of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), about the supposed special help and special programs that some people get. I presume that also means special programs for pensioners, based on age. I suppose we also have special programs for people with diabetes, people who cannot read and write or people with particular medical problems. All those special programs should obviously go, because in the context of a program based on a special need—whether it be a disadvantage, language inability or age—where do you stop? Where do you draw the line? Once you start that approach—and that approach has already started—where do you stop? I suggest that what we are seeing is leading to a serious breakdown of our social standards.

This should and does concern all of us. We are seeing now that suddenly there is a concern because it may affect the economy. The fact is that that has always been there and we have always known that, if we insult people often enough, eventually, if they can, they will shift their business. More importantly, the trade between countries is undertaken by people of goodwill, between people who speak the languages and know the cultures. If they are the ones who are being insulted, then the people at the forefront of trade are the ones who are being wounded and damaged.

The more important concerns should be the concerns about our society and its make‐up—the questions of respect, recognition of each other's differences and the acceptance of the benefit of that. I had an example just the other day—I am sure we are all getting phone calls now—of a mother of Asian extraction whose son came home one day and said to her, `Mum, at school they asked me today why I don't go back to where I came from. What did they mean, Mum?' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring to the attention of the House the shameful situation that the coalition government inherited from Labor after 13 years of neglect of the rural and regional areas of Australia. In particular, I want to highlight a report, recently released by the Liberal Party's regional and rural committee, entitled Striking a Balance . This shows that over 13 years, from 1983 to 1996, Labor effectively completely left out of the policy process many parts of the services to regional and rural Australia. This report is the voice of the country. It is the voice of the anger of the people, not only in my electorate of Wannon but also right throughout regional Australia. I think it shows just why there was such a huge swing in so many parts of the country against the Labor Party on 2 March. It demonstrates that over 13 years the Labor Party really had very little interest in the concerns of people in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time available, I want to quickly go through a number of areas which highlight just how serious this neglect really was by the Labor Party. We start by looking at unemployment. Many people are aware how serious the problems of unemployment have been in the country. Not only is there a limited variety of occupations available in the country but also, in many cases, there just simply weren't any jobs. In fact, while we are all well aware that unemployment, particularly amongst our young, exceeded one in four, higher than 25 per cent—in fact, in many cases as high as one in three could not find work—we find in some parts of Victoria that it went even higher. For example, in western Victoria it climbed to 36 per cent, while in the Mallee it climbed as high as a staggering 66 per cent of our young unable to find work, at one stage, under the Labor administration. These are only the official figures. Often they hide an even more serious situation.

The second area I would like to highlight today is health. Many people think the country is a nice, healthy place to live. In some ways, the lifestyle is very healthy. But, unfortunately, when you look at some of the statistics, we find a very different picture. For example, heart disease in the country is up to 18 per cent higher than it is in the city; strokes are up to 29 per cent more prevalent than they are in the city; pneumonia or influenza can be as high as 95 per cent higher than in the city; and the incidence of traffic accidents can be up to 61 per cent higher. I could go on.

Rural children are now far more prone to ailments than those in the city. The death rate for rural girls is 15 per cent higher than in the city, while rural youth suicide, which is one of the great tragedies that has crept up on us, is now the highest of any Western society. Despite this, one would have thought that the availability of services might at least have been shared, but in figures which I got from the former Labor minister for health we found that people in the country, on average each year, get between $100 and $200 less in Medicare rebates than those in the city. This could be up to 30 per cent lower. In other words, the availability of services in the country is such that people just do not have access like those in the city.

PARA.BREAK: You might say, `What did Labor do about it?' I cannot say they did absolutely nothing. In the past four years we saw the national rural health conference, we saw the national rural health alliance and we saw the national rural heath strategy, and the Australian Rural Health Institution was set up to study the program—just form another committee. Despite all this, the Department of Human Services and Health had stated simply what the problem was, that is, that country Australia needs another 300 to 500 GPs. What you might say is that Labor might have been seen as the government of perpetual announcements and really, when it came to health, the government of perpetual inaction. We ought to contrast those examples with some of the work that is already being done by the coali tion government, when we see the work that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has already undertaken in the setting up of a number of private health initiatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The third area I want to touch on is education, something we all know is so important for our young in this current age. It gives them the means to get ahead. But if you look at what is happening in the country, the sad fact is that, as a percentage, fewer country students are completing secondary education and even fewer are going on to tertiary education. It is really very disturbing to find that rural retention rates for year 12 have seen country students fall behind their city cousins, with a rate of 52 per cent compared with 66 per cent. If you look at those going on to tertiary education, you find that the number of country students is actually falling, down from 25 per cent in 1989 to just 16 per cent last year. This means they are 60 per cent less likely than city students to undertake tertiary education.

Despite these chilling figures, despite what was so obvious, we saw a government that continued to refuse to even face up to what is basically one of the major causes of the problem and that is that it costs more to get education for country students than it does for city students. Yet they failed to address this in any meaningful way. The statistics show very clearly just how seriously they failed that test.

The fourth area I want to touch on is transport. To see what has led to the growing disparity between the city and the country, you only have to look at what Labor did to transport costs. What better example is there to show this than the change in fuel excise which increased a staggering fivefold under Labor. Yet at the same time the amount of money that the federal government was spending on roads under Labor fell from $850 million to $840 million over that period. At the same time the amount of fuel excise collected by the Commonwealth rose from $3,000 million to a staggering $10,000 million.

The fifth area I want to touch on is drought. Nothing shows more clearly the stark contrast between the coalition government and Labor in the response, the understanding and the concern for people who suffer horrendous costs and losses and suffer personally as the result of drought. We saw an example in Victoria where in 1992 many farmers had their entire crops wiped out by flood only to find that just over a year later they faced drought. But, according to some little formula that Labor had concocted, they did not qualify for any drought assistance even though they had suffered such devastating losses. If you look at the criteria Labor was applying in the 1967‐68 drought and in the 1982‐1983 drought, nobody in Australia would have qualified for any drought assistance. I want to contrast that with the announcement the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made today. He showed that the coalition government really does have an understanding of drought, not only while an area is drought declared but also in the subsequent period with the costs and the difficulties that people have in getting back on their feet.

There are a number of other areas that I would like to touch on but given the limited time available I would like to come back to the key point that I think 13 years of Labor neglect of the country has created a devastating situation and it has left rural Australia very much the poorer. Professor Lindsay Falvey from Melbourne University put it very eloquently when he said:

The image of rural Australia and in particular agriculture and related industries in Australia has been neglected and in some cases denigrated amongst the city base where electoral power largely rests. It is a responsibility of Government that all Australians be made aware of the benefit of strong agricultural, food, horticultural, forest and related industries to the well being of all Australians in economic and lifestyle terms. Similarly, the image of agricultural and similar industries and those working in them needs to be updated significantly so that the diverse skills in terms of environmental and use of appropriate high technology are appreciated.

Hear, hear, I say to Professor Falvey. And I think it was the Labor Party more than anyone else that set about to downgrade that image of rural Australia. So the report that the Liberal Party's committee put together, Striking a Balance , not only outlines these problems but also looks at some of the initial solutions that the coalition government has already put in place. But the coalition's commitment to rural Australia has again been reinforced by the release of our Budget document, Rebuilding regional Australia , which shows that clearly we are starting down that track. But the election itself highlights just how much the electorate woke up to what was happening in Labor and if you look at the regional and rural seats today Labor holds just five whereas the coalition parties hold 49. That shows clearly how disillusioned rural Australia was with Labor. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to enter this grievance debate to grieve not merely as the member for Melbourne Ports, a genuinely multicultural community, but as a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and a former Minister for Immigration. I rise to condemn the semi‐illiterate, prejudiced and biased statements of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I believe there has been a level of tolerance extended to that member which belies the kind of nonsense which she has perpetrated in this House and which I believe is doing great damage to the nature of our Australian community. There is no minister for immigration or ex‐minister for immigration who will not tell the Australian people that it is always the last group of migrants getting off the boat that cop the flak. It has always been thus.

SPEECH.PARA: One only has to look at the history of immigration immediately after the war to see the way in which the late Arthur Calwell, the founder of our immigration policies, was subject to abuse, vilification, turgid comments and cartoons. Why? Because he brought to Australia people of Jewish religion, many of whom were holocaust victims. That criticism of Calwell came not simply from the more conservative sections of Australian society but also from people who have had former associations with the Labor Party.

So there has always been this problem in Australian society. I thought we had overgrown it until I heard the member for Oxley condemning people because they have their own culture and religion. So what! Which Australian citizen cannot claim to be a product of his own culture and his own religion?

She also says they form ghettos. If you visit any community in Melbourne, you will find areas where Italians, Greeks, Chinese and Vietnamese have settled. Why? Because, if you are arriving as an immigrant without much wealth, you will seek out cheap housing and, if you do not speak fluent English, a neighbourhood which is sympathetic and, hopefully, contains some of your fellow former countrymen. You will seek their views and their advice. You will seek to live near the place of your religion and hope that you will also find a place to educate your children.

That is the history of the major centres of Melbourne and it is a history which up until now has produced, I think, one of the most remarkable multicultural societies to be found anywhere in the world. I, for one, am not prepared to sit and listen to the kind of nonsense talked by the honourable member for Oxley, who is long on rhetoric and long on slander but short on detail and chooses to use what she describes as fact without any real basis at all.

She wants to abolish ATSIC. I have heard that argument before. She is the only member of this parliament or of any parliament—and I have been in two—who has said they will not represent people in their electorate on the basis of their ethnicity, and she is referring to our indigenous Australian people. I have always operated on the basis that, after an election, it does not matter how many votes you win or lose, as a member of this parliament, you represent all of your constituents. If the chairman of the local Liberal Party is having difficulty with his bureaucracy and he is one of my constituents, he has a basic right to have me argue for him and do my best for him. That is a view that I believe runs through this parliament as part of our tradition.

When I hear the member for Oxley read out a speech written for her—usually she cannot get through it without making all sorts of mistakes—and say that there is one section of people that she will not represent, I condemn her. She does not understand the workings of our parliament. She does not understand the policy that has been formulated and administered by ministers for immigration over the years of different political complexion.

There are plenty of things to argue about in immigration. All ministers have had to face the question of how you balance the immigration intake, how you deal with that in economic terms and how you deal with it in terms of regional capacities to absorb people. That has engendered many important debates in this place and so it will continue to do.

But there is no significant contribution to this debate coming from the member for Oxley—oh, no! She could have been here when a very important motion was passed by this House, but she chose to absent herself because she had business in Melbourne. If she feels as deeply as she obviously does and if she is wanting to express a view on a debate of that kind, one would have understood if she had absented herself from any previous engagement to be here to put her point of view. But that is not her methodology.

She chooses carefully where she will make her statements and she does that under the privilege of parliament. She will not be interviewed by the ABC—no reason given—and she will only go to select audiences. Let me say quite frankly to this House: if you want to run a racist agenda and if you want to run an exercise in vilification of certain groups in this community, there are organised groups in Australia which will be only too happy to provide you with an audience. I find it no accident that she has now been adopted by the League of Rights. Why would she not be?

She says all she wants is equality for all Australians. From the very birth of this nation, all Australians were not equal and they are not equal. No government can legislate to produce some kind of odd equality. What does she want? She has claimed John Howard, the leader of the political party that disendorsed her, as her leader. He will do her. I sympathise with the Prime Minister on that matter. There is not much he can do about it.

What she says is one leader, one nation and one race. We have heard it all before and the world learnt the tragic result of that concept. If she says she still wants to debate this matter, then, I for one, as a former minister, will meet her anywhere in Australia at a time and place of her choosing—and I believe there will be other members of this House who will do the same—because you cannot let this argument run on.

This is not just a question of damaging our economy. I have read the very important statement of a former political colleague and friend, John Brown, a leader in the tourist industry, commenting on the damage being done to that industry—and that is true. But more important than the economic damage, let us get this right: it is a question of national morality; it is a question of how we see ourselves as a people; it is a question of saying, `The one thing we will not abandon'—and it has not been abandoned by any minister for immigration—`is that, irrespective of your colour, irrespective of your religious beliefs, irrespective of your background, you will face a test, which is a uniform test, for whatever class or category you choose to enter Australia. You will not be told that, because of the colour of your skin or your religious beliefs, you will not be accepted.'

It is time that we stopped being gentle with the member for Oxley. As far as I am concerned, I will debate with her any time, any place, anywhere—and she can bring her League of Rights goons with her. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Court Case: Mr and Mrs C. Mann

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the notice of the House a case that I believe is tragic and that, to my knowledge, has been running for over seven or eight years. It concerns Mr Christopher Mann and his wife, Christine, who are constituents of mine. I would inform the House that I have been seeking to assist Mr Mann since 1988. His case has advanced and, despite some positive rulings and reports, he is now no nearer to realising finalisation of his London case than when he first began eight years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I have appealed to a wide range of authorities to help me resolve this matter because it is complex. It is not always within the powers of the bureaucracy or the Attorney-General to resolve such matters, but I have appealed to attorneys and bureaucracies of all political persuasions to assist in this matter. We have even had hearings of the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee where Mr Mann appeared and gave evidence in the examination and report on privacy, completed by that committee some time during last year.

Mr Mann, due to a series of circumstances, brought proceedings in the High Court, London, against a former employee of his, Mr John Eccott; a journalist, Dianne Fernyhough; and a medical journal, called World Medicine, for publishing a defamatory article. Mr Mann was successful in the case and, due to the defendants' apparent protraction of the argument, his costs were substantial—over £900,000 accumulating over a period of some 10 years or more.

The case came about because Mr Mann was made aware of the defamatory article in a London journal. In the process of seeking to defend himself, he pursued his opponent in the British courts. In order to gain information for the case being brought by the Medical Defence Union, who supported Dr Eccott's litigation, that union employed a solicitor, a Mr Rubinstein. Mr Rubinstein, solicitor for the union and other defendants, I believe, may have misused confidential information which he obtained through Commonwealth and state government departments.

On a visit to Australia, Mr Rubinstein was able to gain access to the department of health in New South Wales and the departments of health and immigration and ethnic affairs in Australia. Over a period of time I have seen freedom of information copies of file notes and comments by departmental officers. From those, it is patently clear that there was an understanding in the public service that Mr Rubinstein was acting on a matter of highest principle and had the support of the then Solicitor-General in making his inquiries here in Australia. He was provided with a range of documents, files and statements from state and Commonwealth records—documents, files and statements which were of a confidential nature and should never have been supplied to an outsider.

Mr Rubinstein, after being supplied with this information, then proceeded to go back to Britain to prosecute Mr Christopher Mann using the documents that he had obtained here in Australia. These documents, when produced in court, were used by Mr Rubinstein to prove, or attempt to prove, to the court that Mr Mann had not conducted himself in the best manner and that he was regarded as a person of some doubt by Australian authorities. When asked in the London court to produce all of his documentation, Mr Mann was not able to produce the documents which had been obtained by Mr Rubinstein.

It seems strange to me that we have an instance where an Australian citizen, born and bred, is not able to obtain from the bureaucracy documentation about their own records and behaviour, but that a foreigner coming into Australia on a visit, by using officers and contacts, is able to gain complete files which he then takes overseas and uses to prosecute that Australian citizen. When these matters were first raised with me by Mr Mann, I did not believe that Australian government departments would be party to such a process. But I am absolutely certain that they have been and, whether inadvertently or by design, they have supplied documentation that allowed Mr Mann to be prosecuted to the extent that he has lost his own home, the home of his mother and that of his mother-in-law. He is now enjoying very poor health, due to the great physical strain he has had to undergo over the last 10 or so years.

For a normal individual to pursue these matters a lot of money is needed and the court costs are extreme. Mr Mann long ago ran out of the capacity to pay for QCs and barristers and has in fact been basically successful in pursuing this matter himself. He has become extremely well read in the law. He is an intelligent man and he is able to pursue these matters himself. He has had to do so if he is intent on restoring his good name.

An examination on three occasions by the Australian Ombudsman first found there was no fault on the part of the Australian government departments. But, with persistence, the Ombudsman has established that there has been a misuse of confidential files by Commonwealth public servants. The files were improperly released to a London based solicitor who acted for the defendants against Mr Mann.

The former Attorney-General acknowledged these facts, as do the current office holders, but says that the case of Mr Mann was not affected by the Commonwealth's release of confidential information because that confidential information had already been made available by a similar process by public servants in New South Wales. So we have had two lots of public administrators saying that they were not to blame—the administration in New South Wales blaming the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth blaming New South Wales. In this process we have a man who has been done a grave injustice in my opinion.

Mr Mann, as I have said, has suffered greatly. It would not be such a serious matter if the London courts had not found Mr Mann right in all his claims and awarded him costs of £900,000. It would not be so serious if Mr Mann could not go through the taxing process of that £900,000 because he cannot afford to. It would not be so serious if there were other public servants, other than Commonwealth public servants, involved in this process.

What appears to be happening to Mr and Mrs Mann is a process of attrition. Eventually the public administration in this country feels that if they hold out long enough the Manns will give in. The Manns have not given in. Despite the Commonwealth refusing to allow Mr Mann and his lawyers access to his own files, despite the fact that he has had to fight his own case unaware of what was on Commonwealth and state government files about him, he has been successful in prosecuting.

I have found that there have been a number of extraordinary and deceitful excuses made by public officers surrounding these breaches of privacy, which they at first denied. Then after representations by me they attempted to justify their conduct by claiming that Mr Mann had failed to conduct his litigation in a proper manner. That is clearly refuted on reading the comments reported by Judge Sir Michael Davies. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve for the double standards of the coalition parties. I grieve for the way in which they talk about most issues in code—that is, stating policy for the consumption of one audience but then adding a qualification to satisfy the prejudices of another audience. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is the best example of this code of doublespeak.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister claims to be sympathetic to the cause of Aboriginal people but not by learning any of the lessons of their history. He claims to be sympathetic to cultural diversity in Australia, yet he talks the language of one monocultural Australia. He claims to have taken a stand in the race debate, yet perhaps he alone in our nation refuses to mention Pauline Hanson by name. He claims the priority for Australia's future in the Asia-Pacific, yet he declares our closest bonds to be with Britain. He claims to be a micro reformer, yet he is only interested in reforming the labour market, not product markets. He claims to be an economic reformer yet also a social conservative, as if the two come from different planets and can never collide.

None of this doublespeak makes for national leadership. It only makes for confusion and drift—the type of confusion many Australians now feel about the race debate and our national identity; the type of drift now being felt on employment policy, the nation's economic growth and our place in Asian markets. Confusion and drift—the hallmark of Howard leadership then and now. Confusion and drift—the defining features of the Howard government.

It is not just the Prime Minister. The full extent of coalition doublespeak is revealed in the publication the Australian candidate study released just last week. This was a survey of the views of candidates who stood at the last federal election conducted by academics from three universities. It is a reliable, candid and quite stunning insight into the world view of the coalition's candidates, most of whom now sit in the House of Representatives. It reveals the full extent of the coalition's doublespeak—the conflict between its public policies and private prejudices.

Let me run the House through the key findings of the study, which I shall also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard. I will provide six instances in this study of coalition doublespeak. The first instance of doublespeak relates to multiculturalism. The public policy of the coalition is support for cultural diversity and racial tolerance in Australia. The private prejudice revealed in this study is that 35 per cent of the 115 coalition candidates surveyed believed that Australia had gone too far in giving equal opportunities for migrants.

The second instance of doublespeak relates to the rights of women. The public policy of the coalition—and their female members use this in the House quite frequently—is support for the rights of women and active female participation in our society. Yet in the anonymous survey distributed to each of the coalition candidates who stood at the last election 33 per cent of the 117 respondents believed that Australia had gone too far in providing equal opportunities for women.

Even worse, 40 per cent of the coalition's candidates, two‐fifths of their membership, disagreed with the proposition that government should increase opportunities for women in business and industries. That is hardly a radical proposition; and hardly a statement of attitude which accords with a party which says that it believes in equal rights for women.

The third instance of doublespeak relates to Aboriginal Australians. The public policy of the coalition was that governments need to improve the living standards and opportunities of Aboriginal people in Australia. Yet the private prejudice revealed in this survey is that 54 per cent of coalition candidates believed that governments had gone too far in helping Aboriginal people. More than half of the candidates who stood for the coalition at the last election believed that governments had gone too far in trying to help Aboriginal people.

BREAK.PARA: The fourth instance of doublespeak is on relations with Asia. The coalition's public policy, stated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) and the Prime Minister, is that the coalition gives priority to a relationship of trust and cooperation with our Asian neighbours. The private prejudice revealed in this study was a stunning finding: 61 per cent of coalition candidates believed that China is likely to pose a threat to Australia's security. Even more amazing, even more out of step with their public pronouncements, is that an even higher number, 76 per cent of coalition candidates, believed that Indonesia, Australia's closest neighbour, is likely to pose a security threat to our nation.

The fifth instance of doublespeak is on trade policy. The public policy of the coalition was a belief in an open economy and a free trade agenda for the Asia Pacific. Just today, there was quite an excellent article by the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) in the Australian Financial Review echoing that attachment to free trade. Yet the private prejudice of coalition members and candidates is that 49 per cent, almost half, of the 114 coalition candidates surveyed agreed with the proposition that `Australia should limit the import of foreign products in order to protect its national economy'. No wonder the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) is wincing. No wonder he is trying to hide from these quite stunning and revealing survey results telling us so much about the private prejudices of the coalition.

It gets even worse. The sixth instance of coalition doublespeak—indeed, the mother of all doublespeak—was on help for battlers. The public policy of the coalition was that they would spill blood to try and assist the so-called Howard battlers. Yet there was an interesting response to the question in the survey conducted just a few months ago: would candidates agree with the proposition that income and wealth should be redistributed towards ordinary working people?

One would have thought that a party, the coalition, that declares so much support for battlers would readily agree with the proposition that income and wealth in Australia should be redistributed towards ordinary working people. Seventy‐five per cent of the Australian Labor Party candidates agreed with that proposition. Three‐quarters of Labor candidates surveyed agreed with that proposition. For the coalition? Sixteen per cent. So much for a party for battlers. So much for a party that states its support for ordinary working people. Only 16 per cent of their candidates at the last federal election thought that income and wealth should be redistributed towards those battlers.

This just goes to show that the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) may have left the coalition but her views linger on. They are revealed fully in the private prejudices of coalition members in this stunning survey. It is all there in black and white. It is all there in the survey results: the perceived threat from Asia, the economic isolationism, the strong suspicion about equal rights for migrants and women, the suspicion about helping Aboriginal Australians and, of course, not really doing anything positive for battlers—not wanting to do the positive thing of income and wealth redistribution to ordinary working families. Only 16 per cent of the coalition candidates believed in that element of redistribution in public policy.

I thought that, while I am on the subject of coalition cant and hypocrisy, I might say a few words and single out one member, the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson). During the adjournment debate on our last sitting day, the member for Bradfield, with all the elitism expected from a medical professional, spoke of mediocrity passing for debate in the House of Representatives. One of my little hobbies is to hold sanctimonious Tories to their own standards.

I ask, therefore: did the member for Bradfield mean by mediocrity someone who changes political parties the way most people change their underwear? Did he mean by mediocrity someone who presents himself as a saviour on all issues without advancing any new ideas? Did he mean by mediocrity someone who supports debating life and death issues in the non-controversial side chamber of the House? Or did the member for Bradfield mean by mediocrity the asking on notice of the following question to the head of Australia's central bank and monetary authority:

Between 1972‐1975 Australia had a fixed exchange rate. What in your assessment would be the effect on the value of the Australian dollar now if the budget outlays increased by equivalent proportions as they did in the early to mid 1970s and in particular, if the Government of the day announced a 14.6% increase in budget spending in one year, as the Whitlam Government did in the 1974-75 Budget?

Of course, between 1972 and 1975 Australia did not have a fixed exchange rate, if by that the member for Bradfield meant that it could never move. What Australia had was an exchange rate determined by government rather than determined, as it is now, by the market with, from time to time, some intervention by the Reserve Bank of Australia. This was a government‐determined exchange rate, but it could move, and it did move, over that three-year period.

Just for the edification of the member of the Bradfield, I point out that when the Whitlam government was first elected in December 1972 the Australian exchange rate was US119c. By the time of the coup in November 1975, the exchange rate was US127c. The Australian dollar had appreciated, in fact, by 8c against the American dollar. So there was an appreciation over time reflecting, of course, the mediocrity of the member for Bradfield. What a silly question to ask Australia's head of the Reserve Bank, especially when he didn't know the basis of his own proposition. The answer was to the credit of the Whitlam government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the material—
—His time has expired.
—Come on. You gave me leave earlier on. I seek leave to incorporate the material in Hansard .
—Is leave granted?
—Members should compare the contribution by the member for Werriwa with that of the member for Melbourne Ports. It is a tragedy the member for Werriwa is consumed by such bitterness and unhappiness—
—Minister, the question is whether or not leave will be granted.
—It is the dodgiest survey, the most inaccurate. It lacks total credibility.
—The minister will either—
—We don't burn books on the side of the government, so you can table your falsities till the cows come home—
—The minister will either respond to the request or resume his seat.
—But by allowing the tabling I give no credit whatsoever to the veracity of the figures used by—

—The minister will resume his seat! There seems to be a good deal of confusion in the chamber, thanks to the minister's determination to ignore the chair. The question was whether or not the member for Werriwa would be granted leave to incorporate a document in Hansard , a document he had previously shown to the Clerk. Is leave granted for that incorporation or not?
—I should firstly apologise to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for speaking over you, but the emotion of the event overcame me.
—Is leave granted or not?
—Leave is granted, but again I stress—
—That is all I need to know. The minister will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl, Garry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to introduce a slightly different thrust to this grievance debate because I am going to rejoice. I am going to rejoice on behalf of the Surfing Australia team which represented this country at the world titles at Huntington Beach, California, last month. They did extremely well indeed. There were 18 competitors consisting of men and women, juniors and seniors. Board riders competed in events for stand up, traditional long board, kneeboards and bodyboards. The team as a whole won the bronze medal from 680 competitors from 43 countries, so it is an absolutely outstanding result.

SPEECH.PARA: Two people in particular I have to mention are from the electorate of Cowper. Nerida Falconer from Scotts Head won the gold medal for the open women's event, a fantastic result. Craig Ashdown, who also happens to be one of my staffers, and I am very proud of him, won the silver medal for kneeboarding. Of course other team members won the silver for the long board and the men's bodyboard. It is a tremendous result and one which the parliament should be advised of.

Still on the issue of sport, I would like to raise the issue of the need for a bicycle velodrome at Macksville in the Nambucca Valley. The Nambucca Shire Council is prepared to donate a suitable piece of land—a natural amphitheatre—and this would be a regional facility managed by the local committee with support drawn throughout the whole of the mid‐north coast, Australia's holiday coast. Although velodromes are not cheap to construct, once they are built they are very cheap to maintain. So the investment of funds into this will be very significant and a very long-term thing.

PARA.BREAK: It will be a focus for cycling in the region for road racing, recreational cycling as well as track racing. As we have found with the recent Olympic Games, cycling is becoming a more accepted sport. It is one that creates a lot of spectator interest. Having made representations to the Minister for Sport, Territor ies and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), I am taking this opportunity of reinforcing the need for some special funding to get this going. It is something which would benefit an enormous number of people. There is no velodrome between Newcastle and the Queensland border, and I believe that this would be a very sensible injection of funds from the federal government.

SPEECH.PARA: I also need to bring to the attention of the parliament the fact of bananas being sold, somehow or other, illegally in Brisbane at a food fair held, I believe, about three months ago. Apparently, dried bananas from the Cook Islands were brought in and sold. They were wrapped in banana leaves, and of course the minister at the table, Mr Jull, will know that the spores of the disease black sigatoka are carried in the leaves.

The banana industry in Australia, both in Queensland and New South Wales, and to a lesser extent in Western Australia, is very significant. It is a family activity of horticulture and it ends up creating an enormous amount of employment and big contributions to the economies of the banana growing areas. In actual fact, the Australian Banana Growers Council has spent more than $1 million trying to keep black sigatoka out of Australia. I have seen it in the Torres Strait. It has come in from New Guinea. The last outbreak was at Weipa, on the western side of Cape York Peninsula, where every banana plant was infected. The authorities believed that the spores which infected the bananas at Weipa were either brought down in a cyclone or by people from Pascoe River, where there was an outbreak two years ago. I stress to the House that the quarantine regulations that are in place are essential. They are necessary and they are absolutely vital to protecting the Australian banana industry.

Just to head back for a moment to another sporting area, on Saturday afternoon I had the very great pleasure of attending the opening of the Leon Adams Lawn at the Sawtell Croquet Club. I know the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is in the House, is one of those of us who acknowledges the pleasures of that game. It is very interesting to note that the Sawtell Croquet Club was founded in 1948. It was founded by wonderful people. One of those founding members, Islet Faichney, is 93 years old and she was there playing on Saturday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good for her!

—Good for her indeed. I just wanted to bring this to the attention of the House because they opened their second lawn. They are only a small club—33 members. They had Rex Hardaker from the Coffs Harbour sporting group to do the official opening and name it the Leon Adams Lawn. Leon Adams is the club captain and has provided coaching. Probably the most outstanding year was 1992 when they had finalists in five state championships. So I thought it was appropriate to place on record the great success of the Sawtell Croquet Club.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also concerned about a number of Vietnam veterans in my electorate who have approached me. They were under the impression that, with the funds being allocated by the Australian Vietnam War Veterans Trust, there may have been some discrimination against veterans who were also TPI pensioners. I wanted to make this issue clear, and I have been in touch with the trust. I will just refresh the minds of those members present. In an out of court settlement after the class action, a sum of $5.5 million was provided to the trust to allocate to those Vietnam veterans who had been affected by contact with agent orange. I must say, too, that when they received that $5.5 million they invested it. Until June this year, over $6 million had been handed out to veterans in need.

I must say too that I am aware the staff of the trust have been very severely overworked. I pay tribute to them for doing an excellent job. They assure me there is no policy of discrimination in the allocation of funds from the trust against veterans who are TPIs. All applications go before a committee of five, and that committee is made up of delegates from Vietnam veterans, Legacy, RSL and AVADS and one female. The distribution of the money is determined on the individual circumstances. There is no means test. Each case is looked at individually.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have to indicate to the member for Cowper that the time allotted for this debate has expired. He may like to take up his temporarily compressed time with the Minister for Science and Technology, but in fact the time allotted for the debate has expired.
—I thank the Deputy Speaker.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Jull, on behalf of Mr Warwick Smith) agreed to:

That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House approves the following proposal for work in the Parliamentary Zone which was presented to the House on 31 October 1996: namely, construction of an extension to the National Gallery of Australia.
Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Dr Wooldridge:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) comprises two groups of measures. The first group of changes relates to limiting Medicare access for new medical practitioners. The second group of changes is a series of alterations to the medical benefits schedule. The majority of the budget changes to Medicare rebates took place with the issuing of the new schedule, which took effect last Friday. This bill contains a number of other changes which have to be made to the legislation itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to turn, first of all, to the changes which the government is seeking to introduce in limiting access for new medical practitioners to Medicare provider numbers. The opposition has grave concerns about the effect of the government's proposed changes to Australia's medical work force. The Labor Party certainly understands the importance of seeking to manage the medical work force, in particular of managing access to Medicare to ensure that the taxpayer and the Australian people get the best possible value for money.

The Labor Party also understands the need to ensure that those practising medicine in Australia are of the highest possible standard and are appropriately trained. In recent years it was the former Labor government which took a number of decisions aimed at limiting the number of overseas trained doctors coming to Australia and it was the former Labor government which worked with the medical profession to improve the standing of general practice and to develop a system of postgraduate training for general practitioners.

What the Labor Party did not do in government was to put in place a system which would retrospectively prevent existing Australian medical students and interns from having the opportunity to practise medicine. In our opinion, the government should have paid greater attention to reducing the medical school intakes and worked hard at restricting access for overseas trained doctors rather than simply attacking Australian trained medical students and interns who are currently halfway through their degrees. We do not believe it is right to disadvantage these students after they have put in years of study and training and after the taxpayer has invested in some cases more than $100,000 in their training.

I would like to turn to the element of this bill that seeks to retrospectively change the rules. Retrospectivity, as we all know, is a very blunt instrument in legislation. This legislation is highly retrospective. It significantly changes the career opportunities of a large number of young Australians after they have started their training—for some of them, seven years have passed since they made that career choice.

I imagine that most honourable members would be deeply disturbed by the fact that this legislation, if passed, will take effect from last Friday—that is, it will take effect from 1 November 1996. I would like to remind the House of some remarks which the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made when discussing the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill in 1983. In the committee stage he made the following remark, and he is referring to the legislation:

BREAK.PARA: I think it is a matter of some substance because we are dealing with a fairly dangerous animal when we are talking about using retrospective legislation in any circumstances.

So the Prime Minister certainly considers that any retrospective legislation is a dangerous animal. In fact, the current Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith), who in 1987 was the then opposition spokesman on legal matters, made some very impressive remarks about retrospective legislation. I would like to quote some comments he made at that time. The current Minister for Industrial Relations said:

One of the common justifications for retrospective provisions is the claim that any criticisms are met by the fact that a prior ministerial statement has outlined the proposed law. This practice is very much a common feature of this Government.
That was Mr Reith attacking the then Labor government. He went on:
It seems that Ministers are oblivious to the fact that it is Parliament that makes the law and not Ministers.
He goes on to quote a speech by Sir Anthony Mason to the Australian Legal Convention in July 1975. He said:

Ministerial edicts do not change the law—contrary to the belief of some. There is first the risk that the proposed alteration will not be made by Parliament and there is secondly the possibility, sometimes unfortunately realised, that the law, when enacted, will not correspond exactly with the antecedent announcement.
Mr Reith goes on to make the statement:
It is a practice which holds the Parliament, and thus the people, in contempt and it is wrong in principle in that it encourages retrospective legislative provisions.

There we have some views of the former Chief Justice—at that time he was a judge on the High Court, I understand. We have the current Prime Minister and the current Minister for Industrial Relations making it clear they thought it was wrong for the former Labor government to use retrospective legislation to close tax loopholes to tighten up the tax act, yet this government announced in August changes which were to take effect on 1 November.

We have been unable to obtain the legislation until a few weeks before it takes effect. In fact, the first opportunity that the opposition has to respond to the minister's second reading speech is three days after the legislation, if passed, takes effect. We all understand that it is quite possible that, with the current parliamentary backlog, it could be Easter next year before this legislation is debated and finally determined in the Senate.

The difficulty that the government faces is that when it was in opposition it altered the Senate standing orders. It did that in a deliberate way. In opposition, the Liberal and National parties argued that governments should only be entitled to introduce legislation in one session and have it determined by the Senate in the following session, unless the Senate gave agreement to a variation.

We certainly are concerned that the government thinks that it can introduce legislation which will be retrospective and will have a serious effect on the careers of many young Australians, and expects to have it debated within a few weeks before the parliament rises by the end of the year. That might have other consequences for the government that I will go into in a few minutes. As I say, any government that uses retrospective legislation has to be very careful because it is a very blunt instrument.

I imagine that people understand that the provisions of this bill were always going to be highly controversial, and it is our view that they should have been introduced immediately after the budget. While the budget was handed down in the third week or so of August the government and the ERC obviously made this decision some weeks prior to the budget's being publicly released. In the past governments have usually followed their announcements on budget night with the introduction of a whole package, a whole raft, of budget measures. This is on the very night that the Treasurer delivers the budget speech.

On this occasion, very little of the budget legislation is before the parliament. Quite a large number of proposals were announced on budget night, yet the parliament has not had a chance even to see the legislation or been able to have some idea as to the detail of the government's plans. I have to say that it is inexcusable that the minister was not able to introduce a bill—certainly a bill of this importance—into the parliament until four sitting days before it took effect.

The difficulty that the government faces is that if the Senate does not discuss or finally determine this legislation until next Easter, 1,200 young Australian doctors will be issued with provider numbers in January when they qualify to register. If the government is successful in having the legislation passed next year then some time, perhaps at Easter—if the legislation is passed—1,200 young Australian doctors, having received their provider numbers in January, will have their provider numbers taken off them when the legislation receives royal assent.

That is no way to run a health system, and it is no way to determine the future of the careers of those 1,200 Australians. I have heard rumours that the government was considering gazetting regulations which would have prevented those 1,200 doctors being able to obtain provider numbers in the early new year. I am pleased to say that I received assurances from the department and the minister's office that there is no intention to attempt to withhold these provider numbers if the legislation is not passed until next year. I am grateful for that assurance from those concerned.

Last week the minister made an announcement about his intention to introduce a 10‐year moratorium on overseas trained doctors. I did welcome that on that day, but I have to say that I do not think it goes far enough. The reason why we believe that this is only a half measure is that Dr Wooldridge's amendments to his own legislation affect only overseas trained doctors who arrive in Australia after 1 January 1997. I understand that to mean that Dr Wooldridge's current proposal, the moratorium, will still allow those doctors—as many as perhaps 200 a year—to register as medical practitioners and to compete with graduates from Australian medicals schools for jobs in public hospitals.

The opposition believes that the minister has also been too generous in allowing overseas trained doctors who are already in Australia open access to Medicare and other medical jobs once they pass the registration exams. On current estimates, more than 500 of this group will pass these exams and compete with Australian graduates for places over the next five years. But the number will be higher if the Australian Medical Council does not accept the minister's request that they limit the doctors in this group to two exam attempts over five years.

I would like to point out to the House that last Tuesday, when referring to overseas trained doctors who are already in Australia, the minister said, `They will have five years to have their skills assessed'—by the Australian Medical Council—`and they, too, will have two attempts to pass.' The minister gives the clear impression that this is going to affect the ability of overseas trained doctors to sit for the AMC exam.

It was only this morning that I learnt that it is actually only the minister's proposal to the Australian Medical Council. In fact, I got a clear impression, from the very strong words the minister gave to the House last Tuesday, of what the new rules would be for these overseas trained doctors. Yet we now learn that what the minister told the House would happen will occur only if the AMC agrees to the minister's suggestions. That is certainly a much weaker position. He went on to say:
. . . we have been mugs to allow ourselves to be one of the last Western countries to allow unrestrained medical migration.
If the minister feels so strongly, why is he taking only half measures? Why is he putting this 10‐year ban on only overseas trained doctors who arrive after 1 January next year?

In particular, if it is good enough for the minister to suggest to the Australian Medical Council that there should be new rules on how many occasions you can sit for the AMC exam, why will the minister not consider reimposing the limit on the number of overseas trained doctors who are allowed to proceed from the AMC's written exam to the AMC's clinical exam? I would like to spend a few minutes on that point.

The previous government imposed a quota on the AMC exams which effectively limited the number of overseas trained doctors who could work as doctors in Australia. This quota was challenged and overthrown by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission but, on appeal, the HREOC decision was reversed by the Federal Court. I am not a lawyer, but it now appears to me that there is, therefore, no legal barrier to the reimposition of a quota on the AMC exams at a level which will ensure that the students already in the system are not disadvantaged by these changes.

If we look at what happens in other countries, such as the United States and Canada, we see that it is very difficult for Australian trained doctors to practise medicine in those countries. A number of people have pointed out that Australia allows many more overseas trained doctors to practise here than those countries allow. I offered the minister, in a private conversation, bipartisan support from the Labor Party if he was willing to impose tighter restrictions on the access of overseas trained doctors to the clinical exam which is set by the AMC—that is, the reimposition of a quota much lower than 200. Unfortunately, the minister has not agreed to pick up that suggestion. I think that is to be regretted.

As a result of the minister allowing overseas trained doctors after 1 January to compete for places at public hospitals, and as a result of the minister's refusal to suggest to the AMC a tough new quota on the overseas trained doctors who are already in Australia, on my calculations that means as many as 1,500 overseas trained doctors will register and practise in Australia over the next five years in direct competition with the students in Australian medical schools and this year's interns—that is, they will be registering and practising in public hospitals as well as in general practice.

There is a good example which can be used to point out why we think this is wrong. When the minister was copping some flak from the Australian medical students and interns about this decision, he broke his holidays and went on the John Laws program on 25 September. He claimed that 32 Sri Lankan doctors came into Australia via New Zealand—I think it was last year or the year before that. He was actually critical of the former government for allowing that to take place. As a result of the minister's decisions, those 32 Sri Lankan doctors who came into Australia via New Zealand will be quite free to sit for the Australian Medical Council exams, whereas if the minister had taken up the opposition suggestion of a tough new quota we could have expected that it would have been more difficult for those 32 Sri Lankan doctors to be competing with the Australian trained medical students.

The main difficulty we have with this bill is that it is unfair to Australian medical students and interns. When the debate began the figures on which the savings were based assumed that about 200 Australian students and interns per year would miss out on provider numbers. Shortly after this, Dr Wooldridge, in that John Laws interview, said that very few Australian graduates would miss out on Medicare provider numbers. He claimed that the number would be fewer than 50 a year. More recently, I have noticed that Dr Wooldridge has become even more optimistic. In his press release last week he said that all Australian doctors and all Australian medical students and interns could expect to find a training place.

These figures have been very rubbery. On 25 September, Dr Wooldridge claimed that there would be 430 overseas trained doctors coming to Australia. Last week he told the House that late amendments to his late legislation would result in 600 overseas trained doctors being stopped. In a similar way, Dr Wooldridge told the House on 12 September that there would be up to 600 specialty training places available and by 15 October, again in this House, this number had miraculously risen to 760 places.

If the Minister for Health and Family Services believes his latest set of figures and if he really does believe that no Australian medical student or intern will miss out on a training place, and, therefore, a Medicare provider number, I simply ask: why has the minister refused to give those students and interns a guarantee that that will be the case? The reason why the minister is refusing to do this is that we know he does not have enough faith in his own rubbery figures to give this guarantee.
