If the Minister for Health and Family Services does not have enough faith in his own figures to give the guarantee, why should medical students have enough faith in him to trust him and these rubbery figures?

The Labor Party remains concerned that the proposal will also have an adverse effect on the provision of medical services in rural areas and on the options available to young doctors, particularly women medical students, who may not wish to proceed immediately after registration to full-time training.

I have had a chance to meet with a large number of the medical students and interns who will be affected by this legislation. It is not surprising that I have received contradictory advice from the claims the students and interns put to me and the claims put to me by officials from the minister's office and the department in the two briefings I have had with them, for which I remain grateful.

The women doctors, in particular, that I have spoken to make the point that, while the minister might be right in claiming that many of the colleges now allow women to take time off if they wish to have children or allow women to carry out some of their postgraduate training in a part-time way, many of the colleges continue to treat women unfairly in allocating places. If women do ask for some time off or ask to do their postgraduate training part time, they seem to be the ones who are less likely to gain a training place.

When we have an opportunity to discuss this bill in its consideration in detail stage, I will be seeking to move that this legislation be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs to allow a more open and thorough debate on these issues. I think consideration by the committee would allow members of this House an opportunity to search for a fairer plan and one that is not retrospective. While I am not optimistic that a majority of the House will vote in favour of that referral—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—Well, we had hoped that, with the power of our arguments, we could convince them. But unless the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) leads a mass crossing of the chamber, it is unlikely that that particu lar proposal from the Labor Party will be successful.

BREAK.PARA: Without wishing to be flippant about this measure, we do believe that this current plan, as it is currently proposed, is unfair. If more time were perhaps provided to allow additional pressure to be placed on the deans of the medical schools to reduce their intakes in the future and perhaps look at the full measures I have outlined to tighten access for overseas trained doctors, we might be able to come up with a package that could win the support of both sides of the House.

I would like to turn to schedule 3, which contains measures to ensure that temporary resident doctors who generally come to Australia to work in rural public hospitals on two‐year contracts will have to achieve the same standards with regard to post-graduate training before they are able to bill Medicare for their services. The date of effect of this element of the bill is, surprisingly, 1 November 1997, which means that those TRDs who are already here will be able to finish their contracts under the same conditions as when they signed them. This is appropriate and fair, but it also highlights that the government is prepared not to act retrospectively against certain groups of overseas trained doctors, but will not extend this same principle to students in Australian medical schools.

The explanatory memorandum for this bill says that the use of TRDs with lower qualifications `has been necessary in order to ensure access for patients in hospitals and in some rural and remote areas of Australia'. Despite this, the opposition has some concerns about the impact of Dr Wooldridge's plans for temporary resident doctors. However, I was pleased to note the minister for health's recent answer in the House to a question from the member for Dawson (Mrs De-Anne Kelly) when he said:
There is nothing in our changes on medical migration that will make it harder for rural communities to get a temporary resident doctor if they can find one.
We will be keeping a close watch on this particular measure to ensure that that commitment and undertaking is kept.

I turn now to schedule 2, which is the element of the bill that makes a whole series of changes to the Medicare benefits schedule. These changes include changes to the multiple services rule for diagnostic imaging, an increase in the greatest permissible gap to $50, and the removal of the Medicare Benefits Advisory Council's power to award higher than normal fees for unusually long or complex procedures.

I turn first to diagnostic imaging. Two of the Medicare related measures in this year's budget which the opposition believes do have merit are the reforms to pathology and diagnostic imaging. The government has recognised, as did the former government, that the very high growth rates in benefits for these services require action. In some ways they have built upon the model used by the former government in seeking to limit the cost of providing pathology services. I commend the government for its negotiations with the various elements of the profession in seeking to limit the levels of growth to more reasonable levels.

The multiple services rule for diagnostic imaging is part of an agreed package with the relevant part of the profession and is similar to agreements in place for multiple surgical services and multiple pathology tests. The opposition's concern is to ensure that these changes do not achieve these savings by cutting the fees for doctors, who then pass these directly on to patients. As I have explained, the opposition supports the principle and the approach of these reforms but we think the government and the HIC should continue to monitor billing practices in this area very closely to ensure that the agreed reforms do not mean that patients end up paying substantially more.

I turn now to the maximum patient payment. The coalition promised before the election that `Medicare would be retained in its entirety'. The minister for health wrote to his own constituents, in that famous letter to the residents of Box Hill, specifically promising that Medicare rebates would not be changed. This measure, which would increase the patient's maximum payment—that is, the 15 per cent difference between the Medicare recommended schedule fee and the 85 per cent Medicare rebate—from $30.60 to $50, is a clear example of a complete breach of faith on these two promises. It is a breach of faith on the Prime Minister's undertaking that Medicare would be retained in its entirety and the minister for health's undertaking to his own constituents that Medicare rebates would not be changed.

This measure is not small beans. It will raise nearly $60 million over four years. This money will be raised from those people who are seriously ill and require medical services with a schedule fee in excess of $200. It is hard to imagine how anyone could believe that this was a fair or reasonable measure. Even the minister does not seem to think so because neither the second reading speech nor the explanatory memorandum gives any reasons why it is appropriate to place an extra $60 million tax on those who are seriously ill. The minister is obviously not trying to defend the indefensible. This is also shown by his refusal to debate the atrocious decision to abolish the Commonwealth's dental health program last week. It is another example of a broken promise in health and it is a measure which simply ultimately ends up being a tax on the sick, and will be opposed by the opposition.

I turn now to the removal of the MBAC's power to award higher fees for unusually long or complex services. This measure is an example of the new government's arbitrary approach to cutting Medicare. The government plans to save around $5 million in a full year by removing doctors' rights to claim for unusual items. The MBS lists thousands of items which are designed to cover all medical services, but occasionally unusual things occur which have not been foreseen. The reason that the MBAC was given the power to determine these fees was to cover this possibility.

Perhaps I could give the House an example of why it is important that this committee continues to retain this power. Imagine if a rural general practitioner is called to an emergency on a remote property. She drives for more than an hour to reach the property and then finds that the patient has had an accident with a piece of farm machinery and has sustained a serious injury. The GP treats the injuries as well as possible, treats the patient for shock, assists the family and then accompanies the patient to hospital. The whole episode could take four hours. There is no item which properly covers this afternoon's work by the GP, so under the current arrangements this GP would write to MBAC and explain the circumstances of the case and the committee would then determine a fair fee.

If the same GP had instead done 16 quarter‐hour consultations in their surgery, Medicare would have paid them around $300. Under the minister for health's current proposal, these new arrangements mean that the maximum a GP could claim for this four hours of work is $70.30, the rebate for a long home visit consultation. This is not a reasonable fee in these circumstances, and the doctor is left with the unenviable choice of accepting this inadequate fee or asking the patient to make up the difference of up to several hundred dollars.

It is another example of arbitrary and unfair changes to Medicare which undermine our universal health insurance system and undermine the way that Medicare acts as a safety net to protect both doctors and patients in unusual circumstances. This measure will also be opposed by the Labor Party.

We also have some serious doubts about the way in which this particular measure was presented and the savings which are claimed for it. I understand that the amount paid out last year for unusually long or complex items was less than $½ million. So I am a little confused about how he can save $5 million a year from this. Looking through more of the budget material, I did find reference to the abolition of previous principles and precedents set by MBAC. If the savings from this part of the measure are up to 10 times that of the part we are being told about, then that is something that is more than a little misleading. I would be grateful if the minister could clarify that matter in his second reading reply.

PARA.BREAK: In summing up, in this budget we have seen a number of changes that begin the undermin ing of Medicare. Poor old Medicare—it is like that salami on the delicatessen's slicer. We have had reductions in rebates for women on the IVF program, we have had limits placed on rebates for people receiving psychiatric treatment and we have had reductions in rebates for knee and eye surgery. You may not now be reimbursed through Medicare for surgeons who assist in operations. Australians who seek to be trained as doctors are retrospectively having their careers affected by this legislation. We think many of these measures are ill thought out. In the detail stage, the opposition will be moving a number of amendments which will seek to express our concerns in some regard on these measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —After 13 years of Labor's mismanagement, the government has some tough decisions to take and some sound management decisions to bring to this area of health care on behalf of all Australians. Labor put private health insurance on the slippery slide. We now have incentives for those who take out private health insurance or who remain in it. Labor never met its two per cent medical research target, whilst the waiting lists for public hospitals have soared. The Labor government got nowhere with COAG and would not even place health on the policy agenda. The current Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has done more in the last six months in that area than Labor did in the previous two years.

SPEECH.PARA: Immunisation was left in a mess, but now we have public health common goals and targets put in place. Labor's neglect of Aboriginal health was also extraordinary and an international disgrace. We now, thankfully, have a minister who is getting on with the job and who has already secured agreements with the states, ATSIC and NACHO. The runs are going on the board, but there is much more to be done. The Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 that we are debating here today is about more positive change; change made necessary by the incompetence and failed management of the previous government.

PARA.BREAK: The member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) tried to reduce the number of students enter ing medical schools but failed. The current minister will do this in a cooperative manner. The large number of overseas doctors accessing the Medicare system was recognised as a problem by Labor, but they failed to grasp the matter and do something about it. Another testament to Labor's inactivity in this area was its inability and unwillingness to manage the problem of having an oversupply of doctors in some areas and an undersupply in others. This problem should have been addressed years ago. Labor's neglect caused this mess with a lack of ability to address the labour force issues.

SPEECH.PARA: A government can be expected to get work force issues and planning right when it spends $20 billion of taxpayers' money on health care. If it cannot, as is the case with the previous administration, costs blow out and the quality of care can be diminished. We need to get the balance right in various areas: hospitals, public health programs, general practice, various specialities and rural medicine. Labor got all this wrong. A healthy labour work force can never be entirely run on open market principles, and that is why good planning is required.

The changes in the bill relating to work force matters relate to the requirement for medical graduates to complete postgraduate education in order to gain access to Medicare benefits. In the transition period I have some sympathy with those young doctors who believe they will be affected. We believe, though, that there are enough training positions in the system to satisfy demands. I have no doubt that time will prove the minister right on this issue. In the meantime, I understand the fear and anxiety that change can bring about.

In the past, the provision of Medicare provider numbers has been demand driven. This government is seeking to return to a more balanced situation. One of the major cost pressures on the health system in Australia is the chronic oversupply of doctors, already estimated by the Australian Institute of Health at 4,500 nationally, and simultaneously a dangerous shortage of 500 general practitioners in rural areas such as the Murray Lands in South Australia and other rural and remote areas of Australia.

This legislation seeks to tackle both of these realities with four key strategies: reducing medical school intakes, reducing the numbers of overseas trained doctors migrating, reducing the need to bring in temporary overseas doctors to staff hospitals and, finally, getting a better distribution of doctors between rural and urban regions. The city of Adelaide, for instance, has one of the highest concentrations of doctors in Australia, with 194 practitioners for every 100,000 residents.

The slight reduction of intake levels at medical schools will be complemented by efforts to reallocate resources to the postgraduate level away from the undergraduate level. Given the timelag of six years for these measures to take full effect and the immediate crisis caused by the oversupply of doctors, however, the government must also reduce incentives for overseas trained doctors to migrate to Australia. The reality of the situation is that Australia has overly generous provisions for overseas trained doctors to enter Australia relative to other comparable countries. We have a situation where a large number of doctors are coming to Australia via New Zealand after only two years residency in that country. From 1 November 1997, temporary resident doctors will not be able to be deemed as medical practitioners for Medicare purposes unless they have the relevant overseas postgraduate qualifications.

The government has announced a 10‐year moratorium on the migration of overseas doctors from the beginning of 1997. Overseas trained doctors who are already resident in Australia will be given five years with a maximum of two attempts from the beginning of next year to complete the AMC process. There are approximately 3,000 doctors currently in this country who have not passed the AMC exams, although some have not indicated a desire to do so.

Some people will say these measures are tough, but others will say that we have been foolhardy to become one of the last countries in the world to restrict the supply of doctors coming to this country to access our publicly funded health system. I have heard Medicare called `industry assistance' in some of these situations.

The need for this legislation has been encouraged by the shortage of doctors willing to work in the public hospital system here in Australia. In the past, it has been just too easy for medical graduates to hang up a shingle and bill under Medicare whilst the states have been bringing in temporary overseas doctors. There were 606 such doctors brought into this country last year. It would be a dereliction of the Commonwealth's responsibility for this absurd situation to continue and a sad reflection on the mismanagement of former Labor health ministers that this situation exists for the government now to have to address.

We would all like to choose our place of employment, but the needs of Australia's health system are such that doctors now have to go where they are required and this may not always mean the first choice of graduates. This may take some time getting used to and it will require careful management and consultation. A package of $20 million per annum, for example, has been provided by the government to assist in medical work force adjustments and in particular to provide key support in rural areas.

Graduates in other professions such as law, engineering and teaching, especially early in their careers, are expected to travel to find employment, and there are many in the community who cannot see why medical graduates should be treated any differently.

This legislation signals the beginning of the difficult but necessary structural changes to address a crisis in the Australian health system which will only begin to rectify the situation created by the inaction of Labor. Under this government's changes, 1,500 new doctors will enter the system in 1997‐98, comprised of 1,200 new Australian trained graduates and a reduced number of overseas trained doctors.

Allowing for the 1,220 training places, with 100 of those being filled by overseas trained doctors, less than 100 medical graduates will be affected by the changes. As some graduates will want to move into other areas or take time out, the number is likely to be far less than that 100. There is more than enough capacity for this shortfall to be absorbed by the public hospital system and, in doing so, to begin to ease the onerous workload currently expected of doctors in public hospitals and identified by health professionals everywhere as another crisis resulting from the inaction of the previous administration.

Cutting the hours worked by hospital doctors to 50 per week would create, in itself, another 1,600 positions with minimum costs to the state governments as they would have overtime costs dramatically reduced. Surveys suggest that there are at least 400 such vacancies in public hospitals. Up to 150 scholarships will also be created by this government to enable medical students to spend some time training in rural areas. Nearly $4 million will be allocated to this initiative over the next four years. One million dollars in the next four years will also be allocated to improving the availability of locum services in regional areas to again relieve the overworked practitioners working in this area.

Through the additional allocation of $20 million per annum to rural hospitals and medical schools, the crisis in rural Australia has finally been recognised and is finally being addressed. The Australian government's health service has recently advertised for 60 new doctors at an attractive salary of around $75,000 per annum. Other opportunities exist within the Commonwealth government and various agencies. Fifty places were also made available in the army, navy and air force, which have suffered a shortage of medical staff in recent times. Other opportunities exist in mining companies, pharmaceutical companies and in academia in both teaching and administrative positions.

I believe that, whilst current graduates are caught in a difficult transition period, they should educate themselves about the many alternatives open to them, their relevance and ongoing worth to the Australian community and labour market, and the limited impact these budget measures will have on their futures or position. Any new doctor who wants to practise medicine will be able to do so. No doctor willing to work will be unemployed as a result of these measures. It is their right to unfettered private practice at taxpayers' expense that is being restricted to circumstances where they will have completed proper training.

New doctors will still be better off than virtually any other profession where significant numbers of graduates are in the unfortunate position of not being able to find any employment in their chosen fields. These measures to give provider numbers only to suitably trained doctors will, in fact, enhance the perception in the community of the role that doctors play in society. Given the relative explosion in medical research, new techniques and alternative treatments, general practice must now be considered a specialty in itself. It should not simply be accessed by practitioners who cannot or will not obtain specialty training in other areas.

The government must curb the critical and unsustainable growth in the use of Medicare funded services. In 1996 former Labor health minister Brian Howe said, `We believe we've got too many GPs out there in the field ordering up too many services.' It is this coalition government which, however, will do more than just recognise the problem.

This legislation is not an assault on medical graduates or students. It recognises that a crisis exists which cannot continue. The minister has acknowledged that these are tough measures but necessary if Medicare is to survive. There are certain realities that cannot be ignored any more. There are too many doctors with too many of them setting up in urban areas. There is also an unhealthy reliance by doctors on government outlays, which is unsustainable if growth remains unchecked.

It is estimated that it costs the Medicare system $170,000 every time another provider number is issued to a practitioner. This government should be commended for this responsible legislation to address this situation, and I commend the minister for his dedication to tackling the legacy left by Labor. This legislation is part of the broader agenda of this government to put into place a sustainable and fair health system which returns some sense to the balance between supply and demand in the provision of health services.

BREAK.PARA: I would also like to discuss the very important schedule 2 of this bill. This measure will allow negotiations to be made to reduce the Medicare benefits payable where multiple services are rendered. Multiple services rules recognise that there is an over-remuneration in the components of the fees where more than one service is rendered to a patient. These measures are sensible, are not random and are designed to keep pace with changes that have taken place in medical and surgical practice.

I commend the minister, who has undertaken extensive consultation in areas such as pathology to work out ways that these costs can be checked but at the same time ensuring that patients in no way suffer or have to pay more for it. It does impact on the overall cost to the system and helps make that health dollar go that much further.

This legislation will also increase the definition of the greatest permissible gap between the Medicare benefits schedule fee and the Medicare benefit payable from $29.30 to $50. The minister has worked hard, as I have said earlier, on consultation. I know he recognises that there are challenges ahead. But if Medicare is to be sustained and the system not collapse, then these changes are necessary. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, today I had the privilege of tabling a petition in the parliament. For your information and the interest of members, it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of NSW draws to the attention of the House that we the undersigned are totally opposed to the restriction of issuing of provider numbers to registered doctors unless they have entered a recognised training program, are vocationally registered or are a qualified specialist. We consider that such an action would cause serious suffering, including a severe disadvantage to women and rural communities and medical research. We believe that it is the essential right of all Australian registered doctors to have access to provider numbers that allow them to provide services which can attract Medicare rebates. We believe that such restrictions are an attack on the most defenceless and vulnerable strata of the medical profession and will not achieve the projected savings which it purports to do. We consider it to be a denial of natural justice, an attack on Medicare and un-Australian.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

Call upon the Federal Minister for Health the Hon. Michael Wooldridge MP, to enter into meaningful discussions with representatives of those groups most affected by the harsh and unconscionable decisions of his government.

That petition was signed by almost 1,500 people from Newcastle, mainly from the Hunter area. It was collected in just one day, on Friday. My constituents advised me that they could have had literally tens of thousands of signatures if they had wished to demonstrate an exercise in numbers. What they were trying to show the government was the level of concern that there is in the community and the level of support that doctors and medical students have.

This petition is particularly relevant coming from a place like Newcastle whose medical faculty has pioneered a community base for medicine which has seen a major shift in all the medical faculties towards a different set of criteria both for accepting students and, more importantly, as to how doctors and medicine are seen. Newcastle graduates are now quite famous for being more concerned about their patients and about wellbeing than necessarily about money. This bill in relation to provider numbers is most marked because it implies the opposite views of many of our doctors to be.

This issue is a difficult one. It is one that I do not profess to have all the wisdom on. I am puzzled by the fact that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) seems to be so confident of his position. I say that because I find it difficult to link up how they can evaluate the savings that are projected. I find it difficult to understand the shifting ground in terms of overseas doctors, registrations, quotas and the like. We keep seeing a constant shifting of numbers and conclusions as to what effects it will have. On the one hand the minister is saying to the students that it will not affect them very much yet at the same time he is talking about substantial budget savings.

BREAK.PARA: This is just one more chapter in the saga of making bad news sound good. It is essentially about cutting money. It is essentially about trying to find who you can soak next for some mythical conclusion. Yet we are being told constantly that it is about improving Medicare. The previous speaker, the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), talked about the bill improving Medicare, but that petition from doctors says that this is an attack on Medicare. That is the fact. It is an attack on Medicare; it is not a defence of Medicare, as the government keeps on pretending.

We are being told over and over that, unless this is done, Medicare will collapse. What a load of codswallop! What absolute nonsense! The only way Medicare will collapse is if those opposite keep on taking away its underpinnings so that there is nothing left. We know very well how that is done. We watched it from 1975 through to 1982—step by step, brick by brick. Medibank was still there in name—it became an insurance organisation—but the principles underpinning it and its essentials were white‐anted.

So every time this government says that this is essential to protect Medicare, I say to people in the community, `Watch out,' because it inevitably is going to hide yet another sneak attack. The people who are more likely to know are doctors and medical students, particularly those from Newcastle. If they are saying in their petition that it is an attack on Medicare, we should believe them because they are the ones who will know. Every time I hear the minister and his acolytes talking about somehow this decision being essential to protect and preserve Medicare, the warning bells get even louder and stronger.

The fact is that this government has retrospectively changed the rules seven years later. People who were contemplating enrolling for medicine or applying to do medicine around Australia seven or eight years ago, making their decision on what courses they chose in year 11—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break, I had been explaining to the House the concern that I have with the current govern ment constantly talking about improving Medicare, which is code for undermining Medicare. This has been emphasised very clearly by a petition presented to the House today on behalf of 1,500 people in the Newcastle area. Amongst other things, the petitioners point out that the amendments are an attack on Medicare. I think those in the medical profession in Newcastle who drafted the petition would be more accurate in understanding the impact of these amendments than the government itself.

BREAK.PARA: This is a new form of social engineering that the government is proposing. It tells people to go to university and to spend seven years training and, after that, it rearranges the rules and decides whether or not they can work. It is social engineering: nothing more; nothing less. It is interference in the rights of individuals who have made their choice to follow a particular career.

This has a number of consequences. The previous government had been successful in training young Aboriginals to become doctors. That program was started at Newcastle University in the mid‐1980s and has been successful. We now have doctors working in Australia of Aboriginal background, providing good medicine and good service to the community. They are also wonderful role models. They have shown that education was available and accessible. Young Aboriginals at school looking to their future as doctors see them as valid role models.

This new system means that those young people will have to find another way to become recognised in their communities because this impediment that is now being proposed will disrupt substantially what would have been their normal pathway. Young Aboriginals currently in medical faculties with the expectation of becoming doctors and servicing their communities will have to think again because of these changes. They are going to have to pass another hurdle to be accepted by the college. What that means, God only knows! None of us know and I am sure that the students do not know.

The point has been made very fluently by many doctors of the effect this will have on women. Many young women doctors do not work full time. They want to have families and share their child raising with their work. For them to go through this process is really going to be quite difficult and almost certainly untenable.

Young medical graduates undertaking research will be in a similar situation. We have relied very much on these people. They work part time as locums, while working in research. If there is no part‐time work, the capacity to be researchers will be taken away. We all know it is there. We have used that system very successfully, and it has been good for all of us. It has been good for them because it has meant that some of our best and brightest could go into the research field and not have to be paid up to the full scale because they could work part time and augment their income. In effect, they were not only doing research on the cheap but also getting experience in medicine and keeping up their skills. That will clearly change.

These are all the things that the government should have talked about. It is not unreasonable for a government to propose changes to the system. That is what governments are there for. This was not a proposed change. This change was announced as a fait accompli. I did not hear any members opposite discussing this over the last six months, during the campaign or before the budget. I did not hear it being canvassed or it being suggested that this was the outcome of a series of public discussions or debates of any kind. It was announced on budget night as a fait accompli not to improve the health system but to achieve a certain revenue objective.

I said earlier that one wonders about and questions the validity of the numbers and the extrapolations. We, on this side, accept that there may be some validity. If you recall, in the previous parliament we looked at reducing the numbers of students going into medicine—not by restricting those who were coming out from being able to practise but by curtailing entrance into training programs, which would have an effect. It would be foolish of us to say that there may be no linkage. Certainly, in that discussion a couple of years ago a lot of people suggested that our data and our conclusions may have been faulty. But we were discussing it at the entry point, not at the exit point.

If we had heard those opposite canvassing this view with the community, with the medical fraternity, with their own backbench in some public way, then what would have come forward would have been the result of a process. What we have had is not a process at all; it has been a railroading. Those doing it are not doing it for the good of doctors, patients or the health system; they are doing it because of some mythical notion that they have on what can be spent on health vis‐a‐vis which part of health. The whole notion of how to apportion public expenditure is valid.

We have heard previous speakers talking about the effect of government spending and how the last government did dreadful things, and so on. The fact is that, during the time of the last government, the amount of public spending went down as a proportion of the country's wealth and capacity and the spending on health was maintained at a very regular level, and in world terms it was at a very respectable level. There has been no massive blow‐out in health costs. There has been no unacceptable surge or disproportionate spending on health vis‐a‐vis other issues.

The idea that this is somehow essential to save Medicare or to save the nation is just a nonsense. If the government had proposed this as a course of action for discussion, then we would have been happy to have discussed it. It would have been an interesting and perhaps useful discussion. If this was done, I do not doubt that at the end of the day the conclusion would have been quite different from what has been put forward now. If this had been discussed openly, it would have been found to be very unfair and very discriminatory.

There is no reason why those young people who are currently embarked on a medical career of seven years duration or one year's duration should suddenly find the whole world changed without having had the chance to comment. The opposition, in proposing that these matters go to a parliamentary committee, is attempting to correct that failure.

The fact is that these amendments will not get through the parliament in this calendar year. They will sit in the Senate for months to come. That will be non-productive, anyhow. The fact is that these amendments were only brought in last week. They came in at the end of October, after being announced in August, and it is now November. That is appalling. That delay and that lateness by the government indicates that they consider this legislation to be of low priority—measures that came into force, supposedly, last Friday. The legislation came into the parliament last week, four days before it was to take effect. What a disgraceful performance. What an insult to these people.

Rather than having these amendments sitting in the Senate doing nothing, the idea of them going to a committee allows for there to be some public input. The government may well find that there are better ideas available. It may well find that there are other consequences or impacts that it has not thought about.

Clearly, the government has not thought about these amendments very much at all. To watch what has come forward and to watch the government attacking the messenger, if you like—and I notice that the remarks of the minister have been increasingly hostile—indicates that very little thought went into this. No cogent argument has been put forward in their support. There simply has been this mantra that `this is to save Medicare' somehow.

PARA.BREAK: The fact is that that does not wash with anybody with any depth of knowledge on this issue. It certainly does not wash with anyone with any sense of compassion if you are to save Medicare, supposedly—and that is a nonsense—at the expense of your own credibility and at the expense of the careers of many young people. Those young people, I can assure the government, are extremely angry—and not just angry, but well informed. They see this for the charade that it is and are offended at the way with which it has been dealt. They are offended that they were not given a chance to talk about it or even canvass it in any form whatsoever. Whatever they have put forward since the announce ment was made has been attacked by the minister and by the government.

BREAK.PARA: I just point out that, in the Brisbane Courier‐Mail, which is not known to be a radical newspaper or a supporter of the Labor Party in any form—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's called Pravda up in Queensland.

—I would have thought the member would have had different views. Most Australians, I would have thought, would consider the Courier‐Mail to be a fairly conservative newspaper. An article in that newspaper quotes the minister as saying:

BREAK.PARA: . . . some young doctors had made wildly inaccurate claims about the effects of government policies on their job prospects . . .

Here he is, `on their job prospects', attacking them. This is the minister who will not give up his Medicare provider number for somebody else. If he had said, `Okay, I'll turn my number in and a young graduate can have it' he might have had some credibility. But this is two-jobs Michael: he wants to be both a minister and a practitioner. This is the guy who wants to lecture them about their job prospects, whilst having two jobs of his own. He is so committed and so confident of his future that he cannot turn in his provider number. What kind of message is that sending to these people?

But the minister then goes on to say that he would be disappointed if his comments were seen to be an attack on doctors. Sure, these people are not doctors yet—and a lot of them never will be now, in the real sense of the word. They may be able to call themselves doctors, but they will not be able to charge for their services because they will have to go through a whole stack of hurdles and hoops. If this legislation is passed, we will all expect—and with some justification, I think—the hurdles to become more and more complicated.

Once you get change into the first level, it is much easier to change the curriculum, the entry levels, the assessment—and who makes decisions as to who will be the 400? Is it done with marbles? Will we have a lottery for them, as with the old conscription system back in the 1960s? Will it be done on birth dates? Will it be done on their sex? Will it be all males or all females? Who knows? Will there be another set of exams around Australia comparing graduates from Newcastle, Sydney, and everywhere else? What kinds of hurdles will be involved? Who will be the judges? Will the minister judge? He is drawing the rules up for someone else to administer.

This is social engineering of the very worst kind because it is blind. It has no social basis, no thesis on which it is founded and, therefore, no rules that will govern its operation. This is blind stuff—pick a number out of the air; quantify X million dollars and give it to someone else to administer. And you wonder why these young people are so angry! These people will stay angry. Whatever happens, they will stay angry.

This government has done itself a great deal of harm in the eyes of some of Australia's best and brightest young people. What stupidity. Why has the government done this—to save Medicare? They say no; they say the opposite. I also thought some of the comments that have been made by some of the other commentators are interesting. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you yourself have time to go through them, given the debates of the last 13 years on health and Medicare, I think you also would find very ironic the situation in which you are being placed now as the latest and best social engineers par excellence.

PARA.BREAK: In the amendments other changes also are being proposed which are again sleight-of-hand—and they are changes to the complex procedures. I think we all understand that this has been a capacity which has been rarely used. A very small amount of money per year has been involved in that, but it did give a capacity for very special cases to be dealt with. That being wiped out is quite stupid, particularly for those of you with rural electorates where doctors may be toiling for many hours on what may end up being a very minor case but on which, because of isolation, complexity and access to transport, they could in fact spend a long time. I am surprised that you are supporting this. No, I am not sur prised. I guess I should know better by now. I am not surprised at what the government does any more. I may have been for the first few weeks, but not since the budget.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, the other part that is of concern is the question of how we are to work out the issue of overseas doctors. That is a much more complex issue than the minister is letting on. From our inquiry last year, which included that area, this issue will not be settled quite so simply. These amendments should be voted down. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address some of the issues raised by the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) when I finish what I have prepared to say. The Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 is a piece of legislation that will not only secure the longer term viability of Medicare, contrary to what we have just heard, but with it the professional and financial base of general practice. It will do so through changes to the availability of Medicare provider numbers and measures to contain growth in two areas which have been of major concern to the previous government and also this one and that is in pathology and radiology.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill introduces changes in three important areas, the first of which is Medicare provider numbers. From 1 November 1996 only those who have either trained, whether it be in specialist or general medical practice, or those who are in the process of training in a supervised training program will be issued with a Medicare provider number. A provider number, for those who do not know, is necessary before a service provided by a medical practitioner will attract a Medicare benefit. The estimated savings over the four years of the forward estimates are in the vicinity of $570 million. But I do accept the concerns of those who wonder how we may have arrived at that figure. Who knows? It may be higher. Let us hope it is not lower.

The second major area of change is Medicare benefit restructuring, most notably in pathology where benefits will increase by six per cent in the next financial year but with a cap on the total funds available for pathology triggering a reduction in fees should the amount of money being spent go over budget in the pathology area. This form of agreement is historic.

As someone who has represented the medical profession in my former life I believe that people should not underestimate the importance of the arrangement at which the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has arrived with the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia, the Australian Association of Pathology Practices and also the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists in radiology restructuring.

For the first time we have an agreement in a fee for service system which will cap the total amount of money which the Commonwealth will commit to a particular program. There is provision for renegotiation of the agreement to take into account significant changes in the emergence of significant new tests and diseases. The savings there are not insignificant—$344 million are anticipated over the four years of the forward estimates.

In a similar fashion, radiology restructuring, including nuclear medicine, which will be implemented progressively from 1 November 1996, has been developed in cooperation with the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists and the Australian and New Zealand Association of Physicians in Nuclear Medicine. The measures will promote more appropriate, quality, cost-effective diagnostic imaging practice by introducing multiple service rules—similar rules apply in surgery—so that, if a radiology provider provides one service and then in conjunction with that a second one is provided, that second service and subsequent services may attract a lower benefit.

Similarly, there are targeted changes to fee relativities, item restructuring and a move toward capital sensitive items, which has to be in the interests of everyone, particularly radiologists who are spending an enormous amount of money on capital and also patients who rely on the services being provided. The benefit needs to relate in some way to the capital intensive nature of the service being provided.

The other important thing for which the minister has not been given specific credit— and I include the medical profession in that—is a review of the ultrasound arrangements in light of the forthcoming report by the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee. Over the next two years an accreditation system will be developed in consultation with both professional bodies. I think that reflects a growing maturity at least in the pathology and radiology areas of the medical profession. Again, $241 million over the four years of the forward estimates is a significant contribution to turning the government's deficit into surplus.

However, the most contentious aspect of the bill is the decision to restrict Medicare provider number eligibility to medical graduates who have either successfully completed postgraduate training or who are in the process of undertaking such training. Given the complexity of modern general practice and the reasonable demands of community expectation, it is not unreasonable to expect someone who has completed an undergraduate degree to specifically train for family medicine. A six-year degree does not, even though it is long and arduous, prepare you for family medicine.

I remember when I left the teaching hospital environment I spent six months working in a neonatal intensive care unit. When I went into general practice I could resuscitate a baby; in fact, I could do almost anything with a seriously ill baby, but the problems people bring their children to you for in general practice are quite different. These days, despite what some students may feel, it does require formal postgraduate training. As such, I think this measure is to be applauded.

Such training can only raise the professional esteem of general practice and, ultimately, secure the financial base of a discipline that will require a total of 10 years of rigorous training. When those on the other side, as they most certainly have done in the past and I am sure will continue to do, criticise the incomes of doctors, just remember that they have to get in the top one per cent to get in there in the first place. They will then have to take 10 years of extremely rigorous training. They will have to go through all kinds of hoops. We are now introducing the last of them: having completed their degrees, only a limited number will be able to get into postgraduate training. People ought to hose themselves down a bit when they criticise the incomes of these people once they finally get there.

From the government's perspective, there is also the pressing economic need for such a decision as there is a clear relationship between the number of doctors there are and the expenditure on the medical services. For example, in metropolitan Sydney the number of pathology services provided per head of population is seven times higher than in rural New South Wales. This year the Commonwealth will spend about $19.4 billion on health. In 1995-96 the Labor government allocated $18.4 billion. Of the $7.3 billion allocated for the Medicare benefit schedule about $6.1 billion is budgeted this year to flow directly to doctors who are billing services reimbursed under Medicare.

Outlays on Medicare services grew at 9½ per cent a year between 1985 and 1994, mainly because of the increase in per capita number of services provided annually to patients. The member for Newcastle, who understandably is concerned about the sustainability of Medicare, ought to reflect on the fact that 9½ per cent growth per annum over a decade and 5½ per cent real growth per annum over the last three years is hardly a recipe for sustainability. Any responsible government, if it is committed to Medicare, has to do something substantial to address that.

Over the past three years—it is worth focusing on that for a moment—there has been 5½ per cent real growth per annum. Those in business, I am sure, would love to see growth of those proportions, but in a government expenditure program you simply cannot sustain that. Particularly, it is unsustainable in an economy with an underlying growth rate of between two per cent and three per cent.

The number of providers—that is, the number of doctors—increased from 27,807 in 1984 to 39,812 in 1994-95. Over the same period of time, the Australian population increased 14.6 per cent. So there was a disproportionately large growth in the number of providers when contrasted with the general growth in population.

In an environment where, by the very nature of medical practice, the consumer or patient is unable to know whether they really do need the service and providers have an obvious interest in providing it, the process is further skewed by the absence of a price signal to the consumer in over 70 per cent of cases, which of course refers to bulkbilling. It is little wonder, then, that doctors have at times powerful incentives to drive service provision to a level that meets income expectations. That is why we find that doctors working in overdoctored areas, particularly in inner Sydney and Melbourne, are able to sustain an income where one might reasonably question whether there is sufficient demand for the services they are providing.

Although I appreciate that this is a contestable statement, the recent Australian medical work force benchmark study, prepared by the Australian Medical Work Force Advisory Committee, estimated that on the basis of a reasonable patient workload there is a 19 per cent oversupply of equivalent full-time general practitioners in Australia, most of whom are in capital cities—930 in Sydney and 414 in Melbourne.

The provision of services seems to reflect doctor presence as well as patient need. In order to give members an understanding of that, looking at the Medicare benefits paid per capita in a number of electorates will illustrate the point. For the year 1993-94 for example in Kalgoorlie, Medicare spent $137 per head of population. In the New South Wales electorate of Parkes, $229 was spent per man, woman and child. In Wentworth in Sydney, $461 was spent per man, woman and child. In Melbourne Ports, $413 was spent.

Morbidity and mortality figures are worse in rural areas, yet the per capita Medicare expenditure is lower. Every extra general practitioner practising full time generates 7,000 services annually and costs about $200,000 in Medicare outlays. At the moment, the net number of doctors billing under Medicare is growing by just over two per cent a year, or around a thousand a year. If these doctors go into city areas, the net gain to the community is marginal, but the cost to the taxpayer is extremely high.

The real contributor to growth in the net number of active doctors, those who are actually using their provider numbers—the member for Newcastle, with this nonsense he is on about, ought to remember that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is not practising at the moment; he is putting 200 per cent of his time into trying to turn around the mess we were left by the previous government—for billing under Medicare, which, as I said, reached 39,812 in 1994-95, was overseas trained doctors. In fact, the overseas share of growth each year for the last decade has averaged about 25 per cent each year. In 1994-95, for example, 758 local graduates became active using Medicare provider numbers, whereas 303 overseas trained doctors commenced the use of provider numbers. In other words, the number of local contributors to Medicare utilisation was double that of those coming from overseas.

Given the announcements by the government of new arrangements for overseas trained doctors, I hope that the government may be able, as we go along—this is a personal perspective—to reconsider a short program, perhaps over a period of a few years, to constantly keep under review the number of training positions which are available in general practice. If there is, as I hope will appear, a significant reduction in the number of overseas doctors taking up provider numbers, then perhaps if things are not working out for our current crop of medical students and interns we may still be able to come in well underneath the forward estimates in the budget, maintain the integrity of the budget and make sure that those who wish to have access to general practice training. I am confident that the minister will be keeping the situation under review.

If you examine the issue of overseas trained doctors, you see that there has been a sharp increase in the number of New Zealand doctors. For example, in 1994-95 there was a net increase—that is, those coming in less those going out—of 182 from New Zealand. Most of those went to Queensland and New South Wales; however, when you look more closely, you see that many of the New Zealand registered doctors were actually born in third country locations. For example in 1994-95, 232 New Zealand citizen doctors arrived. Ninety-six were not New Zealand born. Of those, 39 were from Sri Lanka, 23 were from the UK and 10 were from India.

At the moment there are up to 2,000—this is another major problem—migrant doctors living in Australia who are yet to begin the accreditation process. Of these, according to the census data I could see, there are 857 Chinese born. These are persons who claim medical qualifications at degree level living in Australia as at 1991, yet only 37 are actually practising as doctors.

The other issue this bill will be addressing is temporary visa doctors. The bill requires equivalence of qualification but, with the agreement of the minister, labour work force agreements will enable continued use where it is essential. I think that is a point worth making for those in regional seats and those who are, understandably, concerned about doctors getting into rural areas. Temporary visa doctors will still be able to come. The minister will be required to make sure they meet a standard which is acceptable here in Australia. But, importantly, the minister will be able to use discretion in making decisions.

In 1995-96, about 600 of the total 870 visas issued were to newly sponsored doctors entering from overseas, the great majority of whom arrived in the past year. They need to be sponsored by an employer, of which Queensland is the dominant source. Four hundred and eighty-one sponsors were approved in 1994-95 and 383 were approved last year, despite a labour market agreement of 65, hence the value, if you like, of labour market agreements for the medical work force.

PARA.BREAK: The implications of this high dependence on temporary visa doctors is rather serious. Because visas can be renewed and a temporary visa doctor can stay in Australia potentially for up to four years, there may be as many as 2,000 temporary visa doctors in Australia. Although many of them are sala ried, many actually work, particularly in Queensland, as medical superintendents, with limited rights at private practice and therein access to Medicare provider numbers, and also as locums. These people are obviously adding significantly to the provider induced growth in Medicare outlays.

SPEECH.PARA: So when we talk about the excess capacity of undergraduates who may not be employed in the private sector, it is worth keeping in mind the number of doctors coming from overseas who are currently providing services which Australians clearly need and which Australian graduates are unwilling or unable to fill.

People need to understand—this gets to the heart of where the concern is—that young doctors and interns are not opposed to the idea of postgraduate training. What they are concerned about is the fact that there is a limit to the number of training positions that are available. For example, this year there were about 550 applicants for the 400 positions available for the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners training program. But as someone who knows these people inside out and back to front, I can also tell you that within that 550 will be a group who do not really know what they want to do. Their cut‐off date for application was in July. They do not really know what they want to do but, just to cover bases, they will apply for a training program, in this case general practice training.

PARA.BREAK: A summary of the picture that we now face is that we have 1,200 Australian graduates a year. That is down from around 1,500 in the mid‐1980s. In Australia we decided that we had a need to reduce the number of doctors, so we started planning to do that. At the same time we had an exponential growth in the number of doctors wishing to come here from overseas. The overseas trained doctors now, pre‐January 1997, will be able to sit the Australian Medical Council exam twice. I understand there may be a very small quota on those who will be able to then get access to the College of General Practitioners training program. After January 1997 there will be no limit, but they will not be able to get a provider number for 10 years. That is emi nently reasonable to say the least. In fact, personally, I think it ought to be longer.

SPEECH.PARA: For those 1,200 graduates we produce now in Australia—depending on which figures you wish to accept—the minister and the department are suggesting that the number of training positions in specialist practice may be as high as 760; some would suggest even higher. We also have 400 positions at the moment in the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and another 20 positions in subspecialties in family medicine—for example, sports medicine and venereology.

For the rural work force, this bill addresses things which are very important to people in rural areas. Young doctors will be able to get temporary provider numbers to go and do locum and relief work for doctors in rural areas. That work is to be negotiated, but those who go and work for, perhaps, three or four years in a rural or regional hospital will then get preferential access to the College of General Practitioners training program and 18 months credit for what they have already done.

The temporary visa doctor labour work force agreements will be maintained and the minister will have ministerial discretion over that, which is essential. We still have $16 million a year going to the rural incentives program. We have put $20 million a year into a program to help the rural hospitals employ young doctors. We have provided $1 million a year to assist in employing locums in rural areas and $26 million over four years to establish university departments of general practice.

Those 100 or so who miss out on training positions approximates the number who do generally pursue salaried, research, administrative and other non‐clinical positions. With the overseas trained doctor position, there is, I believe, within the confines of the budget, the option possibly available to the government at a later date to closely monitor and perhaps re‐examine the number of training positions which are, in fact, available in family medicine.

Whilst this bill deals specifically with the supply side measures, how much longer can we cling to the noble but, in my opinion, unsustainable notion of a free health care service for all as often and as much as we want irrespective of the financial and social circumstances we are in? At some stage in the future the government of Australia will have to address that issue, but at the moment this government is very committed to maintaining the bulk‐billing arrangements—I think people know my views on this, but such are the disciplines of being in government, I will be supporting this bill and obviously supporting the policies of the government. This is a very important measure. Those students and young graduates who have portrayed the minister as being uncaring are completely out of order. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of Medicare was probably the former Labor government's most important social reform. It ensures basic medical and hospital cover for all Australians and we should all take an active interest in its survival.

SPEECH.PARA: Those of us on this side of the House certainly share the government's determination to keep the costs of Medicare under control because we all know that coalition members do not really believe in it and we must be forever vigilant to ensure that they do not find an excuse to abolish it.

We know that they resent its success. We know that they dislike its universality. We know, as I said when speaking to the national health pharmaceutical amendments bill, that members on the other side resent the fact that Medicare has been so overwhelmingly embraced within the Australian community. They resent the fact that Australians love Medicare and they resent the fact that, as a consequence, they have been forced to put aside their ideologically driven feelings on Medicare—put those on the backburner—and at least appear to, at this stage, be supporting Medicare. We must beware of the wolf in sheep's clothing. When seeking to find the government's real attitude to Medicare, we really need to go back to 1993 and John Hewson's Fightback program.

Fightback was of course a blueprint for Medicare's destruction. It would have been a body blow to all those Australians with the least ability to cushion the blow—low income families and the aged in our community. We do need to be forever vigilant to ensure that Medicare remains strong and remains financially viable in order to keep the wolves on the other side at bay.

But what a strange way to keep the costs of Medicare under control. What another arbitrary approach to the problem. The Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) will deny medical graduates a Medicare provider number if they have not completed postgraduate education. The measure will deny up to 400 Australian graduates the right to practice.

I do not challenge the concept that graduates should undertake postgraduate training prior to being allowed to practice as general practitioners. My great concern is the fact that this bill does act retrospectively and will hit medical students for six. Young Australians who have now spent up to six years studying to be a general practitioner will be absolutely devastated if this bill is adopted in this form.

In order to provide honourable members with a real life example of the impact this will have on medical students, I want to read for the House a copy of a letter sent to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) from a constituent of mine who has a son in his final year at medical school. He says:

The Coalition has through the election campaign, and its brief period in government, promoted its image as the paragon of sound and responsible economic management. Even the most junior manager knows that an organisation's most economic resource is the motivational and intellectual quality of its people. It is elementary management practice to demonstrate to the stakeholders in any system that they are highly valued.

It is therefore incomprehensible to the logical thinking elector, that your Department intends to put on the scrap heap the aspirations of at least 400 + per year of the brightest young people the schools and universities are able to produce. I of course refer to the budget proposal to limit the number of Medicare Provider Places. It makes no economic or political sense to create a large pool of disgruntled and hostile young doctors within the Health Care System.
Of course, we have seen some examples of that over the last few days—that is, the disgruntlement among students and young doctors. He goes on to say:

Both your training and experience as a practising doctor added to your political experience at a consistently high level must make you one of the best qualified Ministers for Health that this Country has seen. It therefore saddens me greatly that you have allowed the Public Service to lose the plot so badly on the issue of young doctors and the demographics of rural medical practice.

My own experience of dealing with and observing the Public Service culture tells me that the Government has induced a budget cutting fever into that culture. Regrettably the Public Service often behaves like an animal trained to perform useless tricks to please its political master. Quite clearly, on this issue the Public Service mind set has been to throw up any scheme to meet the imperative without spending the time or having the wit to arrive at a better solution.

The virtual reality portrayed on the Public Service computer screens bears little relation to the real world. Fiscal measures resulting from a simplistic internal beam country exercise do not take into account the true financial cost to the community and individuals or the political consequences.
Your professional colleague and Parliamentary counterpart in NSW ultimately trusted his own professional and political judgement having been let down badly by the Public Service advice.
As a medical consumer whose family has collected some pages of signatures to the AMA petition to the parliament, I urge you to consider this matter.

Mr Graham Smith, the author of that letter, also provided me with a copy of a petition to the minister containing some hundreds of petitioners from my own home town of Cessnock. I want to say, without risk of embarrassing or offending my constituent, he is by no means a paid‐up member of the Australian Labor Party, but he does have a son in his final year of medical school. It has been suggested that the cost to the family of putting his son through medical school is in the order of some $400,000, and that is without taking into account the cost imposed on the government and the taxpayer. Mr Smith is very distressed about his son's prospects, and understandably so.

What about the impact the move will have on female graduates? In recent years there has been a marked and healthy increase in the number of female graduates entering the field of medicine. A survey recently undertaken by the New South Wales medical board showed that 36 per cent of medical practitioners working in New South Wales who are between the ages of 24 and 40 are female. In the range of 50 to 75, women make up just 13 per cent of the medical work force. This sudden restriction on the availability of Medicare provider numbers, I fear, will set back that healthy growth in the participation rate of women. In addition, postgraduate programs tend to be too rigid and are dominated by a male culture. Work needs to be done to change this culture before enforcing postgraduate requirements.

My overriding concern is about the impact this bill will have in rural Australia where, as many in this place know—or all should know—we have a shortage of some 500 GPs. For me, it is perfectly logical and, indeed, simple arithmetic that, if you reduce the total pool of medical practitioners, you by virtue of that then exacerbate the shortage of doctors in rural Australia. Surely, that is incontestable.

TALK.START.PARA: —We've got a good rural package.
—You do have a good rural package.
—Order! The member for Hunter will address his remarks through the chair and will be heard in silence.

—The government does have a good rural package. I am pleased to see that it has maintained the previous government's commitment to rural adjustment, but it is not happening quickly enough—nowhere near quickly enough. A lot more work needs to be done, and that work should be done before taking this very drastic action.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the extent of the problem in towns in my electorate. The parliamentary research paper on this bill tells us that the ratio of doctors to residents in New South Wales ranges from 183.2 GPs per 100,000 people in Sydney to some 67.9 per 100,000 people in the Murrumbidgee. I can break down those figures even further.

In the town of Merriwa in my electorate, the ratio is about one doctor for 1,175 people or, to work on the 100,000 population basis, 43 doctors for every 100,000 people. In the township of Singleton, we have one doctor per 1,428 people or, to use that same ratio again, 70 doctors per 100,000 people.

So the problem in my electorate is very real. Of course, the shortage of rural doctors in country towns has an impact on the local economy. A further reduction in the service of GPs may very well represent the final nail in the coffin of many rural towns. We have seen so many attacks on regional and rural Australia since this government was elected only seven months ago—the abolition of the division of regional development and the revocation of drought assistance in many areas of my electorate. Things like the sale of Telstra, cuts to labour market programs and cuts to skillshare impact disproportionately upon towns in rural Australia. This shortage of GPs represents another whack indeed. It is a real threat to rural Australia.

At my final meeting as a councillor with Cessnock City Council, the council was actually considering a notice of motion, from one of my fellow councillors, suggesting that the council needed to somehow act to subsidise the rent of a GP practising in Greta, a town in my electorate, in order to retain that doctor. The councillor could see what a devastating impact the loss of that doctor could have on that town. While obviously it may have been a little bit foolhardy for the council to get involved in such practices—something outside of its jurisdiction—it was a very good example of how badly the shortage of a doctor can impact upon a town.

Of course, equity in health implies that everyone should have a fair opportunity to attain their full health potential and, more pragmatically, that no-one should be disadvantaged from achieving this potential if it can be helped. It is so important that we make health services just as available in rural Australia as they are in our urban and city areas.

The approach the government has taken attempts to tackle the problems highlighted in the system in a very reactive rather than what I believe should be a pro‐active manner. As I said, the former government did have in place a number of fine initiatives, among them the rural incentive program, to encourage a more equitable distribution of general practitioners across the country.

We were negotiating with the universities to ensure that more places were given to rural students. At the end of the day, it is those people from rural Australia who are more likely to return to rural Australia. This is a very important area and one on which the government should be placing far more concentration rather than using this very blunt tool. As I said, I note that the government has maintained its commitment in some of these areas, but it needs to do much more, rather than simply use this very blunt tool of restricting Medicare provider numbers.

Let us have a look at what some groups in my electorate are doing with some of those incentives introduced by the former Labor government. The University of Newcastle has used a $134,000 grant, funded by the Rural Undergraduate Steering Committee, originally as part of the rural incentives program, to develop undergraduate medical education in rural areas. Students now spend their general practice attachment in year 5 in a rural area, and that is compulsory. Fifty students from the first and second years will be doing electives in rural areas this year. More than half the second-year students have done population medicine research projects on rural health.

Students from rural areas are now eligible for entry into the Newcastle University medical course with a TER of 85, whereas urban and city students are expected to achieve a TER of 90. They are trying to encourage more students from rural high schools to apply for entry into medicine at Newcastle. All of these initiatives were originally funded by the Labor government. Fortunately, it appears that the government is embracing them. But much more needs to be done, rather than turning to this very blunt tool.

I welcome Dr Woodridge's announcement about the 10-year moratorium on overseas trained doctors. But both the opposition and I are concerned that the proposals do not go far enough. I simply want to support what our shadow minister has had to say about the expansion in the maximum gap payable under the Medicare schedule fee. I think this is just another arbitrary figure drawn down. I think that what is happening with most of these measures is that the government works out what sort of money it wishes to raise, divides it among the services and works out what the charge should be.

For example, the pension co-payment for pharmaceuticals: work out a general revenue target and work out what you then need to increase the pharmaceutical co-payment by. The same applies to the $20 for non-concessional cardholders—another arbitrary figure. This is starting to be a clear mark of the approach of the government to many of its budgetary initiatives. I support our shadow minister in what he has had to say about that.

I call upon the House to reject this proposal as an overreaction and a measure which gets it all wrong. It puts the cart before the horse. I implore the government to go back to the drawing board and start working very hard on addressing this problem we have in rural and regional Australia before it gets the blunt tool out and screws medical students to the wall. It is about time that this government realised that people should come before money. It really is out of control in its determination to wind the budget back into surplus. Really, if it put in place initiatives to promote economic growth, that problem would take care of itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) has raised this issue of the problem about rural doctors because that is precisely the reason why I support the measures in this Health Insurance Amendment Bill. He quoted figures from his electorate. I note that my electorate is mentioned in the same document. It has the worst figures in the state of Victoria in its proportion of rural doctors—70.7 per 100,000. So no-one is more conscious of the difficulty that rural hospitals and rural practices have in attracting Australian doctors than I am.

PARA.BREAK: Given the member for Hunter's comments, the problem is that he does not really understand how this particular measure in this bill fits into a suite of policy measures being addressed by the government. The govern ment has recognised the serious nature with regard to the supply of rural doctors. I am pleased to have the support—finally, after three years—of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) and the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson). This is not something that has been decided in a hurry. We have spent quite an amount of time developing policy over the last three years. I am very pleased that some of my concerns are finally being addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me take a little time to explain why I am comfortable that this measure, coupled with many of the other announcements the government is making, is going to address my problem. There are a total of 24 hospitals in my electorate. In the three years that I have been the member for Mallee, I have been involved in the process of attracting doctors to 12 of them. Of those 12 doctors placed so far, only two have been Australians. The hospitals went through an immensely difficult time advertising locally, within the state, across the nation and then, finally, they had to resort to advertising internationally.

This is not something that a hospital or a medical practice chooses to do lightly. It takes 18 months. After the hospital has secured a suitable applicant who is keen, the applicant then has to satisfy the medical board on qualifications and then satisfy the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs on all of those issues. It is a prolonged, tortuous process. As I have said, along with all the other measures being announced, I am comfortable that this decision, coupled with the announcement made by the minister in regard to overseas doctors, will finally address a desperate problem in my electorate, although it may be some time before these measures will have an effect.
