I note that the bill specifically relates to the requirement for medical graduates to complete postgraduate education prior to gaining access to the Medicare schedule and to allow regulations to be made to reduce the Medicare benefit payable when multiple services are rendered. The member for Bradfield has covered those broader initiatives quite well, so I will not take time addressing those.

BREAK.PARA: All of these arrangements are somewhat complicated to explain. I certainly have had a number of young graduates and their parents from my electorate approach me. After I have explained the broad objectives and vision that we have, they become comfortable. It is not about restricting the career path of doctors: there are so many other options available to them.

Hospitals often complain to me that it is difficult to attract and keep doctors in the public hospital system because it is so readily easy for them to gain access to a provider number and move across into private practice. What this part of the bill does is to limit the sort of expected unfettered right to be underwritten at taxpayers' expense through the Medicare system, which has other flow-on benefits. I am quite confident that after a period the direction we plan these measures to take will have effect.

The bill results from the 1996 budget decision to restrict access to the Medicare system and is often referred to as a decision to restrict the number of Medicare provider numbers—which must be held for a doctor to assess Medicare benefits. The scheme focuses on what is an important aspect of this whole issue of rural doctors—that is, education—rather than on an ad hoc or arbitrary system of ballot for the availability of provider numbers.

All of this is strongly linked to the supply of doctors. It continues to amaze me that I have regular requests from medical clinics and hospitals across my electorate, so frustrated by the fact that no Australian doctor has applied for an advertised position. Other speakers have mentioned—and it is recorded in the Australian Institute of Health estimates—that apparently there is an oversupply of 4,500 general practitioners, mostly located in metropolitan areas, whilst electorates like Mallee and Hunter suffer a shortage—a shortage in total across the nation of 500 general practitioners.

It is time for some action on this. I am disappointed that we cannot get the support of those on the other side. It is not about dismantling Medicare at all. It is essentially budget related. But I am absolutely delighted because it is, once and for all, going to be part of a suite of measures to address my urgent problem.

Let me describe some of the experiences that I have had. Currently the city of Mildura, which has a huge base hospital servicing a metropolitan city population of 22,000 people and a regional population of about 45,000 people, is currently desperately short of nine practitioners. They have been advertising and doing all the right things to try to attract Australian doctors, but desperate measures drive people to desperation. They sent their executive officer overseas on a recruitment drive.

You can imagine the impact that the absence of nine practitioners has on the economics of a hospital. So far, only two of the nine positions have been applied for by Australian doctors. It is not just a problem for small hospitals out in isolated areas. Sunraysia and the city of Mildura are part of a very strong population centre with tremendous lifestyle and education advantages, yet it is still difficult to attract doctors.

The provincial city of Horsham down in the Wimmera, which has a city population of about 13,500 people and a regional population of about 25,000, is trying to attract two specialists—an anaesthetist and a gynaecologist. So it is not just the small hospitals that are having difficulties; it is the large provincial centres as well. The fact that doctors have such ready access to their provider numbers makes it far too easy for them to stay in a metropolitan centre and not be attracted to rural areas.

Two modifications to the government's policy relating to the attraction of doctors in rural areas was announced in question time here on 15 October. The minister has made an even stronger statement about overseas doctors since that time. I received a phone call from one of my very small hospitals as a result of that announcement. It was from a community with a population of 300 people. Two and a half years ago their hospital was in desperate strife. It is a very small hospital. In the six months following my election to the seat of Mallee in 1993 their hospital suffered a massive loss of $250,000. The future of the hospital was substantially at risk.

An overseas doctor finally indicated an interest, after 18 months. He was British trained and at that stage was practising in Saudi Arabia. From the time he indicated his interest to the time he finally arrived in Manangatang another eight months had passed. Had it not been for his arrival, there would be no hospital in Manangatang. It has been very pleasant to see the hospital rise from its demise since that time. Two Sundays ago I went to their annual general meeting where an announcement was made that the hospital made a profit of about $144,000. That was the impact that having a good doctor committed to the small rural community had on that hospital. They were so inspired that they invited an additional doctor to the community at Manangatang. He arrived last Sunday. But he is a foreign doctor from Afghanistan.

Those members from the other side who stand up and champion the cause of rural Australia had a long opportunity to address these important issues. Their approach was to fiddle with the supply of GPs. Most notable was the attempt to restrict the number of people entering medical courses. That attempt involved a planned reduction of approximately 200 students per year, but it failed when the Vice-Chancellors Committee could not identify more than 20 places that could be removed in the long term. I think they were a little insincere, although I would not accuse the member for Hunter of that. I know him better. I think it is probably more that he does not quite understand completely and seems a little nonplussed why those of us who represent rural areas are so eagerly supporting this legislation.

I am absolutely confident—and I am grateful for the support of the minister at the table—that what has been a very serious problem and one that has consumed an enormous amount of my time in supporting my hospitals is finally being addressed. I urge all members of this House to support this legislation.

PARA.BREAK: I would like to put on the public record the efforts of the new doctor in the small com munity of Charlton, with a population of about 1,000 people. He is a doctor whose ethnic origins are the former republic of Yugoslavia. He is a Croatian by birth. You can imagine the difficulties we had with his immigration procedure. The hospital was beside themselves, having sponsored his residency application.

BREAK.PARA: In a moment of desperation, Dr Nik, as he is affectionately referred to by the Charlton community because he has absolutely fitted in there and he is 100 per cent committed to that hospital, tried to express his appreciation for the effort that I was undertaking on his behalf with the department of immigration. But I could tell by the tone in his voice that he was expressing some lack of confidence in my capacity to finally win the argument. I simply said to him, `Dr Nik, they will send you back to Croatia over my dead body. I can offer you a consultancy if you need it.' His visa was finally stamped on 2 September this year.

After a period of probably 12 months of complicated wrangling with the department of immigration and satisfying the medical board, the ultimate indicator of just how complex we have let this system become in respect of those overseas doctors who want to make a commitment to rural areas was a request to supply to the department of immigration a letter from the Commonwealth Employment Service saying that no Australian doctor had applied for the position. I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, from your knowledge of the medical profession, how many doctors would actually apply for positions through the CES. But we supplied that letter in compliance. It is just a delight to have a committed doctor such as Dr Nik Kosanovic in the Charlton community making a contribution and ensuring the longevity of that hospital in that vital and very important rural area.
I support the legislative measures in the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) and I urge all members to do the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable members for their contributions to this debate so far. I wish to foreshadow that I will be moving amendments to the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. The amendments have been circulated in the House. I take the opportunity to present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: Under these amendments, all overseas trained doctors who have not registered to practise in a state or territory or commence the Australian Medical Council assessment process by 1 January 1997 will not be eligible to receive a Medicare provider number for billing under Medicare for at least 10 years. New Zealand trained doctors and overseas students who are graduated from an Australian medical school are included in this measure.

I will be asking the Australian Medical Council to ensure that all applicants for the AMC exam, including those already here in Australia, will only get two further attempts or two attempts in total if they have yet to commence the exam, at a maximum of five years to complete the process, as this is in line with the opportunity given to Australian students.

This move is long overdue. Australia graduates 1,200 medical students a year. Australia has immigrating to it approximately 600 further doctors a year. It is absolutely ludicrous that we take another 50 per cent over and on top of our graduation by way of overseas trained doctors. No other country allows this. We have found that, as other countries have progressively tightened their immigration requirements for doctors, we have become a target for many countries overseas.

It is necessary to bring New Zealand into this measure because otherwise New Zealand would have become a staging post for doctors wishing to enter Australia. Indeed, there is some evidence that this is happening already. On the best information that I can get, 32 doctors from one country entered Australia last year: having been born and trained overseas and having moved to New Zealand and taken up citizenship, they used this to have right of entry and practice into Australia. Similarly, with 11 per cent of medical graduates now full fee paying overseas students, we simply cannot control our medical supply numbers if these people have the opportunity of marrying, changing their status and circumventing the original requirements.

There are two elements here. The first is that these people have come from overseas countries, usually our neighbours and friends, with the express intention of returning overseas at the end of their training. It is unfair to those countries from where they came, when those countries have sponsored them, for them to lose some of their best and brightest young people. Should they marry and decide to stay, we are not saying they cannot work as a doctor. There are many opportunities open to them. What we are saying is, `You cannot add to our oversupply of medical practitioners in private practice. You cannot circumvent the immigration requirements for Australia. You have an opportunity to apply for one of the 400 vacancies in public hospitals around Australia. You have an opportunity to apply for one of the 50 vacancies in the armed services or one of the vacancies that currently exist in my department. You can work in academia, you can work in industry. But you cannot get a Medicare provider number.' So, should someone decide to stay, there will be enormous opportunities open to them, but there will not be the opportunity to add to our oversupply.

The Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 also deals substantially with the issue of who can and cannot access Medicare provider numbers. It has been interesting to listen to the debate. I would suggest that this is a debate that will be looked upon in the future because there is no doubt that what we are debating here tonight is a turning point for Medicare. The choice is very simple. You can have a Medicare that is unsustainable and that is doomed to failure—and that is what we have at the moment—or you can have a Medicare that has some prospect of being sustainable over the long term.

The reason is simple. Health has a demand curve that is relatively inelastic. People will demand much of it, regardless of the price. The OECD estimates that between 40 and 75 per cent of health costs are generated on the supply side of health. If we wish to have an open‐ended fee for service system, which we do, and if we wish to keep that affordable, which it is barely, then we have no option but to look at the issue of supply of medical practitioners. If you have uncontrolled supply of medical practitioners and an open‐ended fee for service, you have catastrophe.

Brian Howe, former Labor Deputy Prime Minister and health minister, understood that when he said that the unrestricted access to general practice was a time bomb that would destroy Medicare. Graham Richardson, a former Labor health minister, understood that when he told the AMA in 1993 that the system whereby provider numbers were given as a right of graduation could not be expected to continue indefinitely. Indeed, the AMA understood it when, in 1992, they passed a motion saying that doctors entering medical school could not expect training as a matter of right and course.

The choice here is very simple. You either have a health system that is sustainable, you either have a Medicare that we can hope to finance in the long term, or you have something that will collapse. Over the last decade Medicare has increased six per cent per annum real compound and, in the end, has a budget of over $6.2 billion, larger than the budget of the entire state of Western Australia. That is not something that can go on forever.

It is absurd to suggest that you cannot make changes in medical career opportunities after someone enters medical school. If you wait another six years, there will be another 7,000 doctors in Australia adding to the oversupply already of GPs, just in urban areas, of 4,500. Nobody can expect that career opportunities will not change over six or seven years—and why should doctors be any different? Medicine is a very rapidly developing field. Some areas, such as laparoscopic surgery, barely existed seven years ago. With this sort of rapid development in opportunities, our health system must change to follow medical practice. To suggest otherwise is, quite frankly, breathtaking in its hypocrisy.

In 1989, the rules were changed by the previous government overnight to introduce a vocational register. The government at that time firmly rejected any suggestions that they should wait until the current crop of medical students finished their training. And then, over the last four years, the rebate for non‐vocationally registered general practitioners has remained unchanged. Last year, quietly, in the budget, the previous Labor government took out of the forward estimates any increase in rebates for non‐vocationally registered general practitioners for the next four years over the forward estimates.

At the same time, they made non‐vocationally‐registered GPs ineligible for GP practice grants. They firmly fixed the number of GP training places at 400 a year. And so they set the seeds for a large number of young doctors to have no prospect whatsoever of a career. Nobody could claim that people going into medical school, and young doctors affected by this legislation, have not been aware of the possibilities. As I said, two previous Labor health ministers have made it utterly clear. The AMA itself, in 1992, made it utterly clear. And that just shows the intellectual bankruptcy of the arguments against it.

If you believe the claims made by some people—young doctors and medical students in their national day of action—then, quite frankly, it would be impossible to make any changes whatsoever in medicine. I do not want to see well-trained young people delivering the mail as young doctors are in Italy or Belgium. Quite frankly, unless we bite the bullet and do what should have been done years ago, and do what was inevitable after the 1989 changes introduced by the previous government, that will happen. In the meantime, the uncontrolled increase of medical student numbers, of general practice numbers, will continue unabated and will mean the Medicare benefits schedule will continue to go out of control. That will mean to the overall health budget that I am severely restrained from doing anything in public health, in preventative medicine, in Aboriginal health and in medical research, because the whole budget is geared towards controlling an insatiable supply side driven increase in the Medicare benefits schedule.

This legislation also looks at overseas trained doctors and a quota and excludes Medicare from all those overseas trained doctors who have not registered with the Australian Medical Council from 1 January 1997. The opposition says it wants this to go further. By that it means that it wants those doctors who have already registered to do the exam turned away and denied the opportunity to do so or they want an artificial quota put on doctors who have already commenced the AMC exam to be applied halfway through the process. The vast majority of these doctors are Australian citizens.

There are about 1,200 doctors registered with the AMC. On past experience, we can expect 400 or slightly more to pass eventually. Of those who have already commenced the exams—the clinical exams are under way at this very moment—we can expect about 280 to pass. It would be unreasonable and unfair to put a quota on those who are in the middle of the exam process now. The only effect of putting a quota on now would be to put a quota on the difference between those who pass this time and those who are likely to pass eventually, which is the difference between 280 and 400, which is 120. Given the quota that is being proposed generally—previously it was 200 and it has been suggested it might be 150—the fact is there are probably only another 120 to get through anyway. So a quota would be not only pointless and ineffective but unfair and discriminatory against a large number of Australian citizens.

I considered this point very carefully. Much as it might be difficult for this country to have a lot of overseas trained doctors wanting to go under Medicare, the fact is that the majority of them are Australian citizens. Some came here at a time when we were actively recruiting doctors from overseas. I think it is only reasonable that we give them a chance to have their skills assessed. If their skills are up to standard, they will have a chance to work; if they are not up to standard, they will face the same choices that an Australian medical student faces, that is, to try to find a university which will take them in to get further training or to choose another career.

PARA.BREAK: Those who do pass the AMC exam will be subject to the same requirements as other doctors. They will need additional postgradu ate training, and that is not before time. The effect of successive changes over several decades in health, to be fair, have meant that general practice is the dumping ground for medicine. That has left a bunch of general practitioners who are deskilled and of whom, according to Bob Douglas from the ANU survey last year, one‐third would leave tomorrow if there were something else they could do. Given that general practice is the primary health care network in Australia, I think that is a tragedy. General practice is a specialty area that deserves special recognition and that requires special skills. Two years of training in brain surgery or cardiology equip you not at all to go into general practice. It is about time we were prepared to give general practice the recognition it deserved.

SPEECH.PARA: This does not mean that doctors will be on the scrap heap. As best we can determine, there are about 1,300 advanced training positions available in Australia this year and there are 1,200 doctors graduating. The 280 or so doctors who pass the AMC exam will not all come on stream at once. They will filter through the system over several years because of the requirement to do residency years. The fact is that there will be training for everyone who wants it. There will be the capacity to train somewhere, and it might actually mean that we get some trainees going to psychiatry, rehabilitation or occupational medicine—something that should have happened years ago. I feel no obligation to give every 25‐year‐old, second‐year doctor a guaranteed income for life so that they can go and bulkbill their head off in Medicare clinics up and down the Pacific Highway and earn $100,000 a year. I do not think any of the 80,000 people I represent in the seat of Chisholm think any differently.

Claims have been made frequently, but rarely supported by any evidence, as to the impact this will have on women. The truth is this will have no particular impact on women doctors whatsoever. This is important because women make up over 50 per cent of medical student intakes. There is no reason why women should be trained any less in general practice or any other specialty. One of the specialities that particularly attracts women graduates—anaesthetics—will have a substantially increased number of training places available because of the work done by Professor Horvath through AMWAC, the Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee.

Issues around fairness and gender equity in postgraduate training are issues of genuine concern, but they are not directly related to this measure. They are issues that I have raised with every specialty college that has come to see me and they are issues which I have had a keen interest in for over a decade. I will continue to pursue them with medical colleges, unlike the previous government, which made little change here in 13 years in office.

Medical schools are another aspect that this legislation affects. It has been put that we need more time to put pressure on the deans of medical schools to reduce numbers. The last Labor budget in 1995 proposed a reduction of 200 medical school places in Australia. As shadow minister, I went to the then minister for health and said, `This is a correct decision. I will back you 100 per cent. I will guarantee the support of the opposition. I will give you my word that you will have no criticism from me on this issue whatsoever'—as close to a free kick as you ever get in politics. She delivered 30.

The fact is that this has been an area that has been incapable of resolution. The fact is that it is time there was some action here, not some talk. The fact is the previous government had 13 years to act on this. They had a political vacuum. With the solid support of the opposition, they could still not deliver. How much more time do they think we should take?

In the talks that I have had with the deans of medicine they have been helpful and cooperative. They have some particular problems that I am willing to attempt to address, but there is an issue here of national interest. After having talked about it for more than a decade, it is time we got some action.

There has also been substantial talk about the effect on country doctors. All I say to this is that the RDAA, the Rural Doctors Association of Australia, supports this measure because it understands it will help country practice. The preference that will be given to young doctors going to the country, to country hospitals and to the GP training program will be one of the best things that has happened to country hospitals in decades. I do not pretend that it is going to fix things overnight, but it will help. Along with the four new initiatives that we announced in the budget, it has some real prospect of addressing the issue of rural practice over time.

This bill also addresses issues relating to the Medicare benefits schedule. Again I say this is a dynamic thing. The coalition is committed to Medicare. We have made our peace with Medicare. But, if you do not continually adapt Medicare, it will die. We are attempting to adapt it in a fair way. We are attempting to see that it is sustainable in the future. I regret that the opposition has not grasped this basic fact.

In the end, we were left with a Medicare benefits schedule, as I said, bigger than the budget of Western Australia, increasing six per cent real a year at a time when there was an $8 billion deficit. Something had to give. These changes are sensible.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the bill be read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause 1.
Debate (on motion by Dr Wooldridge) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a message from the Senate transmitting to the House the following resolution:

INTERJECT.PARA: That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the Senate approves the proposal by the National Gallery of Australia to construct an extension to the existing Gallery in Parkes, Australian Capital Territory, for the purpose of conducting temporary exhibitions.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a message from the Senate acquainting the House that Senator Woods has been discharged from attendance on the Joint Statutory Committee of Public Accounts, and Senator Gibson has been appointed a member of the committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 October, on motion by Mrs Moylan:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Dr Lawrence moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1) deplores the Government for abolishing operational subsidies for community‐based long day care centres which will have the effect of increasing the costs and reducing the quality of child care for parents using these centres; and
(2) condemns the Government for breaking its election promise not to means test the Childcare Cash Rebate".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a pleasure to participate in the debate this evening on the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. This bill will give legislative effect to 1996 government budget decisions that discontinue the payment of an untargeted operational subsidy to community based long day care centres from 1 July 1997; apply a reduced rate of entitlement to the child-care cash rebate for families on higher incomes, while retaining the current rate for families on lower incomes, this change to take effect from 1 April 1997; and introduce amendments aimed at clarifying eligibility issues and compliance requirements consistent with the intentions of the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The nature of the operational subsidy that had been applied to community based long day care centres had its origins back in 1972, and then was changed in 1985. So from 1972 to 1985 the operational subsidy provided to community based long day care centres equalled 75 per cent of the salaries of approved qualified staff based on attendance of children on a particular representative day. The funding formula was based on one nurse for each 20 children over the age of three; one teacher for every 15 children over the age of three; and one nurse for every 10 children under three years of age. Then in November 1985 the funding formula was changed and the amount of subsidy paid per child, based on approved places and utilisation rates, reduced the amount of operational subsidy on average by approximately 50 per cent.

I have a bit of experience with community based long day care centres in my electorate. We have a number of them, although they cater for the smaller percentage of children who attend long day care centres in the electorate. In fact, in my electorate of Lyne there are 43 centres servicing the requirements of families with long day care. In the community based long day care centres, there are 251 children; in the family day care section, there are 205 children; and in the private long day care centres there are 602 children. So community based long day care, 251; and privately provided places, 602.

I probably have had more experience with the community based long day care centres than the private providers. It was in 1985 as an alderman on the Greater Taree City Council—and we were known as aldermen in those days, not councillors—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a nicer term, isn't it?

—Yes, it is a much nicer expression. I agree with the honourable member for Shortland. So in 1985 an opportunity was presented to us, there not being much provision of long day care centres in the community, particularly in regional Australia. There were preschools but not long day care centres. The Commonwealth government of the day was providing assistance, along with state and local government, through capital funding, to construct long day care centres.

SPEECH.PARA: The council decided at the time to provide the land and build two long day centres, one in Taree and one in Wingham. Interestingly enough, the Taree community based long day care centre was called Snugglepot and the Wingham community based long day care centre was called Cuddlepie. My second child, Prudence, at a very early age attended the community based long day care centre in Wingham. I was on the council steering committee that was managing both centres. Then we handed the management of those long day care centres over to a community based committee. There was still administrative support exercised by council, but the centres were managed by a community based committee.

With that sea change, as it seemed, people in the community thought, `Shock, horror, we'll never manage this.' The income streams were the same. The support, as far as the attendance of children, was the same. But there went that safety blanket of having the local government body responsible for it—and, of course, from day one the council recognised that at some stage in the future the operational subsidy may not be there.

BREAK.PARA: So those long day care centres needed to be able to get themselves fairly commercially viable in the marketplace, as it were, establish a good reputation and get themselves through the accreditation process. But I make the point that, in changing from a management structure where a committee of the council was managing those two centres to a community based committee at arm's length from the local government body, just as many concerns were expressed then as are being expressed today about this current move the government is making with regard to community based long day care centres.

In the lead-up to the budget—we were assisted in heightening awareness of some of the possible changes by members of the opposition front bench—I received a lot of representations from people in the community about the operational subsidies. What were the majority of those representations about? They were about the operational subsidies for family day care.

I acknowledge that family day care with operational subsidies removed would collapse. Family day care provides a real alternative in the community for working families, single parents, who need those services. Without doubt the majority of representation I received prior to the budget about any changes to subsidies to child‐care arrangements were with regard to the operational subsidy of family day care. We know that the government maintained the level of operational subsidy for family day care.

Community based long day care centres have moved on since 1985. Eleven years later they are operating on 50 per cent of the subsidy they used to and have gone through that process and managed very well. I have complete confidence in the management of the community based long day care centres I know about in my electorate that they will be able to manage this change.

You will note in this package of legislation there is also $8.3 million being provided to assist community long day care centres to overcome the loss of the untargeted operational subsidy. When these centres were set up, from memory there was never any process gone through to target socioeconomically disadvantaged sections of the community or sections within the community that provided that service.

It is like so many other things that the government gets involved in in Australia. To kick something off, the government needs to be involved in it. We are such a large, diverse, remote country geographically with a small population and a small economy in relative terms. So in many instances the government has to start these institutions so we can get those services up and going, get a system in place, to the point where it can and should be able to stand on its own two feet.

The child‐care cash rebate is still available to families in that income bracket who most need it, but the operational subsidy that was provided or is still provided to community based long day care centres was not targeted at any particular group. My daughter went to a long day care centre in my community. I was obviously not eligible to receive any child‐care cash rebate but the subsidy the government provides partly subsidised that position.

It is debatable as to whether the partial subsidy is $20 a week or $4 a week. There are all sorts of figures floating about. I am probably more inclined to accept the lower figure, but I am sure opposition members would run with the higher figure. But it was untargeted. The government is trying to make all assistance that is provided to the community generally more equitable and better targeted to the groups in the community who do need support. That is what this bill is all about.

Community long day care centres will no longer receive the untargeted operational subsidy. In order to manage this change a number of special measures will be introduced to improve access for families with additional needs and to assist the long-term restructuring of these services.

Government funding over the next four years for the child‐care sector will include $526 million to retain operational subsidies for family day care, occasional care and outside school hours care; $31 million to support children with high levels of additional need, particularly those with a disability; $12.5 million to ensure families in severely disadvantaged areas do not lose access to child care; $10.9 million to provide capital funding for new places under the targeted new growth strategy; and, as I mentioned earlier, $8.3 million to assist community long day care centres to overcome the loss of untargeted operational subsidy and to assist in that transition to restructure their financial management practices to accommodate these changes.

Bear in mind that community based long day care centres are not dealing with any overheads or servicing any loans to operate. Those facilities have been bought and paid for either by the Commonwealth or the state or, in our case, the local government body in the area. It will provide a more equitable service. I know there are detractors in here and out in the community who take issue with that being the case.

Interestingly enough, currently 200,000 or 70 per cent of children in child care are catered for by private operators, leaving the remaining 30 per cent subsidised by the government at an average of $20, although it would appear that generally only $4 of that figure has been passed on to the parents in fee relief. Bear in mind that child‐care cash rebate for families earning below the threshold for the family tax initiative cut‐offs will still be receiving that child‐care cash rebate.

There will be a change for those above that level. The arrangements under the child‐care cash rebate scheme will mean families with a taxable income lower than the family income cut‐offs outlined in the family tax initiative, which is $70,000 for one‐child families plus $3,000 for each additional dependent child, will have their benefit maintained at 30 per cent of their claimable child‐care costs, while families with a taxable income greater than the family tax initiative cut‐offs will be entitled to a rate of benefit of 20 per cent. I believe that is a fair measure.

One other issue I wanted to raise, seeing as we are debating the provision of child‐care services at the moment, is the issue of accreditation and the process of licensing. Although these measures that are being introduced by the government address the untargeted nature of some of the subsidies, I believe there is still a need to address the licensing procedures that are in place. There are no linkages, to my knowledge, between the Commonwealth, who funds the places through fee relief, and the states, who actually license the building of new child‐care centres.

There does not seem to be any research done in a community to establish need. The local government body in my area, the Greater Taree City Council, through their community development officer, Mrs Mave Richardson, undertook a study of the number of places available in that particular council area, the number of children attending child‐care centres and the prospective number of children that are going to attend in the near future. They did that to get some sort of a handle on the need for new centres.

There was a fairly strong and sometimes bitter debate in the media over the approval of licensing and a building and development application approval for a new privately operated long day care centre in the area—obviously from other operators, both community based and private establishments as this was another private establishment.

The Department of Community Services in New South Wales is only interested in the criteria it has laid out to establish a licence for a long day care centre; that is, the required qualifications of the staff per number of children there from nought through to five years. It will go ahead and issue a licence with no relativity to the need in the area and no relativity to the impact on the Commonwealth with the provision of fee relief. It probably makes the point that there needs to be a bit more research done in that area as well as stronger communication between the Commonwealth and the states in providing what is a much needed service in all parts of Australia. Otherwise, the industry can keep growing like Topsy.

The other issue I will quickly touch on is that of accreditation. There seems to be a lack of consistency across the board with some of the representatives of the department who undertake the accreditation inspections in my home state of New South Wales. Certainly, it is a matter the minister may pay some attention to in that process to try to ensure that there is consistency across the board in the accreditation process for all child‐care centres, be they private or community based. I just put that on the record as something that is very important. The previous government did implement an accreditation system, which I understand is still in place. It is certainly necessary, as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, to ensure that the child‐care places the Commonwealth provides fee relief for are of a quality standard.

It is interesting to note the history of the provision of the operational subsidy for community based long day care centres from 1972 right through until 1996. They have come from that position through to where we are today. As I said, when we changed the management structure of our two centres in the Manning in 1985-86, there were a lot of concerns. I took a very positive attitude at the time that the people who were going to be charged with the responsibility of managing those centres under the new structure then were quite capable of continuing to provide a good service under the system that was going to be implemented.

For a couple of years I actually chaired the community based management committee that had the oversight of those two centres. Today I have confidence in the people that run those centres to adapt themselves to the changes we have before us this evening and to provide those services in those facilities to people in the community who do need that particular level of care. These measures are going to be better targeted to those groups in the community who need the support of the Commonwealth and the taxpayers of Australia rather than to some people who have had access to support from the Commonwealth but who we believe are at a level of income which takes them out of that category of those who deserve a level of support from the Commonwealth. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Community based child-care centres are not‐for‐profit centres generally operated by the local council, a community organisation or a religious or charitable group. Such is the mix of these centres in the electorate of Calare. Of the 33 child‐care centres in this electorate, 26 are community based, community operated. Seven are privately operated. Some of these community centres, particularly in the smaller towns of the electorate, have depended on amounts like $3,000 and $4,000 a year for their operational subsidy, yet that amount is vital.

SPEECH.PARA: Although community based child‐care centres are located in urban and rural Australia, they make up by far the largest number of centres in rural and remote areas. Why? Because commercial operators do not see long day care centres in these areas as viable, and they are not. The operating subsidy received by community based centres is used to offset the greater expense of operating a long day care centre in these rural and remote areas.

I am not as optimistic as the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). The government's rationale is that the marketplace will deliver, that the playing field must be levelled to offer the same opportunities to private providers that are available for community centres. The level playing field has now reached the playground and again it is not level.

Let me give the example of the Blinky Bill Portland Child Care Centre. Let me paint a pen picture of Portland, the town the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said gave him his first indication of the overwhelming win in the March election. This is an indication that remains a bit of a mystery to me since the town of Portland, hit by the closure of cement works, downsizing and privatisation of the electricity industry and the nearby Lithgow ADI factory, limited job opportunities and only the coal mines offering a valuable income, turned against both Labor and coalition in March and returned an Independent to this parliament because it felt that this local member understood the difficulties and heartache economic rationalism would bring to towns like Portland, whichever party took office. So a coalition member would certainly not be standing here tonight detailing the bleak outlook for Blinky Bill Portland Child Care Centre.

Portland is a town of 2,000 people. Its child‐care centre services 75 families and 100 per cent of long day care users are on child-care assistance. Why isn't Portland attractive to a private child‐care provider? Well, two major employers have been lost to Portland since the early 1990s. Four businesses have closed in the last 12 months and others are reducing their service level. The only remaining bank—which bank?—is rumoured to be closing, although with some foresight and determination Lithgow Council has put it to the Commonwealth Bank by depositing its funds in that very branch, calling the bluff of the banks who are saying to each other, `Don't be the last one out of town.'

That is the business climate in Portland. It is pretty depressing. Forty-four per cent of the children who have gone through Blinky Bill since January this year have left town with their parents seeking employment elsewhere. The local population is steadily declining—not an unfamiliar story on the Central Tablelands, let alone the more struggling centres further west.

And what does the government do? It not only aids and abets the downsizing of banks and other government agencies like Tax offices and Medicare offices but also helps rip the heart out of other soft infrastructure like community child care. Portland's Blinky Bill centre is also a major local employer. It has seven staff—that is, seven families in the town relying on that employment.

Sixty-six per cent or two‐thirds of long day care families use the Portland centre for work‐study reasons. If these families have no child-care centre, and there are no other options, these families, particularly women and single parent families, will have to move, stop their studies, stop child care or maybe leave the work force to look after their child and become a greater welfare burden than if that subsidised child care was available.

There is a real fear that the cutting of the operational subsidy for Portland's Blinky Bill will result in three-quarters of the current clientele deciding to reduce their hours and that fees will be increased by at least $2.40 per child per day, which is almost $600 per full‐time child per year.

That is the story of Portland's Blinky Bill. I can repeat that story for many of the 26 child‐care centres in my electorate. I have had meetings with child‐care operators and I have also inspected the excellent services provided by private operators. The Tired Teddies and Snug as a Rug centres in Orange are state of the art, providing the nought to two-year‐old service that is not a feature of many private operators because of the expense of this age group and the staffing numbers required. But no private operator would seriously look at making a profit in a Portland, a Kandos, a Canowindra or a Lithgow for that matter, so stagnant is that city's economy.

Do not be fooled by the low inflation rate. Business is not in a position to extend overdrafts, let alone borrow, whether rates be lower or not. Take a look at some of the empty shops in country towns. They are doing it tough. Business is slow to dull. One shop in one major centre in my electorate took $20 last Friday. Low inflation in the bush at the moment means people are simply not spending. That is why price movements are slight to non-existent, and that is why private child-care operators will only pick up the market opportunities in the very big centres.

Might I precis part of a letter from Bathurst City Council about the likely impact of the loss of operational subsidy to the community long day care centres operated by that council. It believes the cuts will mean a funding shortfall of $40,000. It believes an increased fee of $25 a child per week will be necessary. However, the council says it cannot and will not charge this fee and will reduce services such as cooked meals and reduce its staff in order to trim back the $25 to the lowest possible increase.

This council's long day care centre and another community based centre are the only two in the city. The other five private centres in Bathurst make no provision for nought to two‐year‐olds because market forces have determined this kind of service cannot be offered in the city without a subsidy.

The nought to two‐year‐olds require a nurse on staff for every 10 children under three years of age, compared with one nurse for each 20 children over three. Bathurst council tells me it is required to care for children with special needs and disabilities and children at risk—factors which undermine their ability to compete with private providers without this subsidy.

The Australian Law Reform Commission study into federal child-care legislation found rural services are disadvantaged because services cost more to operate because of the need to offer financial incentives to attract staff and increase costs for food, services, building materials and so on. In essence, it is the penalty of isolation.

The government is replacing $118 million of operational subsidies with an $8 million scheme Australia‐wide to help these community based long day care centres adjust to the loss of their operational subsidy. That is welcome, but not enough. There is money also in the budget for families in severely disadvantaged areas, but I do not believe it is anywhere near enough to pick up these people who will be set back financially by these moves.

The National Commission of Audit report and the EPAC report into future child‐care provision in Australia did recommend the abolition of the operational subsidy. But, strangely, the information I have received from community based child-care centres in my electorate shows no contact with the EPAC report compilers in the course of that study. Stranger yet, the government has implemented these cuts long before the required response date—hardly a consultation process.

Other amendments in this bill propose a partial means test on the child‐care cash rebate. I believe the charge can be levelled that middle and high income earners will benefit at the expense of lower income earners in the battle for reduced child‐care funds. In fact, the hardship provisions of this bill will not apply until the estimated income is below $15,646 per annum for a one‐child family. I suspect the lower income families in rural areas will do it tough in the towns where no private operator will open up and where the present high and even quality could suffer through a re‐emergence of backyard child care.

I welcome the amendments to allow parents to claim the child‐care cash rebate against two sets of child‐care fees in certain specified circumstances. But, as I pointed out at the beginning of this speech, the loss of operational subsidies for council and community operated long day care centres is likely to have a dramatic impact on families at a time they can least afford it—that is, when there is no alternative child care available or likely to become available in rural and regional centres where the marketplace has failed to deliver and will not deliver. When you lose other services such as Tax offices and banks, the slow downward economic spiral is well under way. The only problem with child care, though, is that you cannot access it on a 1‐800 line.

The bulk of this bill I can accept, but I urge the government to revisit the amendments affecting long day care operational subsidies. The loss of these subsidies could not only spell the end of community child-care centres in some rural areas, including mine, but also exclude from child care some families who could well withdraw from the work force and become a further burden on the taxpayer or, worse still, withdraw their family from the town, so increasing that inexorable flow of population from small to larger centres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, which is before us, proposes the implementation of the following budget related measures. It proposes to discontinue the operational subsidy to community based long day care centres, to take effect from 1 July next year. Let me reiterate that long day care centres are centres that are open for at least eight hours a day during normal working days—that is, from Monday to Friday—and operate for at least 48 weeks of the year. The next measure is to reduce the child-care cash rebate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent for families with a taxable income in the current year lower than the family income cut-offs for part A of the family tax initiative, and that is currently $70,000 per annum for a family with one child.

SPEECH.PARA: Community based long day care centres are the non-profit centres, as other speakers have said earlier in this debate. They are usually operated by a local government authority, a community organisation or a religious or charitable organisation. The centres themselves, particularly in my electorate, are normally administered by a management committee consisting of parents and other members of the community.

This method has benefits for the children, the community and the parents. The centres, I believe, are more responsive to the needs of the children and parents, with the parents being able to experience and observe the effects of any decisions they make or participate in. Again, it provides the opportunity for greater input by parents into decisions that can create a better level of satisfaction with the results of those decisions.

I turn now to the budget cuts and the changes in the budget. This budget cuts a total of $504 million from child care over the next four years. It will add between $14 and $20 a week to a parent's child-care costs in community based centres. That will take time to work through. This is a very clever budget. The cuts and the damage in the budget are cleverly staged but, nevertheless, they will hit. It is simply a matter of time as they work through.

The cuts take a variety of forms and include cuts to operating subsidies of $118.4 million over three years, benefits paid to families limited to 50 hours per week and reduced for second and subsequent children and, finally, a freeze being placed on the upper limit of benefits for the next two years. Community child care has carried a greater share of the more expensive areas of child care—that is, the care of the under two‐year‐olds, the disabled and the at‐risk children. That is a fact that is readily acknowledged by everybody who is in any way involved with the child-care industry.

The removal of the operating subsidies to community child care attacks its future viability. Many community based organisations will not consider it feasible to continue operating a long day care centre without an operational subsidy. Remember, these are community based organisations and I have outlined the kinds of organisations that sponsor the formation of these centres.

BREAK.PARA: In my own electorate, it took quite some time for the councils, particularly the Lake Macquarie City Council, to become involved, to devote resources and to set aside a share of their annual fiscal resources to the operation of these centres. But, having done that, now the goalposts are being changed. The dilemma facing the councils will be how much of their resources they are prepared to devote to this area of activity, to this area of care.

The centres themselves are sometimes the only option for people living in regional or remote areas who need child care. We have heard that fact from the two previous speakers—one an Independent and the other a member of the government. The decline in the competitive role of community child care within the sector also means there is a greater chance of unchecked fee increases. One can argue very easily, as is apparent to many people, that removing the operational subsidy and thus forcing up the revenue that has to be raised by the centre itself indirectly forces them to increase their fees. It also indirectly makes it easier for the privately operated centres to compete with the community based centres regardless of the quality of service they are providing or of the segment of the market they are catering to.

Operational subsidies for community based long day care centres subsidise the cost of care for children who are expensive to care for, especially babies and children with special needs. The abolition of operational subsidies to these centres means that centres will have to charge higher fees—the fact I have just referred to—as much as $21 a week for a child under the age of three and $14 a week for a child aged three and over.

It is all very well for government speakers and the minister to come back and produce some itemised amounts and present some hypothetical circumstances—they may or they may not—but inevitably the costs to parents who currently use these centres will rise if they are able to afford to keep their children there. That will happen, but it will also depend on whether the centre wants to continue caring for those children and babies with special needs.

The Howard government has said that it will provide a certain amount of money to help centres remain open in severely disadvantaged areas. But operators say that it will not be enough and that they will have to pass the cost on to parents. I come back to that point again: what this is about is pushing up the costs for parents who currently use those community based child-care centres.

The child-care cash rebate has been means tested. If you do not qualify for the family tax initiative, the rebate will be cut from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. So the rebate has been cut by some $34.7 million. The introduction of the child-care cash rebate by the Labor government recognised child-care costs as a work related expense. It recognised that child-care costs can be a significant disincentive for women thinking about taking up employment. Like other tax concessions for work related expenses, the rebate was not means tested.

So, despite their promise not to means test the child-care cash rebate, the Howard government is in the process of imposing a means test on it. We are almost seeing a continuing cycle of broken promises. In each item that comes before the parliament, we are dealing with what this government promised in opposition and the alternative—what it is doing now in breaking those promises.

Changes to the income test for child-care assistance mean that all parents will pay more for child care. The Howard government's so-called family budget cuts $282 million from child-care assistance. When we look at this in more detail, we see that 27,000 families will not get access to child-care assistance for more than 50 hours per week per child; 198,000 families will lose child-care assistance from tightening the definition of income for assessing eligibility; 30,000 families lose from the reduction in the income cut-offs for families with two or more children in care; and 650 families will get less help because of the inclusion of additional fringe benefits in the income test.

So the budget freezes the child-care assistance and child-care cash rebate ceilings for two years, while allowing the minimum fee to continue to rise. The combined effect of this set of measures is that some 330,000 families expected to qualify for child-care assistance in 1996-97 will have higher out-of-pocket child-care expenses averaging about $4.25 per week. So, far from maintaining the level of child-care assistance, what is happening is that 330,000 families in this current year are going to be worse off to varying degrees.

The 5,500 planned community based long day care places, worth $79.4 million, will not be built. In some parts of Australia, there are drastic shortages of long day care places. The coalition promised to support the creation of additional places to meet the unmet demand for child care. But, because of this budget, long day care places planned to be built between now and the year 2000 will not go ahead, making it even more difficult to get quality, affordable care.

I heard one of the speakers in the parliament last week say that there is that core of opinion over there in government ranks, and it is really reflected in the view of the Prime Minister, that the place of women is to be barefooted, pregnant and in the kitchen in a single income family. I repeat to this parliament: the Prime Minister cannot go back to his mother's world.
Mr Lloyd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He cannot recreate his mother's world, I say to the honourable member for Robertson. Much as he hungers for it and yearns for it, that penchant he has for the past, there is no turning back the clock. But he can go on, and you will labour on and go like the lemmings following him until you come up against that hard reaction of the community.
—Like Lindsay.

—You can brag and crow, but I will have the last laugh, let me tell you that. I will enjoy it very much, and that smirk will go right off your face. Whilst you can, enjoy yourself. But I can tell you that it is transitory.
—You will be waiting a long time.

—I will not be waiting that long. You are here for a short while. Enjoy yourself while you are here, my dear friend. Mr Deputy Speaker, with the minister on one hand and the member for Robertson on the other interjecting, are you going to offer me some protection, or shall I continue?
—I am sure you do not need my protection. Just ignore them and address your remarks through the chair.
—I am endeavouring to do it, but those remarks that I had to respond to were not through the chair. I look to you always for protection, you know that.

BREAK.PARA: Let me refer to the petitions that I presented to this House on 10 October in respect of a Belmont community child-care centre. That petition objects to the removal of operational subsidies. All of this is in the Hansard. The petition reads:

We request the House support the retention of operational subsidies to community based (not for profit) long day care centres and that community based . . . child care continue to be valued and supported as a lower cost, high quality child care alternative for working parents.

Let me conclude, because we have to limit our time. I want to quote from two letters from my constituents. One is from a mother and father who use the Marks Point child-care centre in my electorate. Dennis Benson, in his letter to me, said:
I have found that the Marks Point After School Care is one of the best run units in Australia. They are very positive in there attitude and response to the needs of the parents and children.

I have found that when money is involved in the private sector, the children's needs are considered a long last in the list of priorities. This I have experienced first hand as I have had a number of moves in my Business Career both Interstate and Locally.
He concludes:
As a responsible parent who cares about the overall Welfare of our Children do not destroy this vital part of our society.
Mrs K. Kerr, of 1 View Street, Belmont, in her letter, says:
I am a working mother of 3 girls and I write (late at night!) with concern over suggested changes to the Childcare Assistance Scheme and operational subsidy to child care centres.

My decision to work is based partly on financial needs—my husband works—but also on my needs as a person and on the future needs of our family. My work is an important part of my life. It is who and what I am.

So, as I said, the Prime Minister cannot go back to his mother's world. The world has moved on, and Mrs Kerr's letter very much underlines that. So I strongly support the amendment in relation to the second reading that has been moved by the shadow minister. I commend the amendment to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor in government had a long history of achievement in child care: the introduction of child-care assistance, the child-care cash rebate and operational subsidies for community based child-care centres. So many new places were provided during our period in government that child care became the highest employment growth category over the past five years. As a result, child care was much more affordable and available. When we came to office back in 1983 there were a miserable, paltry 46,000 child‐care places. When we left office this year, that had grown to 270,000—a complete, stunning transformation.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was a councillor with the City of Coburg during the 1980s, one of our proudest achievements was being part of that transformation in making child care accessible within our own community. I personally had the honour of opening the Pascoe Vale Derby St Children's Centre—two or three doors from where I grew up and where my parents still live. We were also associated with the opening of the Barry Beckett Child Care Centre in Coburg East, the doubling of the capacity of the Shirley Robertson Child Care Centre in Coburg and many others. All along, we were making child care more accessible and more affordable and making it easier for women and sole parents to participate in the workplace.

Labor paid something of a political price for that. If we had had the participation rate in the work force of a generation ago, we would have had much less unemployment. Nevertheless, we were committed to giving women opportunities to work and to giving families options about how they arrange their affairs by making child care affordable and accessible.

BREAK.PARA: So you have to laugh when you hear the Liberal Party talk about families and how keen they are to help families when you look at the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill before the House tonight. This might be an old-fashioned view—and I know there has been quite a lot of debate about what constitutes a family—but from where I sit families mean children. Any government which is fair dinkum in the slightest about helping families would be saying, `We are going to help parents in ensuring that their children are properly cared for if they need to work for a living.' Let us face it, most of us do need to work for a living. We are talking about the battlers here, ordinary parents.
Labor were supporting families with the operational subsidy. The Liberals, by comparison, are withdrawing it. They are attacking families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Liberal members opposite ought to be embarrassed; they ought to hang their heads in shame. Let us not have any more of the cant or humbug about supporting families when you have a bill of the kind which is before the House tonight leading, in the cases of those families it impacts on, to increased fees of the order of $20 to $35 per week per child.

BREAK.PARA: I wish to draw to the attention of the House correspondence from the City of Moreland to the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) pointing out how this bill will impact on the City of Moreland and child-care funding within it. The letter makes the following point:

Currently there are 27 long day child care centres and one Family Day Care Scheme operating within Moreland, providing a total of 1,473 effective full-time (EFT) places. Of these, fifteen are community managed services providing 644 EFT places.
The City of Moreland says:
Removal of the operational grant—
which this bill will do—
will mean a total loss of $616,500 in child care funding from the municipality.

. . . this change will require an increase in fees of between $20—$35 per week. As up to 90% of the expenditure in these centres is for salaries there are very few avenues for cost reduction except for reducing staffing levels or skills. These options would inevitably jeopardise the quality of the child care service provided.

The smaller centres under 35 places, of which there are ten in Moreland, are particularly vulnerable given their limited capacity to reduce costs. These centres will be forced to close or explore options for amalgamation.
The council also express concern about the proposed changes to child-care assistance. They point out:
Within Moreland there is a high percentage of parents receiving Child Care Assistance, ranging from 70% to 90%.
Families with more than one child will be particularly disadvantaged.
These fee increases will be exacerbated by limiting the CCA entitlement to 50 hours per week.
This—
according to their surveys—
will mean an increase of up to $11.50 per week per child for full-time care. This additional cost will generally apply even if families do not use the service for 55 hours per week.
The City of Moreland also express concern about the impact of this legislation on quality. They point out:

It has taken many years to build the impressive network of good quality child care services throughout this municipality. Parents have contributed countless hours of voluntary time to develop and manage these services.

With the changes provided for in this bill, all of that is in jeopardy. The council has urged the federal government to rethink its legislation. The response from the Minister for Family Services that they do not expect any child-care centres to be forced to close and that `there is no need for fees to rise at all if the inefficiencies in the community centres are eradicated' is both wrong and offensive to those involved in the management of those centres.

PARA.BREAK: It has already been reported that the Moreland Child Care Co‐op, which has 25 places and which will lose between $25,000 and $30,000 a year in federal funding through this bill, and the Brunswick Child Care Co‐op, which stands to lose some $37,000 per year, are involved in discussions about amalgama tion. No doubt, other child-care centres are similarly involved.

BREAK.PARA: But right throughout there is great concern amongst these child‐care centres about the impact this bill will have on them. For example, the CARE Day Nursery in Broadmeadows has indicated that they stand to lose around $53,000. Ms McCrow, a director of that agency, has indicated that it is going to hit low income families very hard; in other words, the battlers—precisely the point I made earlier.

As for the Derby St Children's Centre, the centre director, Mandy Canham, has pointed out that it costs $150 a week for full-time child care and that 78 per cent of the centre's 54 families receive fee assistance. A parent who sends her child to that centre, Carol Knight, said:
I would not be able to continue working if I did not receive fee relief. I depend on it.
There are many other parents who are similarly impacted on by this legislation. I have received a letter from one of my constituents—
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the many destructive decisions in the budget was to reduce funds allocated to the parliamentary departments by $10 million a year from a total in 1995-96 of $142 million. One way in which this huge reduction has been accommodated is by combining the staff of committees of the House of Representatives and those of joint committees staffed through the House of Representatives so that one committee secretariat and staff service two committees. The total number of committee staff has been reduced from an already inadequate 76 to 68. The effectiveness of committees of the House is being further constrained.

SPEECH.PARA: The inadequacy of staffing has been exacerbated by the establishment of two substantial new committees—Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs and Treaties—though the impact of this has been significantly offset by the abolition of two standing committees on televising the House and on long‐term strategies. Also, the standard committee membership has been increased from 12 to 14, which increases the complexity of arranging mutually convenient meeting and hearing times. The committees only began operating in June, so it is too early for all the consequences to be apparent, but some of the effects are already clear. The most important is simply that committee secretaries, and to some extent staff, have become schizophrenic, their attention being divided between the demands of two committees. Meeting and hearing times are restricted by those of the other committee.

The staff amalgamation will reduce the capacities of secretaries to be readily available for consultations with chairs and committees. Other cuts to the number of parliamentary support staff intensify the stress. The number of Hansard and printing staff has been reduced, increasing the amount of support work required of committee staff. Most importantly, all this will cause great pressure of work, particularly towards the end of inquiries, which occur simultaneously towards the end of parliamentary sessions. The heavy workload and stress at these times may well cause injuries such as RSI and the breakdown of health of some staff, as it has in other parts of the Public Service, despite attempts by management to prevent personal damage.

It will be necessary for committees to strictly limit the number of inquiries undertaken. It is quite likely that fewer public hearings will be held and probable that inquiries will have to be less comprehensive and reports less well researched. The funding cuts will also reduce the capacity of committees to employ consultants for technical aspects of inquiries. So the work of parliamentarians in committees is likely to be less effective.

The establishment of a comprehensive committee structure in 1987 was one of the significant achievements of the Labor government, undertaken following a caucus resolution and committee report which I moved and chaired. However, the new committees have always been relatively poorly staffed. A relevant comparison is with another inquiry organisation, the Industry Commission. In June 1995 that commission had a budget of $25 million and a staff of 247 compared with the House committee funding of $4.3 million and a staff of 76. Yet in that year the IC produced 17 reports, on a generous definition of a completed report, and the House and joint committees for which the House is responsible for funding tabled 48 reports. There is a case for privatising the Industry Commission, which is now the Productivity Commission, so that it would contest the conduct of inquiries with other research bodies. This would significantly increase the diversity of advice available to government.

The Department of the House of Representatives has commissioned KPMG to make an evaluation of the effects of the committee staffing changes beginning early next year. This will allow more time for the effects to become clearer. In the meantime, committee staff will continue to overwork, there will be some inconvenience and it is possible that the health of staff and the quality of work may suffer. So one of the best means of maintaining an effective communication between parliament and the community will be weakened and democracy will be undermined. This is damaging the effectiveness of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as you are aware, I am fortunate enough to represent much of the beautiful Sunshine Coast area of Queensland. We have a long and very beautiful coastline on the Sunshine Coast. Our nation has one of the longest coastlines of any country in the world and also one of the largest exclusive economic zones of any nation. In fact, our coastline covers 36,700 kilometres and supports 86 per cent of Australia's population and much of our nation's commercial and industrial activity. In addition, the exclusive economic zone represents some 11 million square kilometres of marine waters and their resources double the size of our land mass. The value of Australia's marine resources, according to CSIRO estimates, is around $17 billion per year.

SPEECH.PARA: The executive summary of the state of the environment report released on 27 June this year highlighted the critical state of our environment and, irrefutably, the need for extra work to be done on the environment and the impact created by more than 200 years of European settlement. This report was prepared by over 200 independent experts and identifies major problems facing our environment, such as the soil erosion of agricultural land, degradation of waterways and loss of biodiversity. These problems must be addressed in an integrated and systematic way and will be as a result of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill, which we passed through the House recently.

Specifically, the report does confirm that our coastline has suffered as a result of increasing urbanisation and population growth. Growth along the coastal areas is continuing at an unprecedented rate. In 1993 the coastal zone supported about 80 per cent of the Australian population, although around 70 per cent of Australia's coastline remains sparsely inhabited, which means that there are great pressures placed on local marine ecosystems.

The report also showed that the population of the non-metropolitan coastal zone is growing at an unprecedented rate—2.1 million to 4.1 million between 1971 and 1991. The Australian population in that period grew by only 32 per cent. The Sunshine Coast has shown a major growth. It grows at approximately six per cent per year. Over the next few years the population on the Sunshine Coast will grow to in excess of 300,000 people. That means that we have increasing pressures on our local environment. We need to address the major problem of urban dune encroachment and substandard effluent treatment.

The report I mentioned did indicate one area of particular concern and that is that coastal urbanisation has already destroyed much of the local ecosystem. Between 1974 and 1989, 33 per cent of the coastal bushland along the south‐east Queensland coast was lost. From the coasts and clean seas initiative which we propose as part of our environmental policy, we will indeed benefit. Indeed, all coastal electorates will benefit and, because they benefit, the nation as a whole will have an improved environment to pass on to future generations.

The electorate of Fisher is fortunate to have a number of national parks, two of them being the Bribie Island‐Pumicestone Passage National Park and the Glasshouse Mountains National Park. Pumicestone Passage water quality, though, is not all it should be. Tree clearance in the catchment areas of the passage in the Glasshouse Mountains is the worst in the state. Along with the destruction of wetlands, it has resulted in environmental damage. We have a situation where something needs to be done. The Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996 has passed through the House, and I would like to call upon the Senate to accept that we have a mandate to implement our policy and to pass that bill as well. We need to ensure that the environment that we pass on to future generations is better than the environment which we inherited. After more than 200 years as a nation we have nothing to be proud of. We inherited a continent with a pristine environment and, over 200 years, through successive governments, we have found that our environment has continued to deteriorate.

The coalition government elected on 2 March is the only government to bring forward a detailed environmental package which will redress the 200 years of ignorance and neglect. It is about time that those opposite accepted that they were comprehensively rejected at the time of the last election. It is about time that they accepted that we have 76 Liberals and 18 Nationals, a total of 94 coalition members. There are only 49 Labor, of course, and they are going to seek through the Senate to reject our mandate. It is totally unacceptable. I would like to call on the Senate to pass this bill urgently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP
