TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) should mention the increase in woodchipping as well, while he is at it. On Friday night I had the great privilege of attending the Apprentice and Trainee of the Year awards arranged by the Newcastle Vocational Training Committee for apprentices and trainees throughout the Hunter Valley. I want to pay my tributes to the organisers of the function, to all those who took part, including the sponsors and the businesses involved, and particularly to all the prize winners. They were a very impressive group of people. My particular appreciation goes to Joanne O'Malley, who is the Trainee of the Year for the whole area. That is an impressive achievement, and Joanne is a very impressive young woman.

SPEECH.PARA: The Apprentice of the Year award went to George Saloum, a 32‐year‐old motor mechanic from Macksville. Some years ago George was injured when he was hit by a tree. He was injured to such an extent that he was offered a disability pension. He fought against that and spent three years recovering. Through Nambucca Valley Skillshare, one of the great success stories of the skillshare scheme, he happened to meet Bob Lindsay of Big Bob's Car Care at Macksville. He eventually became an apprentice. He is 32 years old, has three children and he is the Apprentice of the Year. That is a terrific story. It certainly was an impressive night. I extend my best wishes to all the young people who took part, particularly the winners of the overall awards.

The second matter I wanted to mention relates to an incident that occurred on 6 May 1986 when a young woman was pushing a cart of coins up a ramp at a branch of the Commonwealth Bank. She slipped and was pinned to the wall by the cart. It was a minor incident in an otherwise happy and successful life, but that incident was to lead to a 10‐year nightmare. The nightmare ended on 23 August when that young woman and I appeared before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to appeal against a decision by Comcare, which claimed that the injury that had plagued her since that time was not work caused.

The fact is that this organisation needs rethinking. It needs to examine what it is doing and what its responsibilities are. In this particular case, the tribunal did such things as send the woman to a doctor without producing the report. Despite the fact that the report was about the woman's medical situation, Comcare chose to keep it secret. This is not a private organisation; this a publicly funded body with a duty of care to people. In this particular case they failed their duty most dismally. In the Administrative Appeals Tribunal they refused mediation. They produced a doctor, a solicitor and a barrister against a young woman who could not afford any of those.

The hearing before Senior Member Allen was a difficult one because neither the young woman nor I had ever been to a hearing there before, nor were we used to the processes that are involved, which are extremely intimidating. At the end of the day Senior Member Allen found in the woman's favour and upheld her appeal. In other words, an individual has been taken through the process by a government agency which spent a vast amount of money to try to deny her what was eventually judged to be her right. Senior Member Allen was both courteous and understanding of the situation, unlike Comcare, which was not.

Mr Speaker, as a result of that incident and that experience, I am in the process of seeking assistance from your staff to draft a private member's bill proposing that legislation affecting Comcare be changed to allow people to appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal as a first appeal level. The fact that when the organisation makes a decision the only appeal available is to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal through an extensive and complex legal process is inappropriate and unreasonable. The private member's bill will seek to amend legislation so that the first level of appeal will be the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. It is a much more human and more personal service, and I am sure it will give a much better result.

This action would not have been necessary if Comcare had adopted a process of mediation and other processes that were fairer and more reasonable. They chose not to do that, therefore the act must be changed to make them. The organisation and those responsible need to be examined and made accountable. That young woman has been blighted by the organisation. No thanks are due to Comcare for the fact that her appeal was upheld, and no thanks are due to Comcare for their duty of care, which was noticeably absent in this particular case. I trust that when my private member's bill comes forward the House will support this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On Sunday, 27 October I attended the annual picnic day in Broken Hill. It was an event of great success due to the 500 volunteers who took part, the 80 community groups, the 60 business houses and, not least, the 8,000 or 9,000 citizens who participated. But I want to bring to the attention of the House this evening the memorial service that was held there to honour those 704 miners who have lost their lives on the Line of Lode, that famous ore body that has given Australia and the world immense wealth since it was first mined in 1883. I remind the House that another 1,500 have died outside the accident rate on that mine from other ailments such as dust on the lung.

SPEECH.PARA: Seven hundred and four people over the course of a little over a century is an average of nearly six or seven a year who were dying for the benefit of this country. What other centre has made such a sacrifice for Australia? The contribution that Broken Hill has made in lives alone has been immense and is long overdue for recognition. I am pleased to bring this to the attention of the parliament.

What words can we use to describe such an immense loss of life? We are not talking about five people, 10 people, 20 people, 50 or 100, but 704 people. In per capita terms, it is equivalent to a loss of life in excess of 80,000 in Sydney, and that is not even including the 1,500 who died outside the accidents on the mine.

We are not talking about a coalmine. Broken Hill is a silver, lead and zinc mine. It is notable that, of the 704, 702 of the bodies have been recovered. There are only two—Thomas Jordan and Leopold Campbell— whose bodies were never recovered, and of the latter his mother had lost another son on the mine and a son‐in‐law from a previous incident. To attend the service there that Sunday and listen to the Victorian Welsh Male Voice Choir perform, especially when they sang It is a working man I am, the lines of which talk about the dangers and the reticence of people to go underground, brought a tear to the eyes of many of the hundreds of people who were present at that service.

The Reverend Brian Nicholls, who gave the eulogy on the day, reminded everyone that $70,000 million worth of silver, lead and zinc has been taken out of Broken Hill, twice as much as Kalgoorlie has ever put together. He quoted from the book that R.J. Solomon wrote, The Richest Lode, where he says:
In the whole world, few population centres of 25,000 people or more have persisted in areas where there is no permanent source of water, where the annual rainfall is less than 250 millimetres—
that is 10 inches—
where summer temperatures are commonly high and where the seat of government is 1,200 kilometres away—
referring to Sydney—
that Broken Hill has done so for over a century is probably its greatest achievement.

Today the population of Broken Hill has shrunk from 33,000 at its peak to about 24,000 today and the mining community is down to 800. The life of the mine will probably be 10, 12, 15 years, depending on metal prices, exchange rates, industrial arrangements and so on. This town has given us immense wealth over the last century in exports, royalties and better mining methods. It has founded the most famous company we have in Australia today—BHP—and it has given us a resilient spirit which has contributed to the essential Australian character. It is sad that Aboriginal claims around the town are hindering a full exploration effort to keep mining going in that town. It was great indeed to be able to attend the miners' memorial service, and I pay tribute to all those who have lost their lives on the mine over the last century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add some further comments to the grievance debate speech I gave on 28 October about the decision announced in the Australian Taxation Office Business 2000 statement that the Bankstown Taxation Office will close in the period after 30 June 1998. The final decision completely overturned the draft report recommendations for the Bankstown Taxation Office to be retained and for its staffing to be increased from 644 to 800. This decision crushes the very real expectations of the individual taxpayers and small business people of Bankstown that the ATO presence in Bankstown would be enhanced.

SPEECH.PARA: This decision means that the local small businesses in Bankstown, dependent upon ATO staff spending their money in their stores to keep up their profitability, will be put under even further financial pressure. This decision means that the ATO's policy of regionalisation and decentralisation of its offices and services is directly threatened not just in Bankstown but elsewhere.

This decision means that all the ATO's clients in Bankstown will be disadvantaged in terms of their access to the full range of services which was so readily and efficiently provided in Bankstown by the Bankstown Taxation Office. This decision means the contraction of ATO services in Bankstown and the contraction of the local economy. This decision means that Bankstown's individual taxpayers will be put to considerable expense and to a considerable waste of time because they will have to go to ATO offices at Parramatta or Hurstville to deal directly with ATO staff on matters relating to their tax affairs.

The coalition government wants to abandon direct service provision by the Commonwealth Public Service and to drive towards those functions being provided by the private sector through outsourcing. The tremors of this drive are already evident in the ATO Business 2000 document. The overview of accommodation argues that:
The difference between current best practice of around 15 square metres and our existing holdings is the equivalent of 1,200 staff.
Put another way, if we were to accommodate our existing staff at 15 square metres, we would need an average 8 fewer buildings than we currently have.
And, ominously, the document argues that:
Into the new century our major leases expire and, with the benefit of our new experience over the coming years, we will be freer to develop new directions.

That can mean only more job losses and more taxation offices closing: a centralisation, concentration and contraction rather than decentralisation and regionalisation, where a full taxation office service is provided at the community level.

The Australian Taxation Office envisages that, after the year 2000, it will have more flexible accommodation management arrangements. It will use external expertise in strategic management of accommodation holdings and its accommodation standards will be consistent with comparative industries. In all, the ATO sees accommodation as a major business expense. The implications of this viewpoint are that the ATO will decrease both its staffing levels and its regional accommodation after 2000. More jobs will be lost and more government services moved away from the individual taxpayers and industries it is meant to serve.

After the year 2000 we can expect greater contraction of ATO services, greater job losses and a rapid move away from the decentralisation and regionalisation of the past decade. This will be at a greater direct cost to individuals dealing with the tax office, which, having caught the gist of the National Commission of Audit and this coalition government's drive to make the people pay, expects that `the user‐pays concept is common practice in the Australian Public Service for non-core activities'.

This drive towards a contraction of services and to the outsourcing of services from the Australian Taxation Office directly links in with what it perceives to be the drive of this Commonwealth government under the coalition towards putting pressure on the Australian Taxation Office to cut its staff numbers, to cut its accommodation and to cut its direct services to the public. It states specifically that it expects that the government is contemplating a smaller, more competitive Public Service, that the government has made an in‐principle decision about outsourcing IT—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vale, Danna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —A matter of grave concern to the people of my electorate was raised in this House today. I am gladdened by the discussion in which the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) agreed with me and my constituents in Hughes on the importance of exploring a further possible site, particularly Goulburn, as Sydney's second airport.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues on this side of the House will recall that on 21 May this year I requested that an EIS be undertaken at Goulburn at the same time as the EIS is undertaken at Holsworthy in my electorate. I attend many public rallies on this issue. An airport at Holsworthy is the consuming concern of my constituents and I am often asked: why Holsworthy when it was ninth on the list of airport sites back in 1985? Why are we not looking at other sites? Why are we not looking at Goulburn?

With the topic of very fast trains in the media over recent weeks, the prospect of Goulburn presents a very real possibility to my constituents. Not only have the people of Goulburn reportedly expressed a desire to have an international airport located within their vicinity, but the development of very fast transport does lend a good deal of sense to a proper investigation.

I have heard arguments that Goulburn gets fog bound, but so too does Holsworthy. I have heard that the cost and difficulty of delivering the necessary Avgas to Goulburn is great. Yet since 1976 we have had a natural gas pipeline from South Australia which delivers gas to the people of the city of Sydney. With modern technology it is anticipated that as early as 2009 natural gas will be piped from Western Australia to the eastern states. So already in Australia the technology exists to transport gas over very large distances.

BREAK.PARA: I am totally and utterly opposed to any idea that a 24-hour international airport might be located at Holsworthy and so are my constituents. My position on this issue is all the more difficult because in taking such a stand one is against those on my side of this House for whom I have respect, high regard and even warm affection.

Perhaps my position may not be conducive to a successful career in this parliament. But I did not come here for my career; I came here to do a job. I am mindful that I am here and that my colleagues now sit on this side of the House because of the faith of all the people all over Australia. But the people of Hughes also had faith for the first time since 1969, when the present boundaries for the seat of Hughes were created. The people voted for this government.

There is a heavy sense of betrayal, heavy enough to be tangible, angry enough to be expressed in unrelenting protest and it exists in my suburbs in Hughes. After all, we did make certain promises to all Australians before the last election. `For all of us,' we said. `For families,' we said. But my constituents are families too. These are substantially residential suburbs where mums and dads and young couples have invested their lives and their financial security in their homes and in their communities.

We promised for all of us. Yet my constituents are the only people in all of New South Wales who are bearing the burden of the prospect of an international airport. The bushland, environment and green spaces of these suburbs will be detrimentally affected if an international airport is located in their backyard. It is grossly unfair and it is obscenely unfair. There may never be an airport at Holsworthy, but the hardworking families in the suburbs of the west of Hughes already have lost at least $20,000 from the value of their family home, which in the majority of cases is the only asset that they possess.

Ten years ago a decision to investigate Holsworthy would have made good sense, but today there has been significant and substantial extension of residential development in the area. Over 500,000 people now have their homes here. It is also a fair observation that, had the Labor Party shown any political will and clout and completed Badgerys Creek years ago, none of us would be faced with this dilemma today. For today, the air quality and the water quality of the Sydney basin is shown to be under the increasing stress of the intensification of human habitation and activity.

It is bad planning, bad policy and even bad politics to place an international airport in the midst of one of the fastest growing residential areas of Sydney. This may be an exercise in hard‐core economic reality, but it leaves little room for people in its ultimate outcome. Such a proposal is an abomination to family life. It would be a shattering experience to the families in my electorate, and I totally reject it.

I fully understand that the airport at Sydney is also a shattering daily experience for the people of Sydney, but is it a solution if, in trying to correct one unbearable situation for one group of people, life is made unbearable for others? The people of my electorate see merit in many of the matters raised by the member for Prospect and, with respect, I believe such matters ought properly be explored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 60 seconds remaining, I felt it appropriate that the parliament adjourn on a thought that would elevate us, that would lift our sights, that would give us some encouragement and some intellectual nourishment. So I conclude today's proceedings with the great patron saint of democracy, the great hero of conservatism—Edmund Burke. He said in his reflections on the French revolution:

SPEECH.PARA: To be attached to the subdivision, to love the little platoon we belong to in society, is the first principle, the germ, as it were, of public affections. It is the first link in the series by which we proceed towards a love of our country and of mankind.

I simply want to make the point that there are those who regard any form of attachment to one's nation, any form of national feeling, as something to be suppressed. I just want to join with Edmund Burke in the moments left to celebrate the fantastic nation that we have created in this country over the past 200 years.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following notices were given:
Mr Cadman to move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Wool International Amendment Bill 1996 be referred to the Main Committee for consideration.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following papers were deemed to have been presented on 4 November 1996:
Australian Bureau of Statistics Act—Australian Bureau of Statistics—Proposals for the collection of information 1996 Nos. 16, 17.
National Health Act—Determinations 1996 Nos. PHI 15/1996, PHI 16/1996.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are members of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) who served with the UN Multinational Force in Haiti entitled to tax concessions in accordance with provisions in sections 23AG, 23AF, 23ADA, 23AB, 23AD or other provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act; if not, why not.

(2) Are (a) members of the AFP who served in Cambodia, (b) Australian residents employed by the Commonwealth on UN service and (c) members of the Australian Defence Force performing eligible duty outside Australia entitled to concessionary treatment of remuneration received while serving overseas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) AFP members who served with the UN Multinational Force in Haiti will be entitled to tax concessions under section 23AB. Those AFP members who served with the UN Multinational Force in Haiti are not entitled to tax concessions under section 23AG, section 23AF, section 23ADA, section 23AD or any other section of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Section 23AB provides a tax rebate to civilians who, with the approval of the Commonwealth, are serving overseas with an armed force under the control of the United Nations. Section 23AB will apply because the Government has decided to extend the provisions of this section to cover members of the AFP who served with the Multinational Force in Haiti between November 1994 and March 1995.

Section 23AG exempts from income tax foreign earnings derived by an Australian resident individual from foreign service. This section does not apply where the earnings are exempt from tax in the foreign country only because of an international agreement to which Australia is a party and which deals with privileges and immunities in relation to persons connected with international organisations. As the AFP members were exempt from income tax in Haiti because of an agreement between the governments participating in the Multinational Force, authorised pursuant to UN Security Council Resolution 940, and the Republic of Haiti on the status of the Multinational Force in Haiti, section 23AG does not apply.

Section 23AF does not apply because this section only relates to Australian residents working overseas on projects approved by the Minister for Trade. AFP members who served in Haiti were not working on approved overseas projects.
Section 23ADA does not apply because that section only relates to AFP members serving with the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia.
Section 23AD does not apply because that section only applies to Australian Defence Force (ADF) members performing eligible duty overseas.
There is no other provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act that confers a tax concession on AFP members who served with the UN Multinational Force in Haiti.

(2)(a) Yes. Members of the AFP who served in Cambodia are exempt from income tax on pay and allowances if earned while the person was on duty with the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (section 23ADA).

(b) Yes. Section 23AB provides tax concessions for Australian residents who are specified in the Income Tax Regulations. Those Regulations specify that the only persons who qualify for the concessions under this section are AFP members who are part of the UN peacekeeping force in Cyprus and AFP members who served with the UN Operation in Mozambique from 27 March 1994 to 10 December 1994.
However, as previously mentioned, the provisions of this section will be extended to those members of the AFP who served with the UN Multinational Force in Haiti.

(c) Yes. Pay and allowances received by members of the ADF serving in specified operational areas are exempt from income tax under section 23AC. As the only current operational area under this section is the former Yugoslavia, ADF members who serve as part of the UN peacekeeping force in the former Yugoslavia are exempted from income tax on their pay and allowances earned during a period of operational service.

Pay and allowances received by ADF members performing specified overseas duties are exempt from income tax under section 23AD. While this section serves the same function as section 23AC, it simplifies the process by allowing the Income Tax Regulations to prescribe what service is eligible for the concession. There is no eligible duty currently specified in the Income Tax Regulations.
Deployment allowances paid to ADF members who served in Cambodia, Haiti, Iraq, certain areas in the Middle East, Mozambique, Rwanda and Sinai are exempt from income tax under subparagraph 23(t)(iii).

A rebate is available to ADF members who serve in a specified overseas locality (section 79B). The total period of service in an overseas locality does not include any period of service in which the ADF member is entitled to exemption for income tax under section 23AC or section 23AD. A list of the areas that have been declared to be overseas localities for the purpose of section 79B is available from the Australian Taxation Office.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trade and Economic Benefits: Competition Policy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What work has his Department or other government forecasting agency performed on the potential trade and economic benefits to Australia of conformity of competition policy among member nations to (a) the World Trade Organisation and (b) Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation.
(2) Will he advance the issue referred to in part (1) as a major competition policy reform.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) and (b) The Department of Treasury and Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Productivity Commission have been involved in work on the subject of competition policy in international fora. Treasury and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have been involved in discussions of these issues in the OECD and APEC fora. Discussions in the WTO context are at a very preliminary stage. The interrelation between trade and competition policy encompasses such issues as considering how ineffective competition policies hinder market access, the effect of divergent competition laws on global business transactions,, the impact of trade remedies on competition, and the importance of competition law enforcement assistance. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has begun consultations with industry to ascertain its views on the potential trade and economic benefits to Australia and, in particular, on the issues requiring further work. In 1995, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade published a paper on these issues entitled, `Trade and Competition Policy: A Survey of the Issues'. The Productivity Commission has undertaken analysis of the implications for Australia of the completion of the Uruguay Round, and of the commitment to free trade required under APEC. In September 1996, the Productivity Commission published a paper entitled `International Cooperation on Competition policy: An Australian Perspective'. It noted that a greater commitment to competition principles (including removal of tariffs) by APEC economies could raise Australian real income by over 6 per cent in the long run.

(2) The Government is participating in discussions on competition policy in the WTO and APEC fora. It is in Australia's interest to support continued work in the trade/competition policy field. Australia has a `world class' competition policy, and efforts to improve competition policies and laws of other countries are likely to benefit Australia through increased access to overseas markets. The Government strongly supports the exposure of regional markets to greater competition, including through implementation of competition policy principles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 June 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Securities Commission investigated whether the Guangdong Corporation share float was closed and subsequently re‐opened specifically to enable shares to be allocated to Mrs Felicity Kennett.

(2) Do the Corporations Law, Australian Securities Stock Exchange rules or other provisions prohibit the closing of a share float and subsequently re‐opening it without the same opportunity for further share allocations being available to all potential investors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Under section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989, the Australian Securities Commission is authorised to investigate only where it has reasonable grounds to suspect that there may have been committed a contravention of certain laws, including the Corporations Law. I am advised that the Australian Securities Commission considers that the manner in which shares were reported to have been allocated to Mrs Kennett did not, in its view, appear to be in breach of the Corporations Law.

(2) In general terms, no. I am advised by the Australian Securities Commission that any relevant conditions concerning the manner of share allocation would be set out in the prospectus. I am also advised that, in this case, there were no relevant restrictions and the company had reserved the right in the prospectus to be extremely flexible in making allocations for shares and there were no guarantees of equal treatment for potential investors.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tax Concessions for Research and Development

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Which companies in the electoral division of Wills have received taxation concessions for research and development since 1 July 1994.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has advised that as a matter of law (Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936) it is unable to provide details on the tax affairs of individual taxpayer companies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 10 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Have airline operators complained regarding delays experienced in (a) landings and (b) take offs of aircraft at Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport (KSA) during the period 3 April to 9 September 1996; if so, what are the details of each complaint including (i) the date of each complaint, (ii) the name of the operator or operators, (iii) reasons for the delay and (iv) whether or not the East‐West runway was operational when the delay occurred.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Airservices Australia has provided the following advice:
(a) and (b) A formal complaint was received relating to take-off delays on runway 25 (take‐offs to the west from the east‐west runway).
(i) The complaint was dated 7 June 1996.
(ii) The complaint was from the Regional Airlines Association of Australia but referred specifically to delays to Kendell, Hazelton, Aeropelican and Tamair flights.

(iii) The reason for the delay was that there were many flights scheduled to depart at around the same time and only one runway was being used for departures. Single runway operations were used as an interim measure between 3 April and 15 June 1996. Since that time Airservices Australia have introduced a number of air traffic management initiatives to ameliorate the effects of aircraft noise and enhance the efficiency of operations.
(iv) Yes, the east‐west runway (runway 25) was in use.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 11 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: How many Medicare offices will be closed in the electoral division of Hunter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has not said that it is closing specific Medicare offices. As part of our initiative to introduce pharmacy agencies, which will enhance access for Australians to make claims under Medicare, the Health Insurance Commission will undertake some rationalisation of its office network.

Some Medicare offices can be expected to close where the level of demand for services does not justify keeping an office open—this may be for a range of reasons, such as higher than average levels of `bulk billing'.
However, the Government has not at this time decided which, and how many, offices may close—local community views will be considered in examining the viability of particular offices.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 17 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Inland Marketing Corporation's Parkes freight airport proposal economically viable.
(2) Will the Government provide financial support to develop the project.
(3) Has his attention been drawn to NSW Government financial support for an Environmental Impact Statement study being carried out into the project.
(4) Is there a need for a freight‐specific airport being located in eastern Australia; if so, where.
(5) Is there a need for increased capacity to meet the needs of freight‐specific aircraft in eastern Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Neither the financial nor the economic viability of the Inland Marketing Corporation's (IMC) Parkes freight airport proposal have been established. At my request the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform is currently conducting an Air Freight Review Inquiry which includes consideration of opportunities to improve the efficiency of Australian exports, particularly perishables, through enhancing Australia's air freight services. The Inquiry is specifically investigating the need for, and viability of, additional international aviation infrastructure to cater for regional needs. Opportunities for improved coordination and linkages in the export air freight chain are also being considered. The IMC has made a number of submissions to the Inquiry and the Committee is aiming to finalise its work and report to Parliament by the end of 1996.
(2) Further assessment of the IMC proposal should await the findings of the Parliamentary Committee.

(3) The Government is aware of the Environmental Impact Study (EIS) process in place, but notes that the scope of the EIS will only include a very limited financial analysis of the benefits and costs of the proposal.
(4) The Parliamentary Committee's Terms of Reference specifically include consideration of the need for, and viability of, a freight‐specific regional airport.

(5) Evidence provided to the Parliamentary Committee to date suggests that generally the handling and capacity requirements for freight‐specific aircraft can currently be fully met by existing international airports on Australia's east coast. However, this matter is being fully examined by the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 17 September 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) How many persons benefited from treatment under the Commonwealth Dental Health Program in (a) the electoral division of Denison and (b) Tasmania in (i) 1993‐94 (ii) 1994‐95 and (iii) 1995‐96.
(2) What was the average waiting period for dental treatment under the Program during the years referred to in part (1).

(3) Has he received advice or information from his department or ministerial advisers, or from the Tasmanian Government, relating to the effect the abolition of the Program will have on dental care waiting periods for health care card holders in the electoral division of Denison and Tasmania; if so, what was that advice or information and by whom was it provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to provide information on the number of people treated under the Commonwealth Dental Health Program in the electoral division of Denison because the Department of Health and Family Services does not collect dental statistics on an electoral basis.
The number of people treated under the Program in Tasmania was:

(2) It is not possible to derive annual average waiting times for the Program because waiting time data provided by the States is either non‐existent or incomplete. However, a survey published by the Dental Statistics and Research Unit at the University of Adelaide in January 1996 showed that in a 12 month period between 1993 and 1994, the following waiting times were being experienced under the Program:

In November 1995 the Department sought advice from the States on waiting times. Most States reported overall improvements in waiting times, although this was not necessarily uniform across regions within States.

(3) No. The impact of the abolition of the Program will depend upon whether States decide to increase their own funding for dental services. I have not been informed of the position of the Tasmanian Government in this respect. In response to a recent Senate Estimates request Tasmania was not able to provide the information on an electorate basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the formula specified under subsection 221YAAA(3) of the Income Tax Assessment Act allow the provisional tax uplift to fall below six per cent; if so, how.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The level of a provisional tax uplift factor for a year of income after the 1996‐97 year of income, depends on the degree of positive change of a later calender year gross domestic product (GDP) over an earlier calender year GDP. These are the main factors in the formula in subsection 221YAAA(3).

Where the percentage degree of change of the relevant years' GDP is less than six per cent the formula provides for the provisional tax uplift factor also to be less than six per cent. Under section 221YAAA, the only time the figures produced by the formula will not be used is where the figure is negative. In this situation, the provisional tax uplift factor is zero per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 19 September 1996:

BREAK.PARA: What action has been taken or is in train to provide a second general aviation airport in or around the Perth metropolitan area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth is not involved in any planning for a second general aviation airport in or around the Perth metropolitan area. Any such future development would be a matter for the appropriate State and local government authorities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Dental Health Program: Electoral Divisions of Wills and Chisholm

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 8 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many persons benefited from treatment under the Commonwealth Dental Health Program in the electoral division of (a) Wills and (b) Chisholm in (i) 1993‐94, (ii) 1994‐95 and (iii) 1995‐96.
(2) What was the average waiting period for dental treatment under the program in the electoral division of (a) Wills and (b) Chisholm during the years referred to in part (1).

(3) Has he received advice or information from his department, ministerial advisers or the Victorian Government relating to the effect the abolition of the program will have on dental care waiting periods for health care card holders in the electoral division of (a) Wills and (b) Chisholm; if so, what was that advice or information and by whom was it provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This information is not available as the Department of Health and Family Services does not collect dental statistics on a regional or electoral basis.

(2) It is not possible to derive annual average waiting times for the Program because waiting time data provided by the States is either non‐existent or incomplete. However, a survey published by the Dental Statistics and Research Unit at the University of Adelaide in January 1996 showed that in a 12 month period between 1993 and 1994, the following waiting times were being experienced under the Program:

In November 1995 the Department sought advice from the States on waiting times. Most States reported overall improvements in waiting times, although this was not necessarily uniform across regions within States.
(3) No. Victoria has advised that it is not able to provide the information on an electorate basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 15 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the Commonwealth Dental Health Program introduced.

(2) For each year since it commenced, (a) what sum was expended on the program, (b) how many persons benefited from the program and (c) what impact did the program have on waiting lists for dental services.

(3) Did his Department provide advice on the effect terminating the program will have on (a) the number of persons affected by the decision and (b) dental waiting lists; if so, what was that advice; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Program was announced in the 1993 Budget context, with the Emergency Scheme component commencing 1 January 1994 in most States and the General Scheme 1 July 1994.

PARA.TAB: 1995/96—656,000 (target number)
1996/97—328,000 (target number)

ANSWER.PARA: (c) In November 1995 the Department sought advice from the States on waiting times. Most States reported overall improvements in waiting times, although this was not necessarily uniform across regions within States.

(3) On advice from States (as stated above) waiting times had improved and my Department advised that the target number of additional people treated for the Commonwealth funds provided would be reached by December 1996.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Council for the Order of Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 16 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 679 (Hansard , 9 October 1996, page 5065), had successive Chief Justices of Australia chaired the Council for the Order of Australia before the Governor‐General invited Rear‐Admiral P.R. Sinclair to chair the Council.
(2) On what date and in what circumstances did Chief Justice Brennan cease to chair the Council.
(3) Who are the members of the Council who have been nominated by the Commonwealth Government.
(4) On what date was each appointed.
(5) What are each member's principal qualifications.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, until the appointment of Sir Anthony Mason AC KBE as Chief Justice, High Court of Australia, expired.

(2) Chief Justice Brennan AC KBE was never appointed to the Chair of the Council for the Order of Australia. The Report of the Review of Australian Honours and Awards (p.268) made it clear that the Chief Justice had indicated to the Governor‐General that he did not consider it appropriate for him or any other justices of the High Court to serve on the Council.
